Dear Mr. Graham—

I am enclosing quotations and invoices of plumbing materials which I purchased on block for four houses thinking by getting the four equipments together I would save on the whole.

I also thought I would be able to carry same on my cash intakings but find that I have really bitten off a little more than I can handle and as these people want their money I am sending same on to the Dept. with your endorseration wondering if they perhaps could find sufficient in the N. E. C. grants to cover the purchase.

As you know these additions were greatly needed and add materially to the comfort of those concerned.

Beyond the price of the material it has not cost any extra as I had the Houses, including my own, fitted and installed by the handy man at the school.

I trust you will find the above in order.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal

Dear Sirs:

Referring to our account in the sum of $691.68, for goods supplied to Rev. R.A. Lett of St. George's Industrial School, Lytton, B.C., on a net cash basis, we were advised some time ago that this account had been approved for payment, and that we should receive a cheque in the near future.

When we were requested to quote prices on a net cash basis, we presumed that the party from whom we received the order would pay for these goods on the cash basis. Later we were asked to send our account to the Government for settlement. Therefore, instead of purchasing the goods on a cash basis, the terms basis should have applied, which is a higher price.

Inasmuch as there has been this misunderstanding through no fault of ours, we specially request that you give this matter your attention upon receipt of this letter.

Thanking you, we are,

Yours very truly,

KYDD BROS.

[Signature]

HPK/DB

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have been leaving off our Ice proposition as long I fear as I dare, in hopes that the weather might turn somewhat colder and we would be able to harvest our ice on the river as we have heretofore been able to do.

This has thus far been a very mild winter having had a maximum of only fourteen or fifteen degrees of frost, and we cannot get Ice within five hundred miles, and to pay for the cutting and freight on fifty tons would run us into a bill of approximately four hundred dollars. This is rather a heavy bill for us to handle with our finances at such a low ebb and must ask you to approach the Dept. to see if they would undertake this expenditure for us as we cannot do without some means of keeping our meat and other perishable foods.

I would like to suggest an alternative, which is that the Dept. add to the above amt. four hundred dollars with which to install a Celco Freezing system. These I believe are giving satisfaction and can be run at a maximum cost of seven and one half dollars per month. This would not only do away with the worry of waiting on the weather but would also save us a round sum even though we were able to harvest our ice at the greatest possible convenience. The plant could also be transferred to the new school when built at a very small cost.

I hesitate to go to you at this time but it is a necessity that we cannot very well avoid.

Yours very sincerely

[Signature]
Principal
Sir,— 

I herewith beg to enclose financial report for January, 1926, from St. George's Industrial School, which I trust will be found in order.

I am also enclosing a letter from the principal concerning ice. This is a very important matter, and there seems to be no prospect of cutting any ice anywhere round this neighborhood this winter.

Trusting the Department will give its early attention to this matter,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

March 19, 1926.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

Mr. H. Graham, Indian Agent, Lytton, B.C., under date of February 17th has issued instructions to place before you a quotation covering the installing of a Frigidaire Iceless Refrigerating equipment in the St. George's Indian Industrial School, Lytton, B.C.

The equipment which we propose is our one-half horse Power Compressor Assembly together with two Model SS-F specially designed Frigidaire coils. This is the latest equipment recommended by our factory for a refrigerator such as you now have in the school.

For your information we were at one time discussing a brine tank equipment with Mr. Graham. The above equipment recently designed by our engineers have replaced the old brine tank. Consequently we are very glad to be in a position to quote you on an equipment which is an improvement over the older system of refrigeration.

This entire equipment installed complete and in proper running condition lists at $825.00 nett. We are enclosing folders which illustrate a portion of this plant. We have not yet received folders which illustrate the new cooling coil system.

You will recall that we had the pleasure of supplying a Delco-Light equipment for the above school. We are told it has been particularly satisfactory. We believe we can guarantee the same satisfaction with our Frigidaire equipment.

We trust we may have the pleasure of your instructions.

Yours very truly,

BRUCE ROBINSON ELECTRIC

Manager.

THERE'S A SATISFIED USER NEAR YOU
Ottawa, March 26, 1926.

Gentlemen:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, quoting on a Frigidaire Iceless Refrigerating equipment installation in the Lytton Indian Residential School. This institution has to generate its own electric current, and I am not satisfied that such equipment would be suitable. The matter, however, is now under consideration, and your quotation will not be overlooked.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Bruce Robinson Electric,
544 Howe St.,
Vancouver, B.C.
Ottawa, March 26, 1926.

Sir:

With reference to my letter of the 12th ultimo, I have to inform you that the Department has received literature from the Bruce Robinson Electric Co., of Vancouver. It is extremely doubtful whether any type of electric refrigeration is suitable when the school has to generate its own current. I am writing to suggest that you enquire concerning the possibility of securing a carload of ice, which should be stored in the school. If this commends itself to you, please let me have a recommendation, with an estimate of the cost, by telegram, if dispatch is necessary.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Attention Mr. J. D. McLean
Your #165-0-5 March 26/25
Re Frigidaire Iceless Refrigeration Lytton Industrial School.

Dear Sir:

Before recommending this equipment to Mr. Lett, the Superintendent of your school, we very carefully considered the question of your supply of Electrical Current. In a few words, Mr. McLean, here is the situation.

Your Delco-Light plant has a generating capacity of from 2½ to 3 kw, in addition to a heavy duty Storage Battery, which forms part of this equipment. In all, you have an equipment capable of handling an active load of 4000 watts during the average twenty-four hours.

The Frigidaire equipment proposed requires a 1/2 HP Motor. This motor in turn requires some 375 watts only of current on its starting torc, using considerably less current to carry the load of the compressor to which it is connected.

We do not hesitate in recommending this equipment for another reason, namely your Frigidaire equipment would be most active during the day, at which time very little current is being used from your plant.

After again considering this equipment from every angle we still feel justified in recommending Frigidaire for the Lytton school, believing it will be a very satisfactory and efficient means of saving food supplies and also in protecting the health of the children.

We trust the points on which we have touched but lightly in this letter will induce you to accept our recommendation.

Yours very truly,

BRUCE ROBINSON ELECTRIC
Manager

THERE'S A SATISFIED USER NEAR YOU
Sir,

I have departmental letter dated March 26, re the proposed refrigerating plant for St. George's Industrial School.

I wrote to the Delco Light Company, as this company is the Agent for the Bruce Robinson Electric Company, and am just in receipt of a reply, together with a copy of one sent to you, which will explain itself.

I have talked the matter over with the Rev. Mr. Lett, principal of the school, and he states that he has made enquiries for ice and there is none to be had inside the Province, excepting artificially made ice, which would amount to as much as the plant would by the time we got it here.

I might state that the same refrigerating plant is being installed in this town for the butcher shop, and in other small towns in the interior, and is proving a great success, so we can see no reason at all why it should not be successful at the school. This plant can be moved into the new school when it is erected, so it will not be lost.

Trusting the Department will give this favorable consideration,

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(W. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir;-

We have your esteemed letter to hand of the 5th, with a rough plan attached for an Indian Residential School in B.C., stating that your building will require an 8K.W. plant. We believe, in buildings that would require a plant of this size that the parallel lighting equipment which we supplied for Cardston and Edmonton, is the best thing which we can offer you as these plants are working out very satisfactory.

A detailed description of these plants, we believe, might be in order and might say they consist of the following;-

Two plants, one a 3K.W. and one a 6K.W. both automatic in starting and stopping, working as follows;-

When the small lighting load first comes on the 3K.W. plant starts up and carries the load up to 90% of its capacity. At this point the 6K.W. plant starts up and takes over the load and the 3K.W. stops when the 6K.W. plant has reached full load. The 3K.W. starts up again and they both work in parallel, carrying their load to the maximum limit. When the load is decreased to the point where the 6K.W. can handle it, the 3K.W. stops and when the load is further reduced to the point where the 3K.W. can handle it, it starts up and takes over the load, allowing the 6K.W. to stop and it continues to carry the load until it is reduced to minimum when it also stops. This feature is very economical as the small plant only runs a large portion of the time.

Further automatic features is incorporated in this system, that if at any time the small plant ceases to function, the larger one automatically starts and takes over the load, thereby safe-guarding the batteries.

This plant is equipped with a battery of 54 cells of 85 A.H. capacity on the 8 hour rating which is of adequate size to carry the required number of lights up to a point where it will be more economical for the plant to start up and take over the load.

We wish to point out that these features are absolutely automatic, requiring no manual attention in transferring the load from one plant to the other in any way. All the attendant has to do is to look after his lubricating oil, fuel and cooling water.
Mr. R. Guerney Orr, (continued) --- 2 ---

You ask what our recommendation is in the driving of a Laundry and might say we will not consider putting our plants up against a motor driven load for this work. We have found in every instance where we have done your work that the handling of a laundry machine is in the hand of inexperienced persons and if an electric motor were used for this work there would be times when the motor would be driven off the battery instead of having the plant running to supply the necessary current. This discharge for a 3H.P. motor taken from the battery until the plants got started, would eventually ruin the battery and on every laundry drive which we have hooked our engines up to, 3H.P. has not been adequate to drive them.

We might say the Edmonton Laundry, when in operation, takes from 5 to 5½H.P. Our other reason for preferring mechanical drive from the engine is that when the laundry is running, the engine can be used at the same time to give the required overcharge to the battery, thereby doing both these jobs at one time and safeguarding your battery instead of taking the discharge from it.

We have been handicapped on the most of our jobs by making our machines fit the room and the line shaft drive and the opportunity which you are now giving us to place our space requirements before you is very acceptable. In the engine room shown on the plan which you sent us a line shaft will be running parallel with the long way of the laundry and will be running parallel with the short way of the engine room. This means that we have to place our plants then one behind the other which makes a more expensive installation and consequently is more costly to the department as it takes more piping and fittings, etc. If the engine room were placed the long way the same as the laundry, then our plants would be put end to end, making a cheaper method of installation and a belt would go from the pulley on the engine straight up to the pulley on the line shaft, instead of on the slant, thereby obstructing the movements of the operator around the machine. To make this a little clearer, we are making a drawing showing what we consider an ideal arrangement for this type of plant. However, on the other hand this might not suit your building requirements and we want to co-operate with you making any alterations which you would prefer and any suggestions we can offer we will be glad to do so and trust to hear from you further in reference to this. The dimensions of the engine room especially if a pump is to be located in the engine room requires to be 20 feet long by 14 or 15 feet wide.

Trusting that we have made this matter clear to you, we are,

Yours respectfully,

R.A. LISTER & COMPANY (CANADA) LTD.

Sir,

The Department is contemplating the building of a new Indian Residential School at Lytton, B.C., to accommodate approximately 150 children. It is proposed to make a commencement this year by erecting a portion of the building. I would greatly appreciate it if you would instruct one of your officers in this locality to visit the site of the proposed new building, and furnish me with a report and plan for a septic tank and drainage system.

Regarding the water supply system for the building there is located to the rear of the proposed site, at a considerable elevation, a running spring, and it is proposed to use the water from this spring to supply the building. Two years ago when we were erecting a new barn at this point a six inch pipe was laid from the spring to the barn, and it is thought that this pipe can be tapped in order to provide water for the building. It will be necessary to construct a concrete reservoir at the source of supply, and I would be glad if your engineer would furnish a plan of the reservoir, and advise me the elevation of the spring above the level of the building site.

The principal of the Lytton School is the Rev. Mr. Lett, and he will be glad to co-operate with your officers in giving them any information that will assist them. There is an old school at this point at present. I am enclosing herewith a blue print of the basement plan of the building intended to be erected this year, and also a rough sketch showing the size of the building. It would be of great assistance if your officer would include a block plan showing the location of the proposed building, the existing barn and the spring, septic tank, etc.

As it is the intention of the Department to invite tenders early in the spring, I will be glad to have this information at your earliest convenience.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

The Rev. Principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School has ordered fencing for Lot 47, the property on the hill. The cost is $385.40. He asks the Department to pay this account from the New England Company grant and to allow him $200 for Indian labour for the erection of the fence.

All future payments from the New England Company should be held in trust for an indefinite period. At present, there is in the account (No. 460) $2900. Approximately $1,000 of this will be required to pay veterinary charges (File 165-0-14). Some $1900.00 is available for other purposes.

I wish to recommend that this account and the labour for the erection of the fence be allowed and that the Rev. Principal be informed of our plans in connection with the New England Company payments, so that in future he will understand that he is to get along practically entirely on the per capita grant.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, April 22, 1926.

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have directed that the account for wire fencing for Lot 47, Lytton Indian Residential School, be paid and that $200 be advanced for labour. The funds will be taken from the New England Company grant. The payments to the Veterinary who is attending the milch herd will also be taken from this source.

I am writing to inform you that these grants will be the last that can be allowed the school from the New England Company funds. It is necessary that the quarterly payments from London be held in the Department in future and I am asking that you will from this date finance the institution on the per capita grant. Your reports from time to time are very encouraging; the latest fiscal report shows marked improvement since you took charge and I am hopeful that, financially and otherwise, the school will continue to make progress.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B. C.
Sir,

I wish to thank you for yours of April 22nd Numbering 165-0-5 allowing the use of the N.E.C.Grant for the fencing of Lot 47 which work has been finished, and also for the expenses entailed in the needed looking after of our Dairy Herd, good results have already been realised and we are now feeling that we shall have our Herd back into shape. We shall I hope have 25 cows milking next winter.

As you are no doubt by this time aware of the fact that water is very short in this district, and due to this fact our upper Lot is idle. Last year we were able to feed our Range Stock here besides baling some 50 tons for sale. Having no production at Lot 47 our source of revenue is not going to be as great as was contemplated and with the withdrawal of the New England Co's Grant I shall be obliged to look for some source of financial aid in order to make ends meet. I therefore must ask if you would agree to provision being made in the way of erecting temporary dormitory room in which I could handle ten or fifteen boys who are now on the waiting list. The staff at present in the school could handle this extra number and outside of the expense of building the necessary housing I would not be at any further expenditure excepting of course the feeding and clothing.

Besides the financial aid to the school I am sure you will agree with me when I say that every care should be taken in not letting these children get too advanced in age before entering school and as the majority of some thirty applications on file are voluntary it is I should think the more necessary.

It is my intention to do this building during the coming vacation so that at the re-opening of school I shall begin the new year with about 118 children. With your consent I shall begin immediately to make this provision.

Again thanking you for past favors and trust the above will receive your close and sympathetic hearing.

I beg to remain Sir

Yours very obediently

Dear Mr. Scott:

In view of the fact that there is no immediate prospect of beginning the erection of the New School, I would again appeal to you on behalf of the temporary Dormitory. A building 25x40 would be sufficient to cover our needs. Material used to cost approximately £225.00 including brick flue and making provision for windows doors and etc., with a total cost equipped with beds and bedding of not more than £600.00 which amount would be only £50.00 in excess of one quarter PER Capita earnings which amount I would be willing to be held by the Dept if you should see fit to be unable to make the expenditure outside of Per Capita earnings.

There are three outstanding reasons why I am again approaching you re this matter,

1. The children are available and should be in school.
2. By being able to remove ten boys from the present dormitory would relieve over-capacitation insuring better health and less worry. In fact we are at the present time occupying dormitory room which is not at all sanitary and is ill ventilated.
3. The additional Per Capita Grant will greatly relieve present financial difficulty.

You might think that I am asking for too much temporary room when I ask for temporary housing of 20 or 25 yet it means that by making room for this number and only taking in an extra ten the present dormitory relief would be an asset to the children and the school on the whole.

It also will be some time before we shall be able to occupy the proposed New Buildings and same being built in units it will prolong occupancy and a temporary of this type this nature could be utilized to advantage for some time.

I shall enclose a rough sketch of the building.

Yours very obediently

Dear Sir;

In view of the fact that a blood test of the dairy herd at the St. George's School, Lytton, for abortion disease, shows that fifty percent of the herd is infected, and that owing to lack of sufficient building it is impossible to segregate the healthy from the diseased animals, I wish to bring to your notice that in order to raise a healthy herd it will be necessary to build more dairy barn accommodation; also an isolation stable to take proper care of discharging cows.

Dear Mr. Graham:

In connection with the condition of our Dairy Herd I would like to point out that Dr. Jagger has lately had a blood test taken through Dr. Bruce of Agassiz in the Dominion Lab., the result finds that fourteen out of twenty-nine head have reacted to the test for abortion, resulting in the fact that we are in a rather precarious position, having no isolation facilities wherein to put these cows. Under these conditions there is not much hope of ever getting the herd cleaned up.

By this time you may perhaps have a letter from Dr. Jagger suggesting that an Isolation Barn be erected which is a necessity, not only at the present time, but also would take care of other sickness in the herd, and in many other ways could be used to great advantage even when the herd is in normal health conditions.

You have been through the barn when Dr. Jagger was working and have, for yourself seen, the difficulties under which we are obliged to work. Our abortion cases are now kept in the Hog Barn where they must stay for a period of from four to eight weeks until all discharges have ceased before transferring to the main barn, thus entailing an endless amount of work in carrying food and water, cleaning, milking, etc., besides running the risk of our brood Sows contracting the disease, as the Dr. has stated that there is grave danger of this latter happening.

Together with this there is the fact that our herd is growing and shortly we will be pressed for room. Again it is our intention to have the Govt. Milk Tester visit the herd beginning the New Year and shall have to have conveniences for this and would suggest that the Horse Barn be utilised for this purpose. Very little expense would be entailed in taking out the present horse stalls and putting in pens.

This latter would of course call for a new horse barn, but if we are going to develop the farm on the whole, we must develop the dairy which is the greatest asset the school has, and which is now the only department that is giving us a cash dividend. Here we have something that not only gives an income of cash but also caters to the health of the children.

I trust you will give the above your immediate and sympathetic attention. Thanking you for considering as you have our needs in this matter,

Yours very sincerely

MR. SCOTT.

Reports have been submitted by the Dominion Water Power Branch on the proposed sewage disposal plant and water supply system for the Lytton Industrial School, Lytton, B.C., which will mainly consist of the following units.

SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM.

The sewage from the new school buildings will be treated through a concrete septic tank which will be located on the left bank of the Fraser River a distance of about 250 feet from the school, and will subsequently discharge into the Fraser River. The cost of the system will amount to $3,000.00.

WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM.

The source of water for the proposed water supply system will be derived from springs located on the reserve at an altitude of 250 feet above the main highway, where a concrete dam will be constructed. From this point it will be conveyed a distance of 600 feet to a concrete reservoir, having a capacity of 25,000 U.S. gallons. This reservoir will be located on the high ground in the vicinity of the new school. From the above mentioned reservoir the water will be carried a distance of 1700 feet through a 6" wood stave pipe to the school building to be used for both domestic supply and for fire protection.

In view of the height of 160 feet between the storage tank and the ground floor of the proposed building a static pressure of 70 pounds will be ensured at any of the hydrants which are to be installed near the building. The estimated cost of the above mentioned work will amount to about $6,000.00. After examining both reports I beg to recommend that the necessary funds be made available when the Department undertakes the construction of the new building.
and that separate prices be obtained in the tender form for these two systems.

To do this will eventually mean either the present horse stalls or the calf pens being turned in as stanchions for extra milk cows, and the present pens are not sufficient as it is.

At the present time there is no storeroom and feed is now stored in different parts, such as at the pig pen, which is badly needed now for the growing number of pigs. The temporary building which I proposed in my telegram, to cost about $1000.00, can be added to the present mixingroom, shown on the plan. These would have to be added eventually, if we are to go ahead, as we hope to, in the dairy business, and it is the only solution we can see, that would take care of the isolation that is badly needed at present. Dear Mr. Graham—

I must again approach you concerning more room in the barn. It is evident that the Dept. does not see our real need in regard to isolation and extension. While we shall in the new building have some relief in isolation it will not by any means take care of it all nor will it take care of development. The present barn room is all taken up and we do not now know what to do with the calves which are now arriving. The present stalls are all taken up with fresh cows and only this morning a cow freshened and should be for atime in isolation but she has to be kept in the stantions in the main barn.

To offset this condition I have already advocated the conversion of the horse-barn into pens to be used as freshening stalls and also to be used for milk testing purposes. If we are going to make anything of the dairy we must be in a position to properly test in order that our cows may go on record and also to be in a position to weed out individual boarders. We are just in the position now where a little additional expenditure will place us in a state of advance whereas if we are to be tied up for some time it will be a heart rending standstill. We have never used the horse-barn and it does seem as though it is still to remain so, when it could be utilized to such great advantage at the present time.

As you know I have spent no end of time and energy to place the dairy on the present footing and I do not want to see things go to the wall. The cost of these stalls and the conversion of the horse barn would entail an expenditure of four hundred dollars together with the present proposed building which I think can be erected for about eight hundred dollars instead of one thousand, as I intend doing a great deal of the work with our own help.

To say the least there is no encouragement in having a forced tie-up but if the above arrangement is not allowed I can only say that I shall be at a loss to know what to do.

There is also another item which would be well considered at this time. The present pipe line to the barn is in bad shape owing to the fact that the pipe put in was not of high enough pressure. This line should either be lifted and replaced with seventy pound pressure pipe at an approximate cost of $600.00 or a reservoir tank built to reduce the pressure to fifty pounds at a cost of about $75.00. This would still leave us ample pressure and while the concrete mixer is here it could be installed and with a few extra lengths of pipe the line could be made right.
This would also take care of the surplus water now running away and which could be utilised to great advantage during the summer months for irrigation purposes.

I am as you see out to save the unnecessary expense. I do not know who was at fault in the beginning nevertheless the line must now be repaired and could now be done at a very reduced cost.

Regarding the former let me ask that there be no tie up if at all possible. The extra room will mean so much and it undoubtedly will save the Dept. money in six months time. With cows freshening the dairy herd should be kept up to its greatest capacity. This can only be done by giving us the added room, which will allow scientific handling, and at no cost to the School or Dept.

Yours very sincerely

February 14, 1927.

Dear Sir:

You will doubtless hear of the following, but in case you do not, I think it is my duty in the interests of the Indian Residential School at Lytton, to report the following:

On Wednesday, the 9th inst., the boiler at the School burst, and the entire school was without any heat. This was a very bad state of affairs right in the middle of the cold weather and meant great discomfort to all. No school rooms could be opened and there was no water for the toilets, and the children were shivering around a few stoves, which said stoves, to my mind, are dangerous to use in such an awful, old building.

I sent down some fire clay from here for repairs, and temporary repairs have been made. Rev. Mr. Lett informs me he does not know how they will get the boiler repaired. It is out of date anyway, but something will have to be done to it if they have to stay in the old building for another winter.

I hope, therefore, that the Department will be able to get the money to start part of the new school anyway, as you know it is most urgently needed.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, February 24, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant and I regret to learn that a boiler burst at the Indian residential school at Lytton and that there was a consequent serious inconvenience. I have to inform you that Parliament at this session is being asked to provide funds for the new main building and I am hopeful that a start will be made in the spring.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Paget:

Trust Fund Cheque No. 958 of April 21, 1926 for $200 was issued to Rev. H. R. Lett as an advance to cover the cost of erecting a fence at the Lytton Industrial School. Up to the present this office has received no accounts to support this advance.

The School referred to above is supported by grants from the New England Co., and for that reason the impression seems to prevail in your department that the expenditures from the grants should not be subject to government audit.

It appears to me that as soon as this money is paid into the Trust Fund it becomes part of that Fund, bearing interest as such, and therefore payments made from this account must be treated the same as all expenditures made from the Indian Trust Fund.

Vouchers in connection with the Lytton Industrial School have been received in this office covering all payments with the exception of the advance to Mr. Lett. I can see no reason why the advance should not be accounted for, and I should like to have your opinion on this point.

"Plans are being prepared for a new building, I am
informed. I wish to say in the most emphatic way that school
building should be condemned. It is not a fit place to house
boys and girls.

"During a cold snap recently, the Principal says the
conditions were deplorable. The younger pupils were suffering
from cold. It was utterly impossible to keep them warm. A new
building should be erected at once or the pupils should be sent
home.

Water Supply:-

For some time the past Winter water had to be hauled.
However, at the time of my visit, there was enough water for
domestic purposes.

Heating:-

Hot water is used. One of the tubes burst while I
was there. The Engineer was able to fix it so that it worked.
The whole heating apparatus is liable to go to pieces at any
time.

General Remarks:-

There are twelve acres that divide the school lands.
This should be bought and added to the present school property.
I would respectfully recommend that the Department look into
this matter before the erection of the new building."

Memorandum:
Honourable Charles Stewart.

RE: PURCHASE OF PROPERTY
LYTTON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Relative to the proposal that the Department purchase the property at the Lytton Indian Residential School from the New England Company, for a consideration of $6,000, I wish to point out that the independent valuator you appointed made the following appraisal:

| Item               | Value   |
|--------------------|---------|
| Land               | $26,080 |
| Buildings          | $13,450 |
| Furnishings        | $2,380  |
| Stock              | $6,265  |
| Implements         | $2,785  |
| Other Equipment    | $3,540  |
| **Total**          | **$64,810** |

Not included in the appraiser's figures, are the barn and two cottages, which have been lately erected at a cost of $19,265, approximately $15,000 of which was from Parliamentary Appropriation.

I have reviewed the capital expenditure from 1920-21 to 1926-27, inclusive. And I find that from Parliamentary Appropriation the following improvements, other than the three outbuildings mentioned, have been made:

| Item                  | Value   |
|-----------------------|---------|
| Livestock             | $6,465  |
| Mechanical Plant      | $6,047  |
| Irrigation            | $5,782  |
| Farm Machinery        | $2,540  |
| Furnishings & other Equipment | $2,373 |
| **Total**             | **$25,175** |

In addition to the expenditure from Parliamentary Appropriation, there has been approximately $7,000 worth of improvements paid for by the New England Company grant.

I believe that the appraiser's valuation was conservative. If 20% of the cost of recent improvements is
deducted for depreciation and the balance subtracted from
the valuator's figures, it would appear that the New
England Company equity is approximately $46,000. The
Company, in a recent letter, indicates that the property
stands on their books as an asset of $12,475, or approx-
imately $60,000. To this figure might be added $7,000 -
the value of the improvements paid for from the New England
Company grant in recent years. Allowing for depreciation
and for the increase in land values during the years I
am satisfied that the proposed purchase price, £8,000, or
$30,848 at current rates of exchange, is quite fair and
reasonable. When the new main building is erected, the
property with its fine outbuildings and splendid irrigation
system will be a very valuable adjunct to our educational
equipment. The site is very attractive and the land, when
irrigated, quite fertile.

The New England Company have written in
part as follows: "That, if your Department would agree to
purchase the property immediately for the sum named (£8,000)
the Court would agree that the payment of the purchase money
could be spread over a period of years to be arranged,
by instalments, and they suggest that the most convenient form
of such an arrangement would be for the payments to be made
in equal sums paid yearly as principal and interest to cover
outstanding amounts at 5%... The maintenance
grants would be continued by agreement for a period of years
on the present basis." Another letter, referring to the
arrangement in the event of purchase, states that the Company
might be willing to continue the grants which they now give
and to add thereto the bulk of the interest derived from the
purchase money.

There is an item of $10,000 in the Main
Estimates as the first payment on the purchase price of this
property. I wish to recommend that the New England Company
be informed of our intention to purchase immediately, that
they be offered $10,000 in cash, $10,000 in one year,
$10,000 in two years, and the balance plus interest due in
three years' time. The last three payments would, of course,
have to be included in our Estimates. I do not recommend
that the New England Company grants for maintenance be set
off against the Department's payments of principal and
interest, as it would be a source of much satisfaction to me
if the Company indefinitely continues its grants and its
association with the Department in the conduct of the
Institution.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

June 16th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I was allowed yesterday, for the first time since his operation, to see Mr. Lett in the hospital. He is most anxious that I should put up to you a few matters in connection with the construction of the new school at Lytton. His requests, apparently, are not anything out of the way, nor do I think they will cost very much as extras. I will enumerate them as follows:

1. In the girls' wash rooms, in the basement plan, he would prefer that the girls have exactly the same bath accommodation as in the boys' wing; in other words, three shower baths and three bath tubs instead of one shower bath and four bath tubs, his idea being that they are much more quickly handled in shower baths than in bath tubs.

2. On the same basement floor, he would like cupboard accommodation built both in the girls' recreation room and in the boys' recreation room, to hold the children's clothes, his idea being that they could come downstairs in the morning in their slippers and dressing gowns and change whilst having their ablutions.

3. In the class rooms on the ground floor plans, he states that the blackboard accommodation is apparently not sufficient. He states that, nowadays, a tremendous lot of teaching is done through blackboard work, and it is necessary to have as much as possible.

4. On the First Floor Plan, he would like to have one more bath tub for staff use. He suggests that it be placed in the accommodation marked off as "stores" on the right hand of the boys' infirmary. This would not add very much extra cost as it could be connected up with the plumbing in the bath room of the boys' infirmary.

5. On the Second Floor Plan, he points out that there is no toilet accommodation for either of the two staff bedrooms. It would mean going through the dormitories to get to the said accommodation. He suggests that in this case, toilets be placed in the two receptacles marked off as "stores" opposite the staff bedrooms, one on the girls' side and one on the boys' side. This would not cost much extra as they could be connected with the plumbing of the dormitory toilets.

I promised Mr. Lett that I would write you for him, and I hope you will give this matter your consideration,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Geo. S. Pragnell
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Kamloops, B.C., June 18th, 1927.

I hereby beg to submit a report on my latest inspection trip to the Lytton Agency.

In company with Mr. Graham I visited and inspected St. George's school and found everything in as satisfactory a condition as can be expected under the difficulties encountered in the old building. Much happiness and relief was expressed by both Mr. Graham and Rev. Mr. Lett, Principal, at the news that the construction of the new building is to take place shortly. I wish to point out, however, that every effort should be made to get the children housed in the new building anyhow as regards sleeping before the winter, otherwise considerable expense will be necessary to recondition the heating plant in the old building. In fact, to my mind, I doubt whether this is possible without largely replacing same, and unless they are housed, the possibility of having to close the school temporarily may crop up.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Matheson:

I am very pleased to inform you that my plans for the Lytton Indian Residential School have rapidly materialized. Not only has Parliament provided sufficient funds for a new main building, but we have received a reasonable offer from a responsible contractor. Complete plans and specifications were prepared some time ago and I called for tenders, which were opened recently. The Department is quite satisfied with the figure £130,000, which was entered by Addison and Hill, of Vancouver, who have been found quite capable of handling the work. I am directing to you, under separate cover, a set of the plans and specifications, so you will know exactly what type of building is being erected. The dormitories and classrooms will be made ready for an initial enrolment of 150. However, if all available space is used, the building will accommodate 180 children besides the staff.

In addition to funds for the main building, Parliament has provided £27,000 for water supply, sewage disposal, shelving, cupboards, furnishings, salary of the Inspector of Construction and a horse barn. There was also a vote of £10,000 for a first payment towards the purchase of the property.

I have arranged application to His Excellency in Council for authority to award the contract and I wish to take advantage of the New England Company's offer to sell their equity in the property attached to the school for a consideration of £8,000. The Superintendent General has approved of this scheme and the Department will be glad to accept the proposal of your letter of June 22nd, last, i.e., spread the payment of the purchase money over a term of years.

I am making arrangements with the Department of Justice for the appointment of a lawyer in British Columbia, who will search title and prepare the necessary legal instruments. I am suggesting an Agreement of Sale with a consideration of £6,400, indicating a payment this year of £6,000, £6,000 in one year, £6,000 in two years and the balance of the consideration plus interest due at 5% in three years' time. In addition, there will be a bill of £6,000 for all chattels with a consideration of £1,000, indicating a payment this year of £2,000, £2,000 in one year, £2,000 in two years and the balance of the consideration plus interest due at 5% in three years' time.

Ernest Matheson, Esq.,
Governor, New England Company,
26 Bloomsbury Sq.,
London, W. C. 1., England.

Sir:

I have the honour to inform you
that, in accordance with instructions con-
tained in your letter of April 6th., 1926,
an investigation having reference to a pro-
posed sewage disposal plant for the new
Lytton Industrial School has been completed,
the following being my report thereon:

INTRODUCTION-

The new buildings for the Lytton
Industrial School will be situated on the
south bank of the Fraser River, approxim-
ately 1,600 feet from the old school build-
ing (see accompanying plan) and when com-
pleted will be capable of housing 175 persons.

The proposed sewage system has therefore been
therefore been designed to take care of a flow of sewage amounting to 6,000 U.S. gallons per day, or 40 U.S. gallons per capita per diem, this amount being equal to the average daily consumption of water per head in institutions of this kind.

DESCRIPTION:

The sewage from the new school buildings will be carried by means of a 6" diameter vitrified sewer pipe from the school to a septic tank which will be situated on the left bank of the Fraser River, a distance of 250 feet from and immediately behind the new school buildings. (See accompanying plan)

After having been passed through this tank, the effluent will be discharged by means of an automatic siphon directly into the Fraser River.

SEPTIC TANK:

The septic tank will be constructed of reinforced concrete and situated at a depth of 2 feet below the surface of the ground to avoid danger of freezing. (See accompanying plan)

It will be divided by a wall into two compartments, one called a settling chamber, which will be the septic part of the tank, and the other called a siphon chamber, where the effluent will be collected ready for intermittent discharge into the Fraser River.

The settling chamber will be of the following
the following dimensions: 16' x 7' x 9'9" deep, and will be connected by means of a 3 foot overflow weir with a siphon chamber having dimensions as follows: 10' x 6' x 9'9" deep.

This siphon chamber will be equipped with an automatic siphon which will discharge when the effluent in the chamber reaches a total depth of 5 feet, and will discharge four times a day.

The settling chamber will have a capacity of 5,250 U.S. gallons, equal to 21 hours flow, and the detention period will therefore be 21 hours, with a rate of flow through the chamber of 7 inches per hour.

Drains have been provided in each chamber to permit of the tank being emptied and cleaned when required.

Vent pipes, manholes, ladders, overflow pipes, etc., have been provided for in the design and arranged as shown on the accompanying plan.

SEWER PIPES—

The sewage will be carried from the school by means of one 6" diameter vitrified sewer pipe (grade .01) to the inspection chamber, which will be situated 45 feet from the school.

From this point it will be transferred by means of one 6" diameter sewer pipe (grade .01)
pipe (grade .01) a distance of 200 feet to the septic tank.

INSPECTION CHAMBER:

The inspection chamber will be of reinforced concrete and so placed that all pipes entering this chamber will be laid on straight lines and even grades to allow of easy cleaning should they at any time become clogged.

DISCHARGE PIPE:

The discharge pipe from the septic tank to the Fraser River will be 4" diameter vitrified sewer pipe, 100 feet in length, laid to a grade of .01 and will be straight and free from bends.

It will be called upon to discharge approximately 1,500 U.S. gallons every four hours.

SLUDGE REMOVAL:

The septic tank should be cleaned approximately once every twelve months and this operation can easily be performed by means of the removable wooden covering provided for in the design and which runs the full length of the settling chamber. (See accompanying plan)

COST:

The total cost of constructing the above sewage disposal plant will amount to $3,610.00, and no further expenditure for either operation or maintenance should be required other than a charge of approx-

INTRODUCTION-

The new Lytton Industrial School will be situated on the south bank of the Fraser River, a distance of 4 miles above the Town of Lytton and approximately 1,600 feet from the present old school buildings. (See accompanying plan)

It will be a semi-fireproof brick building and when completed will be capable of housing 175 persons.

WATER REQUIREMENTS FOR DOMESTIC PURPOSES-

The maximum daily water requirements for domestic
ments for domestic purposes in this institution, assuming 175 persons resident in the building, will amount to 40 U.S. gallons per capita, or a total of 6,000 U.S. gallons per day.

WATER REQUIREMENTS FOR FIRE PROTECTION PURPOSES-

The new building will have a value when finished of more than $100,000.00, and should therefore be supplied with sufficient water to afford protection in the event of fire.

The minimum amount of water necessary to afford proper protection to a building of this kind is 500 U.S. g.p.m. (i.e., 2 standard fire streams of 240 U.S. g.p.m. each, playing simultaneously). This amount should be available for a considerable period in order that a possible outbreak of fire, no matter how severe, may be subdued.

POSSIBLE SOURCES OF WATER SUPPLY-

The only possible sources of water supply available for the new school building which can be obtained, other than by pumping from the Fraser River, which, owing to the great height of the school above the river (400 feet) and the lack of electric power available in this vicinity, would be too expensive, is from two springs, one situated on the Lytton Indian Reserve No. 21 and the other on Lot II, as shown on the accompanying plan.

DESCRIPTION OF SPRINGS-

Spring on Lot II.

The spring situated on Lot II, while it supplies
while it supplies water at the present time to the school barn, does not have sufficient flow during certain seasons of the year to warrant the installation of any expensive reservoir or other collecting works, in order to provide water for fire and domestic purposes in the new school building; and in addition the 4" diameter wood-stave pipe which at the present time conveys this water from the spring to the barn is not of a sufficiently large diameter to provide water at a high enough rate should same be required for fire protection purposes at any time in the future.

This 4" diameter pipe, which has now been in use for several years, is in bad condition and considerable trouble from leakage has been experienced during the past season.

It is, therefore, considered advisable to abandon this spring on Lot 11 for any except farm purposes and to install a concrete reservoir to be used for fire protection and domestic purposes near the spring situated on the Lytton Indian Reserve No. 21 (see accompanying plan) rather than to attempt to replace the existing 4" diameter pipe and make use of the spring on Lot 11.

Spring on Lytton Indian Reserve No. 21.

The spring situated on Lytton Indian Reserve No. 21 is located approximately 250 feet above the main Lytton to Lillooet highway (see accompanying plan) and has, from information obtained
information obtained from reliable persons familiar with this district, a sufficient flow during all seasons of the year to provide water for school purposes.

It is therefore proposed to utilize this spring in order to supply water for the new school building.

PROPOSED WORKS-

The proposed works will be as follows:

A small concrete dam will be constructed and water will be diverted from the above spring at a point 250 feet above the main highway (see accompanying plan). From this point it will be carried by means of a 6" diameter wood-stave pipe a distance of 600 feet to a reinforced concrete reservoir situated on the high ground north-east of the new school.

The proposed reservoir, which will be of reinforced concrete construction, will be 25' x 12' x 12', inside dimensions, and will have a capacity when full of 25,000 U.S. gallons.

From this reservoir the water will be conveyed through 1,700 lineal feet of 6" diameter wood-stave pipe to the school building, where it will be used for both domestic and fire protection purposes.

FIRE PROTECTION-

The elevation of the surface of the water in the proposed reservoir will be 160.00 and the elevation of the ground floor of the proposed school
proposed school will be 0.00, which will give a static pressure at any one of the proposed four hydrants situated in the vicinity of the school of 69 pounds per square inch.

From the above it will be seen that should an outbreak of fire occur a total of 25,000 U.S. gallons of water will be instantly available at a pressure of approximately 52 pounds per square inch at the hydrants, which amount at this pressure will be sufficient to supply two standard fire streams at 240 U.S. g.p.m. for a period of one hour.

COST-

The cost of installation of the above water supply system, including the construction of the concrete reservoir, intake dam and the installation of all supply pipes, overflow pipes, hydrants, fittings, etc., will amount to $5,825.00.

REMARKS-

After having made a thorough study of existing conditions at the above institution, I would respectfully suggest that a water supply system as outlined in this report be installed at the Lytton Industrial School.

Plans, specifications and estimates have been prepared by the Dominion Water Power Branch for the installation of a water supply and sewage disposal system for the new Lytton Residential School.

The water supply system will consist in the construction of a concrete dam in order to form a water reservoir supplied by a number of springs from which a wood stave pipe line will convey the water by gravity a distance of 1700 feet to the school building, where it will be used for both domestic and fire protection.

Owing to the difference in elevation between the school and the above mentioned reservoir it is expected that a static pressure of 69 pounds per square inch will be put on the outlets at the school building. The cost including the installation of fire fighting apparatus will amount to $5,825.00.

The sewerage system will consist in the construction of a concrete septic tank, located at a distance of 230 feet from the school. It is intended that the effluent from this tank will be discharged directly into the Fraser River, a distance of 100 feet. The installation as planned by the report is that usually installed in connection with similar Institutions, and will cost in the neighborhood of $3,000.00. Should funds be available for this expenditure I beg to recommend that it be done by day labour, under the supervision of the District Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch. On visiting the site of the new St. George's School to inspect the progress of the building, Mr. Dill, one of the contractors, drew my attention to the fact that a lot of accessories had been omitted from the plans, such as cupboards in the sewingroom, dormitories, and classrooms, as well as individual lockers in the basement playrooms, which are absolutely necessary as the children attending can personal belongings with them, so which they require access at certain times.

There is also no refrigerator, which is a most important factor in a school like this. This should be put in in the storeroom.

Then there is no provision made for the manual training. A room for this could be placed over the coalbin at a very small cost, as it would only require the extra walls. It would not interfere in any shape or form with the class, and besides, it is of value as a manual training room; it could be used for a dressing-room when entertainments were being given by putting in a door opening into the recreation hall.

I think all these things that I have mentioned will have to be put in sooner or later, and now is certainly the time to do it for they can be placed in the building for half the cost it would take if they have to be put in after the building is completed. I would therefore strongly recommend that the contractors be instructed to do this work as they go along.

I am glad to report that the foundations for the building are just about completed, and they expect to start on the concrete floors in the basement this coming week.

I understand that the Water Rights Branch has been instructed to attend to the water and sewer for the school, and would like to suggest that instructions be given that this work be proceeded with, with as little delay as possible.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Ditchburn,

I trust you will pardon me for becoming uneasy re situation here concerning progress of new school.

The contractors are well ahead and in the first week of September, brick work should be well on its way.

While this is so, the Department have not yet taken steps to install water system. This is a big job, and the autumn is coming. Is there anyway in which they might be hurried? By renting the present concrete mixer to put in tanks would save considerable and hauling of gravel and sand with present equipment would also help out.

Up to the present I have had no message re cupboards and manual training room. It will be necessary for this work to be allotted, as the runners to which the cupboards should be attached should be put in the brick wall.

If it is at all possible for you to do anything in the way of arranging a quick response concerning the above, it would be to the interest of the Department as well as to ourselves.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 15th instant in reply to mine of the 14th regarding connections with the main drain at the Lytton School. Your telegram read as hereunder:

Ottawa, Ont. Sept. 14.
Via Victoria, B.C.

Indian Commissioner,
Care Indian Office, Kamloops, B.C.

"Separate drain pipe to be installed for sewage from laundry and kitchen of Lytton School connected to inspection chamber on outlet pipe from septic tank. Additional pipe and manhole to be included in work under direction of Dominion Water Power Branch."

J.D. McLean.

In connection with this matter, I beg to say that while at Kamloops last week, Engineer Tredcroft, of the Dominion Water Power Branch, informed me as to the instructions set forth in the specifications which were not in accord with his original plan of drainage for the School. Engineer Tredcroft could understand why you did not want the water from the laundry and kitchens to pass through the main drain in the School building underneath the cement flooring, but considered that it could be carried to the outside of the building and attached to the sewer to be passed through the septic tank with the sewage from the toilets, etc. To have a separate sewer from the laundry and kitchen to be carried down a distance of about six hundred feet and connected with inspection chamber on the outlet pipe from the septic tank would entail a further expenditure of approximately $500.00 for which authority for this further expenditure must be given, if it is to be carried out as per your telegram. I am attaching hereto a pencil sketch made by Engineer Tredcroft showing where it is proposed to put in the separate drain from the kitchen and laundry and conduct the same to the outlet chamber from the septic tank. It also shows where the Engineer had proposed for this drainage to enter the main sewer outside the building above the septic tank. Mr. Tredcroft is of the opinion that the passage of the drainage from the kitchen and laundry through the sewer and out through the septic tank would not in any way affect the septic action; in fact...
fact he considered it would be beneficial as it was most desirable to have some other drainage go through this system other than that from the toilets.

I would strongly recommend that you should wire to Engineer Trederoft, who is now at Lytton, authority for this additional expenditure, which must necessarily be contracted.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn

Sir,

I am enclosing herewith estimate of cost and plan showing alterations necessary to the sewage disposal system for the new Lytton Industrial School owing to the decision of the department of Indian Affairs to provide separate drainage for the laundry and kitchen water and to the method adopted by the contractor in bringing out the sewer pipes. Before these sewer pipes were installed I personally visited the new building and during an examination of the site with the contractors representative in charge of the plumbing, pointed out that outlet E shown on the accompanying plan was the proper point for the main sewer to leave the building. With this suggestion the contractor's representative at the time agreed. He did not, however, follow out this suggestion and presumably to save cost, carried the sewer pipes in 3 separate outlets A, B, and C via the shortest route, see plan.

This method as you will see from the plan will make it necessary to install manholes at each bend, as when the grading is completed, these pipes will be buried to a depth of from 8 to 10 feet in loose unstable soil and should any stoppage occur as is very probable where right angle bends have to be used it would be impossible to remove same without great expense.

The specifications did not state at what point the sewer should leave the building neither did they state whether the sewage should be brought out in 1, 2 or 3 outlets and the contractor is therefore technically speaking, working within his rights.

The sewer pipes inside the building have all been installed and most of the concrete floors laid. For this reason nothing would be gained by trying to alter the interior piping now and the only thing that can be done is to alter the proposed disposal system in the manner shown on the accompanying plan and as outlined by me during my recent conversation with you.

In view of the fact that the major portions of these alterations, i.e., those referring to the laundry and kitchen water, have already been authorized by wire from Ottawa, I presume I may carry on the whole project simultaneously and make arrangement to install the extra manholes and sewer connections immediately as there is no alternative but to put them in and any delay at this time is very inconvenient.

You will also probably remember that the specifications call for a concrete tank for rainwater to be provided by the department but up to date we have received no instructions to install same. Is it the intention of the department that we shall install this tank or will they construct it separately. It would seem to me that we are the logical people to undertake this work.

The accompanying list is an exact statement of the extra material and fittings required and I shall be obliged if

Sir:

I hereby acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 1 enclosing copy of letter from the Director of Water Power and having reference to the proposed installation of a concrete rainwater tank at the Lytton Industrial School. In this connection I would state that the installation of this tank is in my opinion advisable in view of the fact that the water which will be used in the new water supply system was analysed by the Department of Health and found to be comparatively hard (see report by Dept. of Health, your file 24705-22B).

The operation of the Lytton Indian school, which is a large institution, will necessitate a considerable amount of laundry work being undertaken each week and if a supply of soft water can be provided at what the Department would consider to be a reasonable cost there is no doubt that it would be of considerable advantage to them in their operations.

The Rev. A.R.Lett, principal of the Lytton Industrial school, when I interviewed him regarding this matter suggested that a tank having a capacity of 8000 U.S.gals be installed so that it would be possible to store water during a wet season for use during dry period, but to this suggestion I took exception on the grounds that the capacity was far too large and that in view of the fact that the laundry would undoubtedly have to be operated at least once a week and taking into consideration the average rainfall at Lytton there would be practically no chance of our ever being able to supply such a large capacity. I further stated that I do not consider that the Department would look with favour upon any very large expenditure for this purpose.

I then suggested that tank having a capacity of 4000 U.S.gals.would in my opinion, be more than sufficient to supply all ordinary requirements. The Rev.Lett then stated that while he did not consider 8000 gals. to be excessive yet he realized the necessity for economy and finally agreed that a 4000 U.S.gal. tank should be requisitioned.

As stated above I consider 4000 U.S.gals. to be more than sufficient to supply their requirements but as a large part of the expenditure will be for fittings, excavation etc. which will remain the same no matter what sized tank is installed there is very little to be gained by reducing the size of this tank below 4000 U.S.gals.

C.E.Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom.Water Power & Reclamation Service,
739 Hastings Street, West,
Vancouver, B.C.
The proposed tank will require to be located outside the school buildings and buried below the surface of the ground to protect it from frost which means that it will be below the level of the laundry floor, the water from this tank will, therefore have to be pumped to another small iron tank (capacity approximately 200 U.S.gals.) situated inside the laundry so that it may flow by gravity to the water heater and thence to the laundry machines.

The Rev.Lett suggested that this pumping could be carried out by a small electrically operated sump pump which could be run off the generator which supplies the school with light and power. It could also be carried out by means of a hand operated pump which could be operated by one or more of the pupils whenever necessary and which would reduce the cost of the installation. I have therefore prepared two estimates of cost, one dealing with a tank and pump operated by electricity and one with a tank and pump operated by hand.

With reference to the above I would respectfully point out that if this installation is to be carried out this year immediate action would be advisable in view of the fact that good weather cannot last very much longer and if the work must be undertaken when the temperature is much below freezing the cost will undoubtedly be increased.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) E.H.Tredcroft
Senior Asst. Engineer
Department of Health
Canada

Sir:

In further reference to your letter of October 21st regarding the proposed rain water tank for the St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, B.C., I enclose herewith a report from Mr. Tredcroft the Resident Engineer together with a letter from Mr. Davidson, Analyst in charge of the Food and Drug Laboratory of the Department of Health, dated September 21st.

You will note that the analysis of the spring water shows that the water is comparatively hard, in fact under some names calcium carbonate content of over 300 parts per million is called very hard. Fortunately boiling removes much of the hardness, but the water even after that process can still be termed a hard water, and therefore the use of rain water for washing would be a decided advantage, and is recommended by our District Chief Engineer.

In connection with the two methods of supply submitted by Mr. Tredcroft, Mr. Webb considers that the use of a hand operated pump would be satisfactory. You will note that the tank with hand operated pump can be installed for an estimated cost of $954.00 whereas the electrically operated equipment is estimated to cost $1272.00.

The last paragraph of Mr. Tredcroft's report refers to the desirability of immediate action if this work is to be carried out this year, and I shall be glad to have your further instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Dear Sir:

Further to correspondence that passed between us a few weeks ago regarding "Asbestoslate" Blackboards for Indian Schools, we have just been informed by one of our agents in Vancouver that the contract for the new building to be known as the St. George's Residential School, Lytton, B.C., has been awarded to Messrs. Adkison and Dill. We understand that natural slate is specified for the blackboards, and when the Contractors were approached they could not consider changing to "Asbestoslate" without the approval of the Department.

This attitude is, of course, quite right, but we would like to have your approval of allowing our Canadian-made material to be installed. There will be a considerable saving in the final cost, and we are confident the boards will give many years of perfectly satisfactory service.

Another point that we think worth mentioning is the time available in which to make delivery. We believe the work has to be finished within a few weeks, and it is doubtful if natural slate could be obtained in time, whereas large stocks of "Asbestoslate" are available at Vancouver and can therefore be in the Contractors' possession within a matter of hours.

We would therefore greatly appreciate your co-operation in instructing Messrs. Adkison and Dill that the contract will be amended to permit the change in question.
Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours very truly

THE GEO. M. HENDRY CO., Limited

Sir,

Yours of the 8th inst to hand re the proposed horse barn for St George's Residential School.

I beg to state that I have consulted the Rev. Principal, and am now enclosing as per your request, a sketch showing exactly what we want.

The new barn is to be a continuation of the present barn with a 20 ft run way between, so that the hay can be carried both ways into the lofts from this run way.

The estimated cost will be about $4700.00.

Mr Lett says that he would be prepared to build this by day labor if the Departments wishes, but would much prefer to let it by contract, and supervise it himself, he says that he thinks he could build it cheaper by contract, especially as he has so much to look after with the building of the new school going on at the same time.

I have the honor to be Your obedient servant.

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Ont.
Indian Agent Graham and the Reverend Mr. Lett have brought to the attention of the Department the need of a new horse barn in connection with the new St. George's Indian Residential School. The most economical and satisfactory way to have this building erected would be by day labour, under the supervision of the Reverend Principal. The cost of a suitable horse barn would be $4,700 and I would recommend that the building be erected by day labour. The Soboba Branch state that funds are available.

Architect.
Ottawa, Oct. 28, 1927.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the building of a suitable horse barn for the Lytton School, I beg to advise you that you may instruct the Principal to proceed by day labour with the erection of the horse barn on the lines shown on the sketch prepared by you. It is noted in your letter that the cost of the barn is estimated at £4,700.00, but I think that this building should be erected under this amount, and I would, therefore, ask you to keep the expenditure as low as possible. All materials should be purchased to the best advantage, after obtaining competitive prices.

I am sending you, under separate cover, time sheets, which should be kept for all labour employed on the work. Mr. Batter, who is acting as inspector of Construction, on the new school, can probably give Mr. Lett some assistance in the construction of this building, and I am today writing him asking him to do so.

An accountable cheque for the payment of labour will be sent you on application.

Your obedient servant,

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir,

A period of wintry weather checked the progress of the contractor of the new school from the 14th to 22nd of October. With the advent of mild weather and an increased staff of workmen excellent progress is now being made.

In about 3 more days the whole of the brickwork will be completed.

The roofs of the Assembly Room, Boiler Room, Laundry, Engine Room, Manual Training Room, Kitchen (and corridor over) and the Residence roof are all ready for the felt or gravel roofing. A crew of roofing men are now at work on these roofs.

Of the sheet metal work, materials and men are on the job and are putting on the galvanized iron work.
suit as roofs, ventilation system, rain water hoppers, flanking etc., etc., the electrical work, steam fitting & plumbing have been brought forward uniformly with rest of work.

The Electrical machinery, Engines, Dynamos have been delivered here or in dry storage until room is ready to set them up.

A crew of men are working on the concrete floor work in Basement, the greater part of which has yet to be done. The floor of Boiler-room has been done so that the Boilers etc. (which are on the ground) can be installed at an early date.

The local work of the steel staircase and the fire escapes I understand is being fabricated in Vancouver but has not yet been delivered.

With a continuance of mild weather for a week or so (which is probable here) all exterior work will be finished with a greater assurance of good work being done.

I remain,

Obediently,

Frank W. Baker

Dear Sir,

Very fair progress has been made on construction of new school during the past two weeks.

The brickwork has been all completed and there only remain a portion of the coping to be done which is of basalt stone or the weather got too frosty to permit of any further work on this.

The roofing has been completed in every part and all glazed window sash has been fitted & installed.

The plumbing and electric wiring has also been completed in the building.

The electric plant has also been installed complete with engines, dynamos, batteries & switch boards. (Manufactured by
the Lister - Brunton to England.

The roughing in of all steam piping has been completed. The steam boilers are in place, but the smoke breechings and the steam mains are not yet connected up.

The heating radiators are all in the building, but no connecting up has yet been done (for temporary heat). It is expected that this will be done in the near future. I might say here that I have forbidden any more plastering work until this has been effected.

The metal lathing have been completed and the plastering commenced with the aid of temporary heat in the shape of some salamanders. This was tried for two days but could not be continued owing to the severity of the weather. During this period I directed that a night-watchman be put on duty as a safeguard against fire.

The steel fire escapes have been installed and the steel stairways...
completed, but the concrete landings have yet to be done. About 80 per cent of the concrete floors of the basement has been finished. The remainder will be left until the building can be steam heated. A large amount of shiplap ceiling has been put up ready for receiving the metal ceiling and all the grounds for receiving interior finish woodwork are ready, for the plastering which will follow.

The work as a whole is being carried out in a satisfactory manner. I might add here that the steam heating men will work through the holiday season in order to get steam heat on at an early date next year. The remainder of the work may shut down for short period, maybe 2 weeks.

Finishing that this will be satisfactory.

I remain Obediently Yours,

Frank W. Baker
Inspector

The new building, which he has set his heart on, is giving him a great deal of worry at the present time, owing to the fact that there are a great number of small things which are being left out, and which will throw a great responsibility upon him, after it is occupied, such as the lack of refrigeration. In a hot climate like we have here in summertime, there is no provision made for keeping food, making it very bad. Throughout the school there is practically no provision made for any storeroom. Storm windows will have to be taken off, and there is not a single place to put them. No provision is made for clothes, in the line of closets or storerooms. No provision is made for the children's grips which will have to be put under the beds. None of these things tend to help him, and with the finances as they are today, it all tends to get on his nerves.

Dear Sir:

On the 3rd inst., it became necessary for us to close down the work on the St. George's Indian School at Lytton, B.C., on account of the men all leaving for the holidays with no intention of being back before the first of the year.

We regret to state, however, that the weather has been so cold up there and apparently is continuing so, that it may be necessary for us to remain closed down until conditions materially moderate. The men working on the heating plant, however, will continue and expect to have same in working condition the second week in January or so. If, however, the temperature at that time is considerably below zero as it has been, we think it will hardly be safe to put water into the system in the building. If such is the case it will be impossible for us to start until the temperature rises, and we have a reasonable assurance that we will not be caught again with frigid weather.

We have carried through up to the present point at great expense to ourselves, the last six weeks of building and have the building entirely closed in, roof on, windows all in and hung and doors boarded up. All partitions are in and all metal lath on. Part of the plastering is done but we found it necessary to stop this work as the frost was too hard.

We regret very much that it seems impossible now to finish the building within the specified time in February, but, trust on account of conditions you will be willing to allow us the additional time necessary.

Gentlemen,

Re: Erection of Indian Residential School - Lytton, B.C.

My attention has been drawn to correspondence with reference to the rate of wages payable to carpenters employed by your firm under a contract with the Department of Indian Affairs for the erection of the above-mentioned Indian residential school. The contract in question calls for the payment to mechanics, labourers, etc., of such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed. It is further declared that the Minister of Labour may at any time and from time to time determine for the purpose of the contract what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages. In the present case enquiry has been made by the Fair Wages Officer of the Department of Labour which shows that the current rate of wages for carpenters is the same as that in Vancouver, namely, $7.50 per day, whereas it is represented to us that your firm is paying a rate of wages of $7.00 per day for this class of service.

Under the authority of the labour conditions of the contract, I am writing you to say that a rate of wages of $7.50 per day must be observed for carpenters on this building and that settlement must be made to individual carpenters who have received less than this rate for the amounts which may be severally due them, covering the full period of their employment.
