Re: Erection of Indian Residential School - Lytton, B.C.

My attention has been drawn to correspondence with reference to the rate of wages payable to carpenters employed by your firm under a contract with the Department of Indian Affairs for the erection of the above mentioned Indian residential school. The contract in question calls for the payment to mechanics, labourers, etc., of such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed. It is further declared that the Minister of Labour may at any time and from time to time determine for the purpose of the contract what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages. In the present case enquiry has been made by the Pay Wages Officer of the Department of Labour which shows that the current rate of wages for carpenters is the same as that in Vancouver, namely, $7.50 per day, whereas it is represented to us that your firm is paying a rate of wages of $7.00 per day for this class of service.

Under the authority of the labour conditions of the contract, I am writing you to say that a rate of wages of $7.50 per day must be observed for carpenters on this building and that settlement must be made to individual carpenters who have received less than this rate for the amounts which may be severally due them, covering the full period of their employment.

I should be glad to have word that this ruling is being put into effect.

Yours very truly,

Gentlemen:

We enclose herewith copy or letter from the Minister of Labour to us in connection with the rate paid to carpenters on the above school and also copy of our letter in answer to this.

We wish here to advise that when figuring this building we enquired of the rates being paid to carpenters and other mechanics in that district and all up the line. We found that in Chilliwack they were paying from $5.50 to $6.50 per day. Kamloops being the largest centre actually in the Lytton district, we found that the wages paid carpenters were from $6.00 to $6.50 per day. We, therefore, figured our job at $6.50 for carpenters, believing that to be the proper rate to be paid. We found, however, about the time of starting this work that the men in Kamloops would soon be asking for a raise in wages to $7.00. We, therefore, started our work off at that price wishing to have no controversy in the matter. We are, therefore, as you will see, out fifty cents 50¢ per day on every carpenter we have employed on the job.

If the letter from the Department of Labour is to be followed and the men paid $7.50 per day, we think it will be only right that the department should pay this difference and not ourselves as we have already gone half way at a loss to ourselves.

We do not see, however, that the department can possibly be correct in their assumption that $7.50 should be paid in this district. It is true we found out only a few weeks ago that Mr. Harrison, the fair wage officer of Vancouver had struck a rate of wages for this work being practically that which is paid in Vancouver. We, however, at the time of figuring and not until a few weeks ago were not cognizant of that fact.
and there is no rate of wages stated in the specifications or any of the papers coming from your department at the time of figuring this work, merely a reference to wages usually accepted in the district which we have followed and done one better by paying the men 50¢ per day more than seemed right at that time and fully the amount which actually exists today in that district.

We ask that you will take this matter up with the Minister of Labour and if found necessary to pay the other 50¢ per day, we trust that you will make it up to us.

We assure you, however, this objection has not come from any of our men but is merely the work of an agitator in the City of Vancouver.

Trusting you will give this matter your immediate attention and greatly oblige

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Construction work on new school during last 2 weeks of Dec was considerably slowed down on account of extremely cold weather. A considerable amount of the stone coping, stone roof had to be left unfinished.

The tar & gravel has been completed also all the galvanized iron flashings or all other gal iron work. The plastering work could not go on owing to lack of proper heat but the second floor was partly plastered (first coat).

The Steel Stairs or fire escape has been completed and is a most substantial or satisfactory job.

As regard the carpentry work all glazed window sash have
been fitted or installed in place. The greater part of the simple ceilings have been put up ready to receive metal ceiling and all grounds for receiving finishing wood work are all done. No further progress can be made now without steam heat being put into use. Regret to report that the contractors have not to date made any attempt to heat the building in any way, declining to go to such expense. They are waiting until the severe cold of the present time is past. I have forbidden any further plastering or cement work until steam heat makes use of (Dec 13). Men from the steam heat contractor are here working on boilers and radiators getting them ready for use within a few days about Jan 8 or 9th. There will be no reason then for any further delay. I shall report to you again around that date as to whether they comply with these requirements. Obediently Yours,

Frank W. Butler

I have looked forward with enthusiasm to the new school and as it is now nearing completion, I am hoping for a new lease of life. While this is so, yet there are coming difficulties, and if these are not given immediate attention there will be unavoidable leakages which I do not want nor can I afford same. There has no provision been made for refrigeration, which, as you know, we cannot do without. We have an ample supply of meat on the farm and also milk and eggs which are perishable. If it is at all possible provision should be made for this before the warm weather sets in which in this part comes about the middle of April.

The new school is provided with storm sash, and where these are to be stored for the summer months I do not know. Storage room for these should be provided with as little delay as possible as to house them without lock and key would mean destruction to the glass and necessitate a probable heavy expenditure before again replacing them for the winter.

There is also the storage of overplus, such as children's private clothing, extra school clothing, bedding and equipment. These are articles which cannot be allowed to toss about in any old fashion and must be looked after in order to avoid unnecessary leakages.

STORAGE ROOMS: In the Secretary's correspondence to you concerning additional storage room at the new school, also refrigerator, I might point out that I have always criticised the new building for lack of storage room, and cannot now see where the storage room for children's private property is to be found, or for the surplus school clothing. Our ice for the year has run us into the enormous sum of from six to eight hundred dollars, so that the expenditure in three years would put up an ammonia plant, which would relieve all future difficulties in this way. Gentlemen:

Re Carpenters' Wage Rate
Indian School, Lytton, B.C.

My attention has been directed to a communication which has been addressed by your firm to the Department of Indian Affairs in relation to the subject matter of my letter to you of the 27th ultimo. I have read the contents of your letter carefully and am sorry if your tender for the work was based on a lower rate of wages than you have found it necessary to pay. I note that you were not furnished until recently with a schedule of current wages rates which had been prepared by Mr. Harrison, our Fair Wages Officer at Vancouver.

The contract with your firm does not contain any fair wages schedule, but does contain a fair wages clause providing that all persons employed in the construction of the work shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed for the character or class of work in which they are respectively engaged; and if there be no current wages in such district, then fair and reasonable rates.

The Fair Wages Officer who investigated the complaint in regard to the carpenters' wage rate on the Lytton school, found that the men of this trade who are employed have been brought from Vancouver and that Vancouver rates are applicable for carpenters as far east as Lytton and indeed are being paid a hundred miles further from Vancouver on work which is being done for the Provincial Government at Tranquille.

After giving consideration to the statements contained in your letter, I do not find any reason to change the direction which was given in my earlier communication, and would ask that this ruling be put into effect without further delay in accordance with the requirements of the Fair Wage Clause of your contract.

Yours very truly,

Re Carpenter's Rates - Indian School.

Architect

We wrote you on January 5th, in reference to a communication we had received from the Minister of Labor with the request that you take up the matter of carpenters' wages with him. Since then, you advise us has been done but we have not heard anything further from the Department urging that the difference in the wages be made up to $7.50 per day for each carpenter. We are, therefore, writing you to know what your attitude is in the matter. From our former letter it must be perfectly obvious to you that it is impossible for us to pay the increased wage out of our own funds.

We certainly followed the letter of your specification in figuring the job and not beyond the spirit of your specification in saying the ten $7.50 per day instead of $7.50 being the amount on which we based our estimates.

If, however, the government desires that a higher wage shall be paid than that which we could reasonably estimate, then we think the government, through the department involved, will surely have to make up that difference. It makes no difference at all to us how much we have to pay the men so long as we have been able to figure that amount into our estimates, and if you feel like allowing the difference to the men, we certainly will be pleased to distribute the amount when ratified by you. I give you all the names and the amount of time worked so that it could be handled direct from your department if you so wish.

In reference to the second clause in the Minister of Labor's letter, copy of which we enclose, he states that all the men who are employed have been brought from Vancouver. Would say it is possible that most of the men came from Vancouver, but, we did not bring them.
They were hired on the job at Lytton, paying their own way there. It is only the fact that our head office is in Vancouver that Vancouver carpenters have easy access to us. Had we been contractors for Kamloops, for instance, this question never could have risen and we must maintain that we are in the same position.

The Minister of Labor refers to the Provincial Government building at Tranquill, on which they are paying $7.50 to carpenters. This, we understand, is quite true, but you must note that the Tranquill contract was let quite a time after ours and in addition to that the Provincial Government took the precaution to state the amount of wages that were to be paid to carpenters, thus eliminating any necessity for the contractors to discover for themselves what rate was being paid in the district.

Trusting that you will either ratify the increased payment or take this matter up with the department of labor further and have it eliminated, which, we think, as a matter of fact would be the better plan as we must assure you that all men being hired on the job knew well the wages that were being paid and agreed to same without question.

Sir,

Re: Iyton Industrial School.

With reference to the installation of a rain water tank at the Iyton Industrial School to provide a source of soft water for laundry purposes, our District Chief Engineer at Vancouver recommends that consideration should be given to alternative means of providing soft water which may be used both for laundry and boiler purposes, in view of the fact that the water as now available may cause serious difficulties if used untreated in the heating system. A copy of a report on the subject from Mr. Tradcroft, Engineer-in-Charge of this work, to our District Chief Engineer is enclosed for your consideration. This report recommends installing a water-softening apparatus at an approximate cost of $1,000.00 instead of a rain water tank at an estimated cost of $654.00; the water softening apparatus would, of course, apply to all the water used in the school building. Mr. Tradcroft asks to have this matter placed before you as soon as possible and a decision communicated by wire through this office so that the work, whether the decision is to build a rain water tank or install a water-softening apparatus, may be completed during the present month. I shall be glad if you will advise me in regard to this at your earliest convenience.

Sir:

With further reference to your letter of November 14th, 1927, enclosing copy of telegram from the Director of Water Power authorizing the installation of a concrete rain-water tank at the Lytton Industrial School, I wish to state that work on this project was delayed owing to the fact that I considered it advisable to make some further recommendations to you in this regard before proceeding with the installation.

The idea of a concrete rain-water tank originated, I believe, with the principal of the Industrial School at Lytton, who was anxious to obtain a supply of soft water for use in the school laundry, and when an estimate of the cost of this tank was requested by the Department, no account was taken of the hardness of the water which would be supplied to the boilers and hot water system in the new building.

I now find, on further careful examination, that during recent years endless trouble and expense has been experienced in the old school building owing to the pipes, boilers, tubes, radiators, etc., being corroded on the inside with layers of lime and magnesia, caused through the use of excessively hard water; and unless some steps are taken to remedy this condition the same trouble will undoubtedly be experienced with the new heating plant.

I would therefore like to point out that if the Department is prepared to authorize an expenditure of $954.00 in order to supply soft water for laundry purposes, it would be far more economical to abandon the idea of a concrete rain-water tank and install a water softening apparatus having a capacity of 20 U.S. g.p.m., and which would soften the entire amount of water which will be used in the hot water heating system.

The cost of this installation would amount to approximately $1,000.00, which is practically the same as the cost of the proposed rain-water tank, (i.e. $954.00) and would have the advantage that whereas the rain-water tank would only supply water for laundry purposes, and the intermittently if the rainfall was light, a water softening apparatus would take care of the whole hot water heating system, and a full supply of soft water for all purposes would be available at any season of the year.

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dom. Water Power & Rec. Service,
Vancouver, B.C.
The cost of operating this water-softening apparatus, assuming that a total of 2,000 U.S. gallons of hot water would be used per day (which amount is ample to supply all ordinary needs in an institution of this kind) would amount to less than 80¢ per day, including the cost of salt, minerals, etc., and this expenditure would be offset many times over in the saving effected in repairs to boilers, hot water system, and the use of soap in the laundry, kitchen, etc.

I would therefore respectfully recommend that in place of a concrete rain-water tank being constructed as originally suggested, a zeolite water softener having a capacity of 20 U.S. g.p.m. continuous flow be substituted in its place, which apparatus, I am convinced, would prove far more satisfactory and economical in every way.

Your obedient servant,

E. H. Tredcroft
Senior Assistant Engineer.

Absolute control of temperature in storage rooms and freezer rooms, chilling of brine for ice cream freezers and the maintaining of low temperatures in ice cream hardening rooms are the principal functions of refrigerating machinery in this industry.

Cold Storage design and construction for the storage of food products in general is a class of work which we are well qualified to build. Special types of refrigerating plants such as Fur Storages, Oil Cooling, Water Cooling, etc., are to be found in our list of installations.

When contemplating changes or an entire new plant we would urge you to avail yourself of our consulting service embracing our many years of experience in designing and installing an increasingly large number of plants of all types.
When writing to us for Quotations please include information along the lines indicated on this page

1. Kindly state character and quantity of goods to be cooled or stored in each room or refrigerator, and the time during which goods should be cooled to room temperature.

INTRODUCTION

We have been engaged in the design, manufacture and installation of complete Refrigerating and Ice Making Plants for a great many years, having been one of the pioneer builders of this class of equipment in the United States.

Our policy has always been to conduct a careful study and a thorough analysis of the requirements of each installation which we have built, to the end, that the equipment installed would be thoroughly satisfactory in operation with regards to reliability and economy. As a result of this policy it can be readily appreciated that we have gathered no little amount of data and information in our many years of experience in building an increasingly large number of refrigerating and ice making equipments for various industries.

This bulletin has been prepared for those who are interested in the smaller sizes of refrigerating and ice making plants and in the following pages brief descriptions and illustrations are given of the compressor and component parts of the so called "high pressure side", the Vilter self contained units, the coil work or "low pressure side", ice tanks, brine tanks, ammonia fittings, etc., all to the end that those who are contemplating the installation of equipment of this class may be enabled to form a comprehensive idea as to what we have to offer.

Built in various sizes from one to eighteen tons of refrigeration (Standard Rating) (A.S.R.F. Code). All sizes being of the same general design, described and illustrated in the following pages. This VILTER ammonia compressor is a logical development of our many years experience in the construction of this class of machinery and has resulted in a very successful unit. It has proven to be very economical and reliable in operation requiring but a minimum of attention. It is made of high grade materials carefully assembled, tested and finished prior to shipment.
THE FRAME

The twin cylinder frame is made of semi-steel and combines the crankcase, cylinders, outboard bearing, and water jacket in one integral casting. The metal is amply thick, of a dense strong composition and the design is one with a low center of gravity thus assisting in securing stability of operation. The base of the frame is provided with a lip around the edge and in addition the base has an opening through it in the central part which admits of grouting being poured under the base at this point.

In the manufacture of the frame the casting is first carefully cleaned and sand blasted to remove any imbedded foundry sand before any machine work is started. For the accomplishment of the machine work on the frame specially designed machine tools are utilized which not only permit of many operations being performed at one setting of the frame but also insures absolute alignment of the cylinders with reference to the crank shaft. After the frame casting has been machined it is tested under air pressure to make sure that it is absolutely tight. As shown on the opposite page the frame is provided with a large hand hole in the base which is placed there to permit of inspection and adjustment of the crank pin bearings.

LUBRICATION

Proper lubrication of the compressor is obtained in part by means of the splash system. The crank case is filled with oil to a point indicated on the oil gauge and the the churning of the crank shaft and connecting rods splash oil up on to the cylinder walls and up into the basins which are a part of the frame and which introduce the oil into the end bearing and also to the bearings where the stuffing box is located. Attention is invited to the oil lantern in the stuffing box into which oil is introduced by means of an oil duct coming from the crank case. The horizontal ring which supports the flywheel is lubricated by means of an oil ring which rides on top of the shaft. The lower portion of this oil ring is immersed in oil and this oil is continually brought to the top of the bearing when the compressor is in operation. Provision is made for draining the oil from this bearing whenever desired. To insure positive lubrication of the piston pins oil tubes carrying oil pumps on the lower ends are fastened to the connecting rods. When the compressor is operated oil is constantly carried from the crank case up to the piston pins by means of this device, thus insuring proper lubrication.

BEARINGS

The bearings for the crank shaft and crank pins are all die cast and made of high grade Babbitt Metal. The bearings in the piston ends of the connecting rods consist of accurately finished close grain cast iron bushings pressed into the connecting rod ends. The design of all the bearings is such that large bearing surfaces are obtained which together with the thorough lubrication obtained results in a compressor which will function extremely well over a very long period of time.
THE SUCTION VALUE

The suction valve is our plate type of valve, the same as is now placed in all of our compressors. As seen in the figure it is made of one or more thin steel rings hardened and ground down to a perfect surface. These rings are held in place by light helical springs, and all is safely secured within two caps fastened together by a special machine screw. The method of construction and the manner in which the valve is secured in the piston eliminates the possibilities of a part ever falling into the cylinder.

The suction valve is located in the piston and is made as large as conditions will allow. The gas is drawn into the cylinder during the down stroke and the change of direction of piston movement, augmented by the spring, closes the valves. As the valve is held flexibly and is ground to a surface, there is no loss of ammonia by leakage past the valve.

THE VALVES

Some of the greatest losses in ammonia compressors are in the type of valve used. For best economy the suction line on the indicator card should coincide with the suction pressure outside the cylinder in the suction header. This is a physical impossibility assumed as it requires some drop of pressure in order to make the gas flow from the header to the cylinder. In order to decrease this loss of pressure to a minimum the valves must be light, of little inertia, and easily operated. The valve parts must be straight and the ports and the valve openings must be ample in cross sectional area.

THE DISCHARGE VALVE

The discharge valve is also of the plate valve construction, although in a modified form. It consists of a plate valve with a cylindrical recess which makes a tight running fit on its inside with a projecting lug in the safety head of the compressor. The valve is held flexibly in place by a light helical spring. By means of our special patented construction this valve will operate with practically no noise.

The discharge valve is made single or in multiple depending on the size compressor; this is done to secure the necessary area. The safety head construction is used which permits of a very small clearance being obtained and also insures safety in operation.
CONNECTING ROD

In the manufacture of our connecting rods the greatest care is taken. Special machinery is used for the boring and reaming of the ends. The rods are made of cast steel with a strong H section and are fitted with a cast iron bushing on the piston end and a die cast pure Babbitt Metal bearing on the crank end. Special attention has been given to lubrication and ample oil holes and grooves have been provided.

THE PISTON

The piston which is of the trunk type with ample space between the two parts for clearance opposite the suction gas inlet is made of semi-steel and ground to a micrometer fit. It is carefully fitted with the required number of piston rings of a high grade type to insure the proper functioning of the piston. The top part of the piston carries the suction valve and the lower part of the piston carries the piston pin which is made of a special hardened steel ground to fit and properly secured in place. This construction results in proper piston lubrication with generous bearing areas.
Vilter ammonia expansion piping, or as it is sometimes designated, ammonia evaporating piping, is very carefully fabricated. The pipe used is of high quality and specially built tools and equipment are utilized in this work. As may be noted from the illustration, the ammonia flanges or couplings are made of drop forged steel and fitted with tongue and groove joints in which metallic gaskets are secured by means of a minimum of four bolts. In the illustration shown below attention is invited to the fact that the finished coil is one homogeneous length of pipe which has been made possible by means of electric welding. The flanges are sweated and soldered on to the pipe when the coils are built up in our shops. After the coils have been fabricated they are carefully tested with air pressure while submerged in water and after testing they are painted.

The Vilter Double Pipe Ammonia Condenser is made up of 14 inch and 2 inch high grade selected ammonia pipes placed one within the other. The inner 14 inch pipes, connected at the ends by the usual form of flanged return bends of 4 inch centers, enclose the water circulation while the annular spaces between the inner and outer pipes form the ammonia condensation chambers. The 2 inch outer pipes are screwed into special return bends at one end and connected to similar return bends by four bolt flanges at the other end. The inner water pipes pass through stuffing boxes on the outer side of the return fittings and can be disconnected and withdrawn separately without interference with the rest of the apparatus. The direction of water and gas circulation in this type of condenser are countercurrent.

Vilter Liquid Receivers and Vilter High Pressure Oil Traps are all made of heavy wrought material with welded heads and with nipples and sleeves welded on. Extreme care is observed during construction and each receiver and trap is carefully tested under pressure prior to shipment.
The illustrations on these two pages outline in a general manner the application of mechanical refrigeration to a single refrigerator box. That portion of the equipment in the refrigerator box is known as the "low pressure side" and consists of ammonia expansion piping and brine holdover tank, both of which are placed in the floor of the refrigerator box. Plants such as these are designed to operate but a portion of every 24-hour period depending upon conditions. The holdover tank contains ammonia expansion piping submerged in a brine solution. This piping cools the brine in the tank during the period when the compressor is operating and this body of cold brine prevents any undue rise in temperature in the refrigerator when the compressor is shut down.

That portion of the equipment outside of the refrigerator box is known as the "high pressure side" and consists of the ammonia compressor, belt and motor, ammonia condenser, oil trap, liquid receiver, pressure gauges and ammonia connections, water supply and drain connections to the ammonia condenser and ammonia compressor are also included.

There are numerous arrangements found in practice depending upon the number of refrigerators, freezers, brine or ice tanks which are to be placed in operation but they are elaborations of the fundamental system illustrated. In general liquid ammonia passes through the expansion valve into the expansion piping where by virtue of its low boiling temperature it absorbs heat from the interior of the refrigerator and thus evaporates into a gas. The compressor takes this gas and forces it through the condenser where the gas due to the pressure generated by the compressor and coming into contact with the cold water pipe in the condenser, condenses into a liquid form, flows into the liquid receiver and from the liquid receiver the liquid returns to the expansion valve again.
SMALL CAN ICE PLANTS

Our tanks and coils are so designed and proportioned, and a sufficient number of cans furnished, to permit slow freezing of the ice. A high grade product of uniform quality is thus secured.

The freezing tank is made from sheet steel, well riveted and braced, so that it will not leak or bulge when filled with brine. The tank is set in a first class manner and the insulating material covered with a neat facing material, dressed and matched wooden lagging. The top is provided with a wooden cover work and insulated covers for the ice cans.

The evaporating coils are of loop construction, each made from one continuous length of extra strong ammonia pipe, connected by heavy manifolds and also to a liquid line leading from the expansion valve and to the suction line leading to the compressor. A valve and connection for blowing air, oil or scale from the coils, or charging the system with liquid anhydrous ammonia, is accessibly located near the bottom of the tank.

The brine agitator is of the horizontal type, usually driven by a link belt chain from a sprocket on the compressor shaft.

In this illustration the air agitating equipment which is employed to make clear ice is shown. This equipment is furnished only when the water which is to be frozen is suitable for making clear ice.

In certain types of installations it has been found desirable to utilize a refrigerating machine which is of the so-called self-contained design, which consists of the complete high pressure side including the motor all mounted on one base.

In the unit illustrated one of the smaller Vilter twin cylinder compressors is utilized. The condenser and liquid receiver used in this unit are of the submerged type and are mounted on the base between the motor and compressor. These units are assembled, tested and finished in our shops prior to shipment thus reducing the work of installation to a minimum. Special foundations are not required for this unit as in the case when a unit of the type illustrated on page 12 is installed.

The operation of this unit is quite simple and easily understood and as it is very quiet in operation owing to the Vilter plate valves being used in the compressor it has met with very favorable consideration since its initial appearance on the market.

In certain types of plants where steam is available for motive power refrigerating units such as this are desirable. To fulfill these conditions this unit has been developed. It consists of a Vilter twin cylinder compressor direct connected through a flexible coupling to a high grade steam engine. The engine and compressor are mounted on a cast iron base and the entire unit is secured to a built-in foundation.
APPLICATION

In the development of the application of refrigerating machinery the field is constantly being extended, in various ways, and consequently no attempt is made here to list all types of plants. The several illustrations are of organizations wherein Vilter Twin Cylinder Compressors and other Vilter equipment have been installed and are the types of applications most generally met with in practice.

The question of whether or not a brine system should be used or an ammonia system employed is best solved by the existing conditions. If there are many boxes to be cooled and they are of small size and not all centrally located the brine system is usually to be desired. Hotels, Clubs, Hospitals and Institutions usually employ brine systems, as in these types of installations there are usually numerous refrigerator boxes in several different portions in the building. In many of these installations an ice making tank is also installed to furnish the ice required for table use. In the event that there are but a few refrigerator boxes which have to be cooled and these boxes are located very close together the direct expansion system is usually to be desired, as in this case the employment of a brine tank, brine pump and brine coils can be dispensed with as the ammonia is expanded directly in the ammonia expansion or evaporating coils properly placed in the several refrigerator boxes.

In some installations a combination of the two systems is desirable. A typical example of this being in dairy and Creamery plants where the brine holdover tank in the refrigerator box is made large enough to not only act as a holdover tank for this box but also supplies brine to the milk and cream cooling apparatus.

Bakers have found that a refrigerating plant is of great value to them in the manufacture of bread. Temperature control from day to day regardless of outdoor conditions is obtained by a properly designed and installed refrigerating plant.

Candy manufacturers have also found that a refrigerating plant is a very desirable item of plant equipment especially so in the manufacture of chocolate confections.

In the Dairy Products Industry refrigerating machinery has proven to be of immense value. Absolute control of temperature in storage rooms and freezer rooms, chilling of brine for ice cream freezers and the maintaining of low temperatures in ice cream hardening rooms are the principal functions of refrigerating machinery in this industry.

In the Packing House Industry and in its branches such as wholesale and retail markets, sausage factories, etc., temperature control is of primary importance. Our many years of experience are available for the correct design and construction of Meat Culling, Freezing and Storage Plants.

Cold Storage design and construction for the storage of food products in general is a class of work which we are well qualified to build. Special types of refrigerating plants such as Fur Storages, Oil Cooling, Water Cooling, etc., are to be found in our list of installations.

When contemplating changes or an entire new plant we would urge you to avail yourself of our consulting service embracing our many years of experience in designing and installing an increasingly large number of plants of all types.

3. Describe the insulation, and location, South, North, etc., of the rooms, how protected from outside temperatures.

2 painters or a handy man has been left to finish up at my direction which will be done in 3 days or so. The building will be left clean and all the contractors materials or equipment has been removed from the ground.

The heating plant gives great satisfaction and is left in perfect condition—same thing applies to the plumbing—a little extra...
plumbing was necessary in the laundry connection with the laundry machinery (apart from the drains) the contractors were very tardy about putting this in. I also asked for a water line & faucet for the engine room for supplying water to the cooling tanks of engines but refused to do it nor being specifically mentioned in specifications. Water will have to be got in by pails or hosepipe.

The laundry machinery is in good order or seems satisfactory. The electric lighting plant give great satisfaction also, and is now in permanent use.

Mr. Lett has taken up residence in the school, & has taken charge.

The greater part of school furnishings is been installed in the school... is almost ready for occupation.

I have given contractors a letter accepting the building as satisfactorily finished & in a few days will be sending in the final certificate along with their Extras & Deductions accounts... for showing cost of Electric fixtures.

Obediently Yours,

Frank W. Beattie

Rev. Sir,

Dear Sir,

Owing to the heavy slope of the land at the rear of the above new school, the grade will be terraced down making it 3 ft lower at extreme rear of building, thus leaving 2½ to 3 ft of unpainted concrete wall showing. Mr. Lott and Mr. Graham think that this should be cement finished as is the remainder of wall showing above grade. There is about 40 super yds required to be covered or finished. The cost of
doing this would not exceed $30.00 labor & materials.

The contractors would not do the work without an order—on the spot—which I could not give them. Thinking myself that the work should be done kindly wrote Mr. Graham whether it can be ordered done at once if possible.

Reporting again on the work of installing the boys' girls' dormers, sewing-room doors, miscellaneous shelving, etc., but to say—as work is only one carpenter & myself also working as a carpenter—the work can not be done much before Sat May 5th.

And as far as I can see there is all that is required at the new school. If any services no longer required here after that date I decidedly you,

Truly W. Baker

Dear Sir:

We have received again your certificate together with our cheque and would say we hoped, as expressed in our letter, that we would have gotten this back to you before you had sent your documents to Ottawa. However, as they were already gone, that cannot now be helped.

We are sending the certificate to Ottawa and asking for remittance in accordance with same.

Now, in answer to your letter regarding gravel, for instance, you have apparently taken a little offense at mentioning gravel at all, but, we see no reason for this as our only mention of the gravel was that we did not figure up the amount you state but we are willing to pass it at this. In this case there is certainly no need to mention it further and certainly no need for any special measurement. We will say, however, that we are quite satisfied with the measurement that you have given.

Now, as regards the tile in the kitchen and scullery, would say originally the plans and specification called for glazed brick in the kitchen. These brick were a part of the strength of the wall and figured by us accordingly, allowing the price that it would cost us over and above common brick to place in glazed brick. We are quite satisfied to show you, or anybody else, our original estimate for this work which is as follows:

We figured that 776 sq.ft. of glazed brick face was required, at a price of $1.00 per foot, making $776.00 for the completion of the kitchen walls, but, you will remember that considering the condition of things and the time required to get the glazed brick, we asked that this be changed to tile allowing us more time and better facilities for finishing these walls.
We knew, at the time, it was likely to cost us a little more to put in the tile than it would the brick, but, on account of the saving in time and convenience we stated at that time that there would be no change and certainly, when the accommodation was to ourselves, we had no right to ask the government for more money to make this change.

Now we submit to you the exact cost on all the tile, metal lath and plaster that went into the finishing of the two (2) rooms, both scullery and kitchen. You will find that this amounts to eight hundred and seven dollars and seventy-cents. ($807.70) and, as we are entitled to 10% on the work, we do, it makes a total of eight hundred and eighty-eight dollars and forty-seven cents. ($888.47).

It is true when first asked to tile the walls of the scullery, we gave you a price of seven hundred and forty-two dollars. ($742.00) for the job, which in our opinion is not out of the way. This, of course, proportionately would be higher than we had figured for the kitchen but we already knew that the tile work was going to cost us more money than we had figured and there was no good reason why we should do additional work at a losing price.

We think you will see by these figures, any of which can easily be verified, that if there is to be any change in the price that we should receive, there is an amount coming to us for the finishing of the two rooms of one hundred and twelve dollars and forty-seven cents. ($112.47) being the difference between the cost of the work eight hundred and eighty-eight dollars and forty-seven cents ($888.47) and the amount of our estimate for finishing of the kitchen of seven hundred and seventy-six dollars. ($776.00). We, of course, are not asking that this amount be allowed but, if you feel in all fairness that we should get it, we certainly will not object to receive our certificate for same.

We are

Yours truly,

ADISON & DILL, LTD.

For J. C. Dill

Dear Sir,

With reference to the trouble with the chimneys of residence of the new school to which I have previously reported and as instructed by your telegram of April 5 both chimneys were heightened 7 ft each or brought up to the level of the parapet walls of main building at a cost of $60.

Regret to report that the trouble is not entirely got rid of so that there is still a little occasional trouble.

I have thoroughly examined flues that no stoppages or obstruction of draught are there.

Mr. Ditchburn, the Commissioner, who was here visiting the school observed the trouble also and asked me to write you to permit us to put another 3 feet on them as these chimneys are now at a
considerable elevation the labor cost would be considerable and each chimney would require anchoring to the main wall of building the cost would be around $40. Kindly advise me by return mail if this work can be done.

I reported also to you on April 25 that owing to the grade line of earth being left 3 ft lower at rear of building the cement concrete foundation walls have been left without a finishing coat of cement and as contractors refused to do this below grade line Mr. Ditchburn who has personally inspected the walls says this should be done and went so far as to authorize me to have it done. Mr. Jett has a quantity of cement left over some of which can be used for this purpose, without cost to the Depot.

The only expense would be labor which would be around $25.00 Both this and the chimney jobs should be done at same time. The builder, who is now off duty since May 10th is open to return to Lytton for a few days if necessary to see this work done. Obeyantly Yours

Dear Mr. McLean:

I had an opportunity of going thoroughly over the school building at Lytton. The construction is defective in several important particulars, and if the contractor's security cheque has not been returned, I would advise you to hold it. I think the Supervisor of Construction is to blame to some extent.

Mr. Dill, of the Contracting Firm, saw me in Vancouver, in company with Mr. Bater, and I was not at all impressed by the last named gentleman.

Unseasoned lumber was evidently used for the doors and interior fittings, and the result is that many of the doors have shrunk, and go right past the stop, and others are crooked and do not close. A poor job of plastering was done, and the material throughout is not first class. The cement floors in the play room are sure to give trouble later on, as they are already scaling. There are one or two points about the building that I will take up with Mr. Orr when I return to headquarters.

Mr. Dill is anxious that certain allowances should be made him, and he brought up the question of increased wages, but after seeing the building, I am not at all sympathetic with his claim, in fact I think we have a claim against him.

Dear Mr. Graham—

Re the present small building which we have been utilizing as a dairy. This is a temporary wooden structure without a flue, as it was not thought necessary to go to any great expense, for a permanent dairy would be erected.

Dear Mr. McLean:

I had an opportunity of going thoroughly over the school building at Lytton. The construction is defective in several important particulars, and if the contractor's security cheque has not been returned, I would advise you to hold it. I think the Supervisor of Construction is to blame to some extent.

Mr. Dill, of the Contracting Firm, saw me in Vancouver, in company with Mr. Bater, and I was not at all impressed by the last named gentleman.

Unseasoned lumber was evidently used for the doors and interior fittings, and the result is that many of the doors have shrunk, and go right past the stop, and others are crooked and do not close. A poor job of plastering was done, and the material throughout is not first class. The cement floors in the play room are sure to give trouble later on, as they are already scaling. There are one or two points about the building that I will take up with Mr. Orr when I return to headquarters.

Mr. Dill is anxious that certain allowances should be made him, and he brought up the question of increased wages, but after seeing the building, I am not at all sympathetic with his claim, in fact I think we have a claim against him.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

Regarding the rough sketch of the proposed new storage and repair shops for this school which I have just submitted to Indian Agent Graham and which he has endorsed and recommended having gone over the situation with me, I thought it best to make some further comment for your information.

Regarding the basement which I purpose dividing into four parts:
One room 20x17 for the installation of the refrigeration plant taking out of the school basement as it is not proving at all satisfactory in its present position owing to it being of such handy access to the kitchen. The milk butter bacon and etc being kept in it causes considerable opening of the door allowing the temperature to fall rapidly necessitating the constant use of the engine and the quick fall and rise is not the best for the keeping of meats.

The remaining part of this division 17x20 left as an open shed to be used as a wood shed and to keep in it the axes saws etc in use rather than having them standing in the corner of the school basement or in the corner of the fence.

The middle of this floor 35x35 to be used for storage of storm sash extra beds & bedding etc now housed in the top dormitory and which we now need for children as we are now running 140 it is essential to relieve these rooms.

The remaining 20x35 to be made into two bedrooms for extra farm help now occupying one room in the school building necessitating the use of one bedroom in the residence to accommodate one of the teachers which at the present time is occupied by her.

The first floor divided into three shops shoe repairing, carpenters repair shop and manual training shop. The present room used for manual training is altogether too small necessitating the curtailing of instruction and repetition of classes.

Regarding the top floor, I have asked that the four walls be extended so that this can be used for a playroom for the boys. The roof has necessarily to be put on and with very little added expense the walls could be extended which would add to the looks of the building besides relieving the congestion in the auditorium also giving a playroom for each side.

I wish also by this means to keep in closer touch with the old boys having a club room which they could come perhaps once a fortnight to play games and carry out the business routine of an organised club.

I feared that perhaps the Dept. would think that the proposition was to elaborate and not warranted but I am sure you can readily see its necessity.

Thanking you very obediently yours,

Dear Sir,

With reference to the proposed new Indian School at Alert Bay, B.C., the construction of which a number of local firms are tendering on—among them Adkison & Dill Ltd. and E.H. Shockley Co. I wish to advise you that these two firms can not be relied upon to do good work except under all kinds of compulsion, and if my advice is worth anything would not recommend acceptance of their tenders under any consideration.

The writer was Inspector of Construction at the Tyton School which was built by Adkison & Dill, and my experience with them there was such that I am prompted write you this letter.

Two very reliable firms tendering are Browne & Vestaunet and Smith Bros & Wilson.

I understand that the Dept. is not entirely satisfied with the work at the Tyton School, I can assure you that...
the building was well constructed, but the clean finishing of the floors was not possible under the conditions that had to be contended against. I am referring to the action of the Principal Mr. A. R. Lett moving into the school too soon, and storing in the new school large quantities of new furnishings 2-3 weeks before the floors were even oiled, thereby giving the contractors trouble in the finishing of the work. Clearly, however his haste to move into it was excusable owing to the bad condition of the old building.

I can assure you now that the work was all completed by the contractors to my satisfaction before they left, but not without difficulties.

If any defects have appeared since my leaving there I feel that they will not be minimized by Mr. Lett as he is not well disposed towards the contractors owing to an unsatisfactory gravel bowling contract he had with them.

I hope however, in this connection that I have not been thought neglectful as I had to be fair to all concerned, & hope also that I shall again serve. I am Sir,

Dear Sir:

We have had a visit from Frank Rater, who was the Inspector on above school which we erected for you.

Now, as to the objections, would say we are prepared to make good, at any time, on any of our buildings whether under guarantee or not, for anything in the shape of faulty construction or poor materials supplied.

The building, however, having been finished in the winter, it is only reasonable to expect that the doors would at that time have absorbed a certain amount of moisture and when thoroughly dried-out would shrink somewhat. These certainly can easily be fixed.

This also would pertain to any other of the woodwork.

Regarding the concrete paint, we presume this is on the floors of the building and would say that we provided the best concrete paint we knew of but, must also say that we know of no paint put on a hard concrete floor that would stand the wear and tear of a school full of children with rough boots, especially in a country with so much sand that blows right into the building with every wind-storm.

Dear Sir,

As directed in your letter to me dated Nov 26th I went by train out to the St. Georges Indied School. I went there in company with the Principal and we went all over the building and thoroughly examined the defects he has complained about.

With regard to the doors, there are about 20 that need attention, refitting so that they fit more closely to the frames and the lock keepers adjusted. There has been some shrinkage in them so as to leave about 3/8 of an inch between jamb & door. The door jambs should be taken out or refitted to doors. The doors themselves are in perfect condition. Only the interior doors are affected.
There is one exterior door—the boy's entrance, the frame of which needs reanchoring into the brickwork as the wall plugs have loosened on one side. This door is subjected to a great deal of slamming & heavier brickwork should have been specified to go around it.

The varnish on the exterior doors is about gone & should be cleaned off & revarnished with a good weather-proof varnish.

The ¼ round of baseboards do not fit closely and should all be taken off & reset.

The baseboards are everywhere in good order and all other interior woodwork, excepting on some of the windows where the window stops need taking off or adjusting closer to sash to prevent rattling.

As regards the glazed tilework there is a patch about 2 sq yds loose in the scullery over the sink and some tiles have already come out.
I suspect that this portion was shock up by the contractors plumbers when drilled holes through it to anchor up some heavy fixtures, and it is a wall of wood constructed (studded) when these tile are reset there will be no further trouble.

The tile in the kitchen is in perfect condition.

As to the plastering, it is on the whole of very good quality, there are a few small holes where it has been damaged by door handles etc., and there are a number of cracks in corners of rooms where walls are of stud partitions. These cracks are caused by the natural shrinkage of wood.

Some of these walls bear directly upon the floor joist in which there is the greatest amount of shrinkage and at other parts are attached to brick walls which remain rigid and at such places cracks appear. However when they are filled up with plaster of parts they are rendered
almost invisible. There is no settlement in the foundation walls nor at any post or column.

There are 2 or 3 small line cracks in foundation wall which I believe lateral shrinkage in a long length of wall. It must be taken into consideration that no reinforcement bars was specified for walls (only in footings of piers).

The faulty cement tread in steel stairs of which there is only one, on the boys side, must be relaid.

As regards the drinking fountains they of a good standard make & are as firm & rigid as could possibly be, but there is either a restriction or contraction of the flow of water, or low pressure as the water does not rise more than an inch from the nozzle whereas when they were first installed the water would rise 6 or 8 inches high. Sir,

When you were out last summer, Mr. Lett and I pointed out to you the various defects in St. George's new school building.

I presume that it was on the strength of this that Mr. Bater, who was superintendent of construction, was sent up to report, and the contractors apparently, that he would mend any deficiencies, with the result that Mr. Bater was sent up by the contractors to do the work. He was here for about ten days, and Mr. Lett asked me to come up today to see the work that had been done and not been done. Additional cleats have been put round some of the windows, but these are far from satisfactory. You can see daylight round almost any door in the building, and the same might almost be said of the windows; in some cases the window sills are coming away from the cement, and one can see daylight right round.

The whole building has shrunk, with the result that you can put your fingers underneath all door casings, and in places the quarter round, round the floors of the rooms, has shrunk, leaving crevices between the baseboard and quarter round.

The residence part of the building is so bad that what heat does get there is all used up by the draughts that come in round doors and windows.

I notice too that the transoms have not been put on with hinges and proper fixtures. Some are actually just held in position by big nails.

Some of the work that has recently been done by Mr. Bater, has not even been varnished.

The crevices left where the building has settled all round the floors are just receptacles to catch dust, etc.

The whole building is taking so much to heat, far more than we ever dreamt, which is not to be wondered at, when so much cold air comes in, in every direction. Even doors that Mr. Bater has tried to patch up, are very far from satisfactory now and lots of them he never touched at all.

Sir—

Re the late repairs which have been done throughout the School building by Mr. F.G. Bater on behalf of Adkinson & Dill contractors, allow me to report the following for the information of the Dept.

I was not at all satisfied with the work and called in Mr. Indian Agent Graham who also will pass his coment on the work.

The door jams have been filled in with ½" material nailed on to the jams and lock catches refitted leaving the woodwork where the original settings open with no filling whatever, & in a great many cases the extra material put on is not varnished.

The Door jams in all cases are standing away from the floor anywhere from ½ to ¾ of an inch leaving a very unsanitary and unsightly condition.

Instead of the baseboards being taken off they were filled in with strips of one inch material and the quarter round reset.

The Fire escape doors were not touched and the wind blows through almost as though they were open.

The windows also were not looked into as a great many of them are rattling in the wind.

There was also some windows left without screens which Mr. Bater said he would provide but they are evidently not forthcoming.

The Drinking fountains have been left as they were.

The outside doors instead of being handpapered and revarnished were varnished over the old varnish and I am sure that in six months time they will be as bad as they were before varnishing.

Mr. Bater has spent five weeks patching and surely left a patched up looking New School but should have spent another five weeks to finish his patching and I expect he will report favorably to the Dept on his own work and ask Railway fare and time wages for inspecting what he has done.

The Contractor was somewhat fore-sighted in asking Mr. Bater to do the work and Bater being innocent enough not to see that he was being made a tool of will report favorably on the repair work to the advantage of the Contractor and perhaps get away with it but I trust this will not be so.

I think a non interested man should be sent in to see what has been done and what has been left undone so that the Dept. could receive an unbiased report on the conditions existing.

I trust the above will not burden you but thought it my duty to again put the situation before you.
so that you might be aware of the situation.

I am sorry to be so harsh in my criticism but I think it is a shame to let these people get away with such work without the Dept. knowing something of it and trust that you will use same to the benefit of the building.

He should also have suggested to the Dept. the proposed repairs before the work was undertaken by any one to see if the proposed repairs would be satisfactory to the Dept.'s Architect.

Dear Mr. Wilson,

With reference to the St. George's Indian School - Lytton BC and your letter to me dated Nov 28, 1928, asking me to go out to the Lytton school to investigate the complaints in regard to certain repairs needed at the school. I accordingly went out to Lytton and as you know sent in a detailed report of what was wrong. I also wrote again about the complaint informing you of what the contractors' advance or did not were doing. The contractors have finished the work they were required to do, so have asked me to report the fact to you, and also to bring to your attention the fact that there is still a certain sum of money due them in connection with the building of the school which I am dealing with in a separate letter herewith attached.
In order to satisfy myself I went out to Sutton again on the 21st inst., & inspected the work done. I will describe it in detail. The doors complained of were not nearly so bad as Mr. Lott reported. They had been fitted frames & lock perfectly. They are not likely to go out of adjustment—again as building & woodwork is now thoroughly dried out.

Of the concrete slabs of basement floors nothing can be done at the present time not until next summer comes. But as the floors are perfectly smooth & cleanable & show no sign of wearing away, nothing is it is not necessary to do anything to them. The floors were treated with borax & properly painted before school was taken over—but as Mr. Lott wanted to occur building before paint had a chance to harden, contractor cannot be blamed if it wore off in places.

The patch of old tile in scullery wall has been replaced. (that had fallen out) Practically all of the 4 round (of baseboard) have been taken off & replaced.

Outside doors have received a coat of best varnish obtainable.
The drinking fountains complained of are a good heavy standard make same as used in Vancouver schools and cannot be said to be of the very poorest as our last claims.

The holes in plaster have been repaired or settlement cracks pointed up. I might say that the only places damaged were caused by heavy objects accidently striking wall at some time during occupation of building and although the contractor was not obliged to repair these - did so.

Two of the concrete stair treads were taken out & renewed. They are all now faultless.

Many small hardware fitting were readjusted so that they would fasten. The fir flooring is everywhere in good shape but need re oiling or varnishing to make them appear good. No varnish was specified. One or two locks have been damaged by accident as also has several panes of glass of which the contractor cannot be called upon to replace.

The engines of the electric plant
has not been running as satisfactorily as expected but this is due to the fact that they were never operated by a man that knew how to run them. Any trouble or misadjustment could not be understood or located. Batteries were never more than half charged, mostly ¼ charged. Engines run under heavy load, perhaps with defective valves or a blown fuse plug.

The plant never had a chance, but it functioned perfectly when school was taken over. Contractor cannot be called upon to recondition same. I believe all else is satisfactory or think the Deptt should appreciate the manner in which the contractors carried out the requirements of their contract with the Deptt to the fullest extent.

I am Sir,

Obsequiously Yours,
Frank W. Baillie

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 6th., instant, and would say we are very sorry indeed to hear that there is still dissatisfaction with our work at St. George's School at Lytton.

We hate to say it but it would almost seem that we are being persecuted on this job for some personal reasons rather than actual fact.

It is true we had Mr. Bater do the repair work. He claimed to us that he was a first-class carpenter and we know he has been working at carpenter work in the City of Vancouver. Had it not been so we would never have given him the work to put right.

We thought at the time that it would be more advantageous to all concerned to wait a little later in the year until the weather moderated and would have done so, but, as Mr. Bater was going to be up there anyway, and as it was he that had to be satisfied, we thought it would be good business on our part to let him make the repairs to his own satisfaction, which to us would mean the department.

It certainly was not in any sense of the word with the idea of putting anything over the department.

We have paid Mr. Bater good money for his services; One hundred and fifty-one dollars and fifty cents ($151.50) cash in wages, and it seems strange to us that the superintendent at Lytton and the Indian agent should allow Mr. Bater to go away from the work and things still in an unsatisfactory condition to them.

Again we wish to assure you as we have done several times that we are behind our work to the limit and will be perfectly glad to make anything right if found faulty on our account.

We think, however, we should be treated likewise and as there is still money coming to us on this operation, surely we either should be paid or some reason given for not doing so.

We have now been trying for ten months to have this matter settled and have been given nothing whatever but promises that the matter would be looked into and few promises even at that.
Feb. 13/29.

We trust that we will hear something better from you by return mail.

We are also glad to know that an officer of the Department will make the next inspection. We would be glad indeed if Mr. Gurney Orr, the architect himself could be that inspector.

We also would be pleased if when any inspection is being made that whoever may be in charge would be given authority to wire us while he is in Lytton, if he finds anything seriously wrong that we may go up at once and go into the matter with him, personally.

This is all we have to say now.

Trusting you will use your good offices to see that we get a square deal as we are perfectly willing and anxious to give one, we are

Yours truly,
ADKISON & DILL, LTD.,

Dear Sir,

With reference to the repair work done by Mr. Dill at the St. George Indian Residential School at Lytton, I beg to mention to you that I have not yet received my cheque for my services or expenses in connection with same from the government. I sent in my account (with my report) Jan 25th amounting to $27.40.

As the Deputy had commissioned me to deal with the matter, I considered that my attention was necessary until the matter was disposed of.

I hope the Deputy will be good enough to remit as I am at present suffering the direst poverty. Having had but little employment since May 10th last when the work finished at Lytton, my appointment as Inspector ended.
After long periods of unemployment I am in very reduced circumstances. My wife and children dependant upon me. I have had to apply to Mr. Barnett Lee of the Soldier Club for relief and to the City Relief Officer so we would not starve.

I obtained a little work from the Depot last June $60 a mo. and also worked 3 weeks here for the contractors. I applied to the Depot for further employment but was not successful. Trusting I shall receive settlement asked for.

I am Sir,

Yours Truly,

Frank W. Batter.

OTTAWA.

Re- St. George's School, Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Replying to your letter of the 23rd ultimo I would say that I have carefully noted your instructions regarding the rendering of my salary and expense accounts, and I shall follow the procedure outlined by you.

With regard to my services at Cardston during the first half of the month of February, I seem to have had no time to make out the account since leaving there, but hope to do so within a day or two.

With reference to that part of your letter bearing on the complaints of faulty work done by the contractors in the building of St. George's School, I have been pretty well all over the job with the exception of the roof, which I have yet to examine, and on the whole there is nothing seriously wrong with the building that is evident at the present time. However, the Reverend Principal has good reason to complain about the loose-fitting doors and windows, and the settling of the floors away from the base in a number of places, and other minor troubles. The trouble is the result of using lumber not thoroughly seasoned, which the dry summer weather has caused to shrink badly. The man who was sent by the contractors to make the necessary adjustments and repairs did not complete his work by a long way, and further corrections are necessary.

When in Vancouver recently I called on Messrs Adkinson and Dill with reference to the defects that have developed in the building and had a conference with their Mr. Dill. I also met the millwork sub-contractor (Mr. Crystal) and the heating & plumbing sub-contractors Murray Bros. The last mentioned firm have promised to make good the drinking fountains that refuse to function, and to make the heating of the water in the hot water storage tank more satisfactory. Mr. Dill states that he has already spent $200.00 in sending a man to overcome the troubles, and had understood that everything was all right until recently notified to the contrary. He agrees to come with his superintendent, and take notes of everything requiring their attention, and to leave everything in good shape. He proposes taking this action within a few weeks, as his firm are pre-occupied with something else at present.
Dill complains that there is a considerable balance due them still from the Department, and that his letters calling attention to this have not met with any response. I told Mr. Dill that after he has remedied the faults which have developed in the building his claims will be more apt to be considered.

Now that the winter is about over there does not seem to be any emergency about having these adjustments performed at the school, and I took it on myself to tell Adkinson and Dill that if they attend to the troubles within the next few weeks it will be satisfactory. This they have promised to do.

With the exception of the defects reported by the Reverend Principal, there is nothing radically wrong with the building that I have been able to discover, and there is much worthy of praise. I shall make a further report after the contractors have completed their repair work.

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.
