Report on St. George's School, Lytton, B.C.

Sir:

In response to a request made by the Department's Architect, Mr. R.Guerney Orr, I now submit the following Report on the condition of St. George's School, with reference to the complaints made by the Principal, Rev. A.R.Lett, of defective work in the building. These complaints may be summarized as follows, and I shall deal with them in the order given:

1. Badly fitted doors, a number of which are not standing up well.
2. Loose fitting and draughty windows, which rattle badly when the wind blows.
3. Defective spots in the concrete floors of play-rooms.
4. Floor drains in wash-rooms above level of the floors.
5. Open spaces in several rooms where the floors have settled away from the base and quarter-round. This applies also in bath-rooms where the floors and base are of concrete.
6. No heat in a number of radiators even when there is a good head of steam.
7. Total failure of the hot water storage system.

When in Vancouver recently I called on the contractors, Messrs Adkinson & Dill, and formally notified them of the defects which I had observed. Last Sunday Mr. Dill came here in response to my request, bringing with him his superintendent who was in charge of the construction, the carpenter foreman, the millwork man, and his heating engineer. We went over the building pretty thoroughly; the complaints were gone into, and Mr. Dill has undertaken to make the following adjustments:

1. The doors will be taken down, and practically all of them have strips added to them as needed to make them fit the frames snugly. These strips will be neatly fitted, glued, sandpapered, and tinted with orange shellac to match other woodwork. In some instances thresholds will be placed beneath the doors to take up surplus space; and the fastens will be made to hold the doors properly.

2. Practically every window in the building will receive a specially-struck parting strip with a rabatted extension which
will extend to meet the edge of the upper sash. As the groove in which the upper sashes slide had been milled too wide, there is far too much play at present, which results in draughty windows which rattle badly with every wind that blows, but by adopting the means outlined this trouble should be overcome. The same fault applies to the lower sash in all windows, but this can be easily corrected by moving the vertical stop to take up this surplus play, and this will be done.

3. The defective spots in the recreation rooms are not very extensive, and the contractor has agreed to chisel out these places, and fill them level with a rich concrete strengthened with Master Mix hardener.

4. The floor drains in wash-rooms have been carelessly placed with regard to the general level, and these floors have not been given the required grade. Surplus water refuses to run uphill to these floor drains. This trouble cannot be corrected without breaking up and re-laying these floors. This would cause no end of mess and trouble at this late day, so the school staff will have to push the water to the floor drains with mops and brooms when swabbing these floors, as they are doing at present.

5. The open spaces below the base at floor lines is caused by the shrinking of the green joists used. The shrinkable timber has not been evenly distributed. Perhaps this was scarcely possible where stud partitions meet brick walls. Mr. Dill tells me that it is impossible to buy seasoned joists in Coast markets, and that this shrinkage was unavoidable. However, there will not be any further shrinkage of joists, and the contractor is sending 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" bull-nosed strips to take up the open spaces where the quarter round has proved insufficient. In some rooms 2" strips will be necessary. The bathrooms have large cracks in the concrete where the base and floor meet. These cracks are to be raked out and filled, which is not a difficult correction to make.

6. A number of radiators throughout the building do not circulate the steam, and remain cold. Even a casual inspection reveals the cause. In my opinion there are far too many horizontal runs to and from the radiators, in some cases several feet in length, with little or no grade away from the radiators. The specifications call for "not less than HALF INCH fall per foot run", and this has not been observed. I pointed this out to the heating engineer, but he states that every radiator functioned perfectly when the heating contract was finished, but that the settlement in the floors has in some instances robbed the horizontal runs of the fall which had been given them, and is the sole cause of the radiators thus affected not now heating. He has agreed to send a mechanic to go over all the radiation, and that every radiator will be made to circulate the steam satisfactorily.

7. The hot-water storage system which has been installed here does not furnish hot water when depending on the steam taken from the heating boilers. It has been found necessary to keep the jacket heater going full blast too, or do without hot water. I took this matter up with the heating engineer, and he assures me that the service has been installed exactly in accordance with the detail
shown on the heating sheet supplied by the Department, and with the specifications accompanying same. Steam has been taken from the boiler header through an 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" pipe to the storage tank of 300 gal. capacity, and in this tank are two loops of coils of 1" diameter. This installation has proved entirely inadequate to heat this large body of water. I told him that as far as the naked eye could tell, something must be missing, and that in other schools not only had we an abundance of hot water but that it had been found necessary to install a "Powers' Automatic Temperature Control" to prevent the water from becoming excessively hot. He asked to see the plans and specifications of one of the other schools, and I showed him that at St. Paul's School. It was then noticed that at St. Paul's the steam is taken from the boiler header through a 2\(\frac{1}{2}\)" pipe as compared with an 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" pipe here, and that at St. Paul's a "Darling-Whitlock Type K Storage Heater No. H-B-3" had been specified, which is a high-efficiency tank, which heats up quickly, and not to be compared with what was specified for this school.

The heating engineer has two suggestions for overcoming the present inefficiency of the water-heating service, viz

(a) To increase the size of the pipe line between the steam header of boilers and storage tank. This would also involve the increasing of the size of the pipes forming the coils, and putting in more coils, in the storage tank. In order to make this change it would be necessary to bore the tank to take larger intakes, for which work he says we should have to bring boiler makers here—all of which would involve heavy expense. Under present circumstances he does not advise this change.

(b) A second suggestion is that coils be placed in the firebox of each boiler and carried to the storage tank on the same principle as is done in kitchen ranges. He states that this method is frequently adopted, and that an abundance of hot water would result; also that the cost would be slight as compared to the first suggestion. The heating boilers are already bored to admit the necessary pipes to carry out this installation, and the entire cost would not exceed $50.00. He recommends that this method be adopted.

As the lack of hot water is a daily handicap in the operation of this school during a large part of the year, I would respectfully suggest that authority be given to overcome the difficulty; and that if the heating contractor's recommendation (b) meet with the Department's approval, that this method be tried out. This contractor offers a guarantee that the present lack of hot water can be remedied in this way.

The foregoing covers the complaints made by the Reverend Principal. The contractor, Mr. Dill, now has his carpenter foreman at work here making the corrections outlined, and has promised to leave him here until everything is made right.
In a previous letter I mentioned the lack of light in the main corridors in this building, and in looking over the specifications I noticed that in both the carpentry and glazing specifications it was required that all doors from the corridors should have glass panels. I intended asking the contractor to take out these doors and substitute others having glass panels as called for, but in looking at Sheet 5 of the Plans for this school I see that the doors from corridors are marked "B", which does not call for glass. This was obviously an inadvertence, for it was clearly the Architect's intention to provide borrowed light for all corridors. The result is that these passages are dark and gloomy.

The lighting specifications, Page 55, Clause 2, calls for a certificate of inspection from the local inspector of the Canadian Fire Underwriters' Association. Mr. Lett states that this requirement has been ignored and no inspection made.

I am informed that during the winter great difficulty was found in heating the Principal's residence, and that only by the excessive heating of the main building could sufficient heat reach the residence. This condition caused a largely augmented consumption of coal, else the residence was fairly too cold for comfort. Mr. Lett asks that a separate steam main be run direct from the boiler room to the residence. I have asked the heating contractor to give me an estimate of cost for this additional service, and when this is received I shall write the Department again on this subject.

In fairness to the general contractors, Adkinson & Dill, I may say that on the whole they have given the Department a very fair job. The main complaints have to do with the doors and windows, and these defects are now in process of being remedied. The masonry of walls and foundations is holding up well, and apart from the minor troubles mentioned, the contract generally has been well executed. I should have preferred an inexpensive pressed brick in the outside walls instead of the common brick used, but I am told the Department approved the sample of the common brick submitted. Also no dark brick were used for trim, as called for in the plans.

I am also told that Sheet 68a dealing with the standpipe system for fire protection was not included in the specifications furnished the contractor, and that this service has been installed as an extra, and it is not yet complete.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.
Dear Sir,

On my return from the semi-official opening of the Kamloops School last week, I stopped off at Lytton for a day and found very good work was being made with regard to the re-building of the chapel at St. George's School under the supervision of Mr. Gardner Smith. I learned, however, that no word had been received in connection with the building of the workshop and I would strongly recommend that this work should be taken in hand while Mr. Smith is at the School. Possibly the Church and the workshops could be completed about the same time.

I believe Mr. Lett sent you a tentative design of what is required—a frame building 35 ft. by 70 ft. of two stories and a basement. The basement is needed for storage machinery, etc., the first floor being for technical training, the second storey for a gymnasium for the boys in the summer to save the assembly room in the main building. To put on the top storey it would only require the walls to be run up about nine or ten feet higher and the extra cost would not be much greater than if the building only comprised the basement and the technical training room.

I think that the building might be constructed on day labour plan under Mr. Smith's supervision, as he would know just what size of timber should be used. I am of the opinion that the building should be on cement foundation with walls sheathed outside with shiplap and covered with rustic, inside walls being sheathed up with number one shiplap. Ample windows should be put in to give sufficient light in the manual training room. The roof could either be of shingles or heavy rubber roofing material, but that would depend entirely upon what is best suited to the climatic conditions at Lytton.

Your obedient servant,

The Rev. Mr. Lett showed me a letter received from the Department a few days ago authorizing the erection of a Utility Building, to be erected under my supervision, and not to exceed $7,000.00 in cost. I staked out the new building on Saturday, and today (Monday) the excavation was commenced. Mr. Lett has explained his requirements, and I am planning the building accordingly. The overall size will be 36' x 70', and will consist of a full-size basement, and two stories above. The top floor will be used entirely for a gymnasium, and the roof will be supported by 5 trusses, so as to leave the floor clear of posts. I shall give you a fuller description and plans of this building a little later. We shall have a good deal of material left over from the Chapel that is now in use for staging, scaffolding, runways, etc., all of which will work into the new Utility Building. Also we have lumber from the old Chapel which for various reasons we could not use again in the new Chapel, and this, too, will find a place in the Utility Building. We shall carry on the two new buildings simultaneously. For this latter building I should also have an accountable cheque for $2,000.00 sent promptly for the payment of labour. The Department cheques are deposited in the Ashcroft branch of the Bank of Montreal, and are drawn against by cheques signed jointly by Mr. Lett and myself. I thought this the proper procedure to adopt.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H. Gardner Smith.

Sir:

In previous correspondence reference has been made to the inefficient heating of the Principal's residence at this school. A few weeks ago Mr. Crombie, of Mortimer & Crombie, Plumbing & Heating Engineers, of Vancouver, was here on my invitation to give a tender for the heating of the new Chapel,—which work has been awarded to this firm.

While Mr. Crombie was here I discussed with him the problem of getting sufficient heat into the residence at the least expense. In order to determine the cause of the difficulty I got the school's engineer to make up a good fire in one of the boilers, and when 2 lbs of steam was registered it was noted that even in the residence the radiators were warming up. After a time, though, it was found that the residence radiators had cooled off, while those in the main building were still functioning. It was also noted that in the residence the steam mains were graded downward in the line of flow, and although provision had been made for dripping the condensate at the low points of the line, yet the steam had ceased circulating. Mr. Crombie states that these mains in the residence become "air-bound", and for that reason the steam soon ceases to pass through to the radiators. He recommends that "air eliminators" be installed in the steam mains in the residence, and feels sure that if this is done there should be no difficulty in heating the residence when there is a fair pressure of steam.

To install the air eliminators recommended, and to make one or two minor changes in the residence steam mains, will not cost more than $75.00 if done while the heating of the Chapel is being installed, and I recommend that this be done. While admittedly this change would not be so efficient as a direct line from the boiler header to the residence, the expense would be almost negligible in comparison, and I believe nearly all the cause for complaint could thus be overcome.

As the heating men have been notified to come on the 17th inst. to install the heating of the Chapel, I should like the Department's consent—if the proposal be approved—to the suggested means of correcting the residence heating.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Building Supervisor.

Sir:

With regard to the Utility Building authorized for this School, I enclose herewith pencil drawings of the three floor plans, and of the East Elevation.

The plans as shown are what the Reverend Principal requested, and it has been my aim to give him exactly what he asks for. You will note that the size of the building is 36' x 70', and comprises basement, ground and first floors. I have marked on the various rooms the purposes for which they are intended, which I think will be found sufficiently self-explanatory.

The basement floors and foundation walls are of concrete. To the latter is anchored a wall plate 3" x 6", and all outside studding is 2x6". The three rooms on the ground floor, and the Gymnasium on the first floor, are all reached by means of outside steps. This feature prevents any passing from room to room on these floors, and Mr. Lett considers this important.

The outside studding is being sheeted with shiplap, placed diagonally, over which comes a layer of building paper, and then the drop siding finish. The interior finish will be V-joint in the residence end of the basement, and in the gymnasium only. The other interior walls will not receive finish material. Double floors, with paper between, will be provided on ground and 1st floors.

You will note we are carrying up 8"x 8" posts on the outside walls to carry the trusses which will support the roof, the purpose being to avoid any inside posts in the gymnasium; and ample support is provided for carrying the floors.

Between the two bed rooms of basement is a wash-room, in which we are installing a wash basin and toilet. We have carried water from the school water main in pipes salvaged from the old school, and have connected the waste to a small septic tank, the overflow from which we have directed to a rock-pit built for the purpose. The Utility Building is placed about 110 ft. north of the boiler room of the main school.

I think from the rough drawings and preceding comments you will have a very fair idea of the kind of building we are erecting. But there is one important point which I now wish to bring to the attention of the Department. I refer to the heating of this Utility Building. You will observe I have indicated the rooms that should have heat supplied during cold weather. On the drawings I have
marked a chimney, but all the rooms which require heat could not be served from one chimney, although the most necessary ones could be heated by stoves connected to the said chimney.

The heating contractor (Mortimer & Crombie, Vancouver) are now installing steam heat in the Chapel, and Mr. Crombie has made a proposition for heating the Utility Building too. Briefly, the scheme is to convey steam from the boiler room through a 2" line, underground to the Utility Building, and to return the condensate to the boilers by means of an automatic electric pump. It would not be the intention to heat the rooms of the new building to the class-room temperatures, and with the exception of the two bed-rooms and wash-room, the other rooms would only require to be made comfortably warm for working in, which means just a little more than taking off the chill, in cold weather. We have almost enough radiators and pipes left over from the old school and chapel for this job, which Mr. Crombie has taken into consideration in quoting a price of $600.00 for the steam heating of those rooms in the Utility Building which I have indicated by the words "To be heated". I think his price is very moderate, and it is only owing to fortuitous circumstances that he is able to give us this low figure. Against this cost we would have the saving of the outlay in chimney (not yet built, only the footing) the stoves, and extra fuel and attendance. Also we should be avoiding a fire hazard.

Mr. Crombie will give a written guarantee that the service he proposes to install will perform satisfactorily, and will give a 12 months' guarantee against defects in labour and materials. It would be a decided advantage to have this new building connected up to the general heating plant of the school, and the heating contractors advise that by so doing we would not be overtaxing the existing heating facilities.

Should the Department sanction carrying steam heat to the Utility Building, the $600.00 that it would cost would run us over the $7000.00 which we were asked not to exceed—perhaps about $500.00 over—and for this reason particularly I am unwilling to take any action in the matter without first obtaining the Department's approval with respect to the excess cost.

Awaiting the favour of an early reply to this heating proposal,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

Building Supervisor.

sir:

With respect to the defects which had developed in this building, I called on the contractors, Adkison & Dill, Ltd., of Vancouver, and notified them to attend to the remedying of same. He showed me a document signed by all the carpenters who worked on the job, acknowledging the extra money the firm had been ordered to pay, and which had been made retroactive.

In reply to the contractors' representations, I told them that the necessary adjustments in connection with the school building must first be done, not as a condition precedent, but under their 12 months' guarantee. I also told them that the matter was entirely out of my province, and that beyond simply passing their request on, I could not presume to take any action in a matter about which the Department had not asked for my opinion or advice.

The Secretary,

OTTAWA.

Re- St. George's Indian School.

Sir:

With reference to the enclosed Voucher for $263.00, in favour of Messrs Mortimer & Crombie, Plumbing & Heating Engineers, of Vancouver, I would say that on the 8th instant fires were lighted in both the heating boilers in order to test out the changes made in the heating services of the School, as well as the testing of the heating of the Chapel.

The radiators in the Residence heated well, even before any steam registered on the steam gauges of the boilers, and they remained hot throughout the test which lasted most of the day. Mr. Lett was delighted with the result, and states that for the first time since the school was built, the residence radiators became really hot. I think we may say the cause for complaint in this regard has been overcome.

The coils placed in the heating boilers proved most efficient in heating the water in the H.W. storage tank. The water became hot in a surprisingly short time, and there is no question whatever as to the abundance of hot water which will be available whenever the heating boilers are in operation. The coils are large and sturdy, and are so placed at the rear end of the firebox of each boiler that the heat and flames come in direct contact with the coils, thus insuring maximum heating efficiency. We found it necessary to replace the firebrick baffle walls which mark the end of the fireboxes, and which serve to deflect the heat and smoke to the flues, as these walls were entirely gone. There will be an additional charge for this work, which I shall send later. This expense of renewing the firebrick baffle walls should not recur in the future, as the coils are placed where they will act as a screen to protect the baffle walls from damage. The charge of $99.50 for the coils includes, also, the alteration of the connection of the jacket heater to the H.W. storage tank so as to get better circulation and quicker results from this auxiliary service, which was very unsatisfactory before.
The steam heating of the Chapel proved fully satisfactory, the radiators there becoming hot simultaneously with those in the school. The radiators in the basement of the Chapel also heated well, though not quite so quickly as those in the Chapel above. The extended steam mains are properly proportioned, dripped at low points and bends, and provided with air eliminators at the extreme ends. I may confidently predict that there will be no lack of heat in the Chapel when the boilers are sufficiently fired. Dunham traps and valves have been used in the new installation.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant

REPORT ON UTILITY BUILDING, ST. GEORGE'S SCHOOL.

Sir:

The work of construction of the new Utility Building is making good progress, and today a start was made in shingling the roof.

From the blue print I sent the Department showing the floor plans and elevation, you will know just the type of building we are erecting. It will be quite devoid of ornamentation and frills, and perhaps severely plain, but will give the school the added room and facilities asked for by the Reverend Principal.

I was glad to receive the Department's approval of the proposal to carry steam heat into this building from the school heating plant, for as this is a frame structure there was the suggestion of fire hazard in heating with stoves. Mr. Crombie, of Mortimer & Crombie, is an unusually conscientious and efficient man in his profession; and from his letter (which I enclose) you will see that he has been very careful to make quite sure that the added load would not overtax the capacity of the boilers. I got back the complete plans of the school from Askison & Dill, and loaned the heating sheets and the specifications to Mr. Crombie so that he might make a careful check-up on the existing radiation, and boiler capacity. As the Utility Building occupies a site somewhat lower than that of the school, provision will be made to return the condensate by an automatic electric pump with sufficient horse-power to cause the 3 K.W. lighting engine to start up and take the load, thus avoiding the danger of exhausting the lighting batteries.

As this district runs a close second to S.W. Alberta in strong winds, we have taken pains to insure the strength and rigidity of the Utility Building. The outside walls are of "H" studding, and all the wall sheeting, as well as the sub-floors, has been put on diagonally. This has added nearly 50% to the labour-cost of sheeting the walls, but the result justifies it. The siding will, of course, be placed horizontally, and building paper placed between the shiplap and siding.

Four sturdy roof trusses have been erected so as to carry the roof without interior posts on the top floor (gymnasium) and ample strength has been provided in beams and posts to carry the ground and first floors, as shown in the blue print.

The plumbing in this building will consist of a toilet and wash basin in the wash-room between the two bed-rooms shown in the basement, and a drinking fountain built into a recess in the wall of the Gymnasium. Provision will be made for easy emptying of all water
pipes in the event of the building ever being unoccupied or unheated in cold weather. We have built a septic tank for this building, as its situation is too low for connection to the school sewage system.

I have completed arrangements for the painting, electric wiring and heating of the Utility Building, all of which should be performed during the next two or three weeks, and the building should be entirely completed, and my men gone, previous to the re-opening of the school on the 16th of August. Practically all the materials needed for the work are now on the ground.

As previously mentioned, the accountable cheques sent me have been deposited in the Ashcroft branch of the Bank of Montreal, to the credit of "St. George's I.R.S. Bldg. A/c", and have been drawn against, for labour only, by cheques signed jointly by Rev. Mr. Lett and myself. My accounts are all in perfect order, and entered up to date. The sum of the cheques issued agrees exactly with the sum of the time-sheets, as of course they should. Mr. Kay, who has worked with me from the start, and who is my right-hand man, is quite capable of carrying the work through to completion, including the keeping of the men's time. I mention this in case the Department might wish to transfer me to Gleichen in the near future, in which event I would suggest that Mr. Graham, the Indian Agent here, append his signature to the labour-cheques in my stead. Should the Department wish to recall me, I could make all necessary arrangements for the completion of the work on just a few days' notice.

The Utility Building is running close to estimates, and is likely to cost slightly less than the sum authorized. The cost to the 20th instant may be summarized thus:

Sir:

With regard to the enclosed Voucher for $819.23, in favour of Messrs Mortimer & Crombie, heating contractors, of Vancouver, B.C. I wish to explain the last item of $72.00.

In order to overcome the total lack of hot water in St. George's School the Department authorized the placing of coils in each of the heating boilers, which has been done, with the result that when the heating boilers are in operation there is an abundance of hot water. It was found, however, that the fire-deflecting walls at the rear of the firebox in each boiler had become disintegrated and broken down, which condition should not be allowed to continue. Also, we were to place the coils directly in front of these walls, and it would have been extremely difficult to replace said walls after the coils were installed, as they now form a protective screen in front of them. I enclose a circular illustrative of the boilers in use, and giving a sectional view showing the baffle walls which we have had to replace.

The firebricks and fireclay for the new baffle walls had to be shipped in from Vancouver by local freight, and 200 firebricks, and a sack of fireclay, were used. The cost or labour and materials for this repair work make up the charge of $72.00 shown.

I am not certain whether or not I am doing right in including this charge in this Voucher; perhaps it should be assumed by the school authorities. However, this can be left to the discretion of the Department.

I have the honour to be, sir,

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Dear Mr. Graham,

Re our Lighting Plant I beg to make the following report:

This plant has never given the service that it should have given for the type of engine installed. When first occupying the school the engines would not switch off and as a result continued to run on the batteries. I have been obliged many times to get up in the night to switch them off otherwise the strain on the batteries would be enormous. The batteries also had a leaky cell which caused rapid discharge, and I reported to the company shortly after moving into the school. We have been obliged to replace three sets of valves in the large unit. This the company claims due to over heating on account of poor circulation the pipes having become blocked with alkali in the water. We have detached the pipes and cleaned out the water system three times since installation, I also had to replace one head on the large unit due to a crack.

The repairs on the plant to date has cost the school £133.36 with a bill now outstanding of £40.00 and a list of repairs just submitted by the engineer which will run into another £50.00. These repairs have all been put onto the large unit, the 3 K.W. engine has not given us any trouble at all, and is now working perfectly while we are unable at present to get any more than 35 amps out of the 6 K.W. unit, which is only about half of its generating power.

The batteries at the present time are in very bad shape so much so that extra charging has to be done to keep any charge in them. This condition of the batteries is not due to over load in lighting or to neglect in any way, but due to defective engines and also to the leaky cell.

I have been constantly reporting the grief we have had to the company principally through Commissioner Ditchburn. My engineer has been constantly complaining and has been obliged to be on duty night and day in order to give light at all.

Last Nov. and Dec. we burned approximately £250.00 worth of gas and oil due to valve trouble, and extra running in recharging batteries. The plant has during the year run us into an enormous overhead expense all of which seems due to a defective plant. The Lister Co. will not hear of this yet I have seen that the plant has had the very best care, and personally cannot account for the grief we have been having. Since the little unit has given good service I cannot see why the large should not have done the same, were it not that something is wrong.

In conclusion I might say that I cannot see that the school or the Dept. should have to stand the expense of a new set of batteries.
which is now evident. The last visit made to the school by a representative I approached him concerning the condition of the batteries, and he had the company replace the cracked cell, and also stated that he would see what could be done with the battery people regarding the installation of a new set. I have not had any more from him re his suggestion and am therefore submitting the condition to you, with a view of having the Dept. take the matter with the company.

The school is not responsible for the present condition of the batteries especially since we have done our best to keep the engines in good running order, the expense of which as you see has been enormous.

Since the softener was installed we have used the softened water entirely and in one month after the circulation had been cleaned out and new valves put in we again had the same trouble develop. We cannot go on spending on the plant in such a way without results. The whole trouble is centred in the large unit and this and the batteries should be replaced by the firm.

You have personally been here and have witnessed the grief we have endured with the plant.

I shall be glad to give you any further information in my power in order that we shall not be obliged to enter upon the long winter evenings with a broken down lighting system.

Yours Very obediently

Principal

Sir:

Mrs. Lett, wife of the Rev. Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, has just reported to me the very unsatisfactory state of affairs at the school in connection with both the heating and the lighting systems.

The Rev. Principal is at the present moment in the Kamloops Hospital, having undergone a serious operation, and thus the reason for my having to write you on the subject.

In regard to the heating plant, it is impossible to heat the chapel and utility building, which were added this summer, by Mr. Gardiner Smith, at all. Not one atom of steam will go through; it just condenses and freezes up, and they do not appear to have left any places to drain these pipes.

The engineer is working night and day, and half his time is taken up thawing out pipes and fixing others as they burst from being frozen. The radiators and piping throughout the building appear to be leaking more or less. There is little or no heat going through to the residence, which is practically uninhabitable, although the temperature is only 40° above zero outside.

The engineer reports that he very much doubts whether the electric light system will keep going until Christmas. This matter I reported to you sometime ago, and you replied on October 13, 1929, that you would take it up with the agents and that they were sending a man to put things right, but the system seems to be no better.

I would like to recommend that these firms be required to send men to put things right, now being the time for them to be on the ground to see that the plants are not working properly.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Re- St. George's Indian School, Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with copy of a letter from the Indian Agent at Lytton, B.C.

It is noted from Mr. Graham's letter that trouble is being experienced in getting heat into the Chapel and Utility Building, and that the Residence is not being sufficiently heated. On receiving this information I at once wired the heating contractors in Vancouver, a copy of which message I enclose, and I delayed replying to your letter pending a reply to my wire. No reply has yet come, so I do not know if the conditions complained of still exist.

Regarding the heating of the Chapel, this was tested out before I left, and the radiators heated there simultaneously with those in the main school. The work was installed in conformity with the best practice in the trade, the lines being properly graded, vented, provided with air eliminators, and with a wet return line underground to join the wet return in the main building. Abundant radiation was placed in the Chapel.

The Utility Building was not provided with a great deal of radiation, as some parts of that building were not intended to be heated, and we did not want to put too much added load on the boilers, but radiators were put where asked for. The condensate from this building is returned to the boilers by an automatic force-pump system.

The Residence heating was found to be airbound, and by installing air eliminators in the Residence basement we overcame that trouble, and the radiators throughout the residence heated well, under the test we gave it, and Mr. Lett remarked that it was the first time those rads had ever heated properly since the school was built.

My own impression is that the boilers have not been steadily and sufficiently fired, and a proper head of steam obtained. It is a large institution, and during extreme cold the boilers should have day and night attention and a good head of steam maintained. This means burning lots of coal, but that cannot be avoided. The engineer (assuming he is still the same) is a diminutive man, both semi-deaf and crippled, and I can understand his being unable to keep up steam during rigorous weather, unless given adequate assistance.
A little dribble of steam is not enough in cold weather, and just invites freezing troubles.

Before leaving Lytton I placed on the Principal's desk a 12 months' guarantee from the heating contractors, in which they agreed to return to the school in the event of anything going wrong with their work, and make any necessary adjustments or repairs, for a period of one year, without expense to the Department. This heating firm (Mortimer & Crombie, of Vancouver) have an excellent reputation, and would undoubtedly observe the terms of their guarantee, if notified of the need for same.

Not having any information later than Mr. Graham's letter of Dec. 12th, I have no way of knowing how conditions now are at the school at Lytton, but expect to hear from the heating contractors in answer to my wire at any time; and should further information come I will forward it to you. Should the Department wish me to do so, I will take a few days off from my work here, and go to Lytton and see for myself what the troubles are, and take the necessary steps to have them remedied under the twelve months' guarantee, should mechanical troubles actually exist.

With regard to the lighting plant at St. George's School, it was giving trouble last summer, and the lights gave out several times. I think the plant suffered from too much tampering with by local help in the endeavor to fix things they did not understand.

Dear Mr. Gardner-Smith,

Yours to hand. It is true the heating in the Chapel, Utility Building, and Residence has not been satisfactory during the cold snap. There was on the other hand an unnecessary cry made during my period in the Hospital. That is they made the situation somewhat exaggerated yet I do not think it will ever be what it ought to be until a separate unit is put in for the Chapel and Utility Building or a Vacuum system is installed; this latter is out of the question as we have not sufficient power to handle the pump. If a vacuum system were feasible it would no doubt solve the problem as it would increase the efficiency of the boilers and insure even distribution throughout, since this cannot be done it seems the plan would be to install a separate boiler in the utility building for heating both buildings.

There are two burst radiators in the Chapel and the heating in the Utility building has never functioned. We have been obliged to forget it entirely and installed a stove in the Manual Training room, the Gym has not been used for about one month and we cannot hope to use it until the weather relieves. We have also not had a service in the Chapel since Christmas Day. It would take approximately 2½ to 3 tons of coal a day to keep it heated sufficiently for use and the school building would be so overheated as to be very uncomfortable and involve a great waste of fuel which we cannot afford. I believe with a separate unit we would save considerable expense in heating.

The trouble seems to be in the fact that the condensate is to slow in returning during the cold weather and is also so great that the pipes cannot handle it so that it freezes in the traps and turns or elbows.

Mr. Crombie was here and said nothing could be done other than install a vacuum pump for which as I have stated we have not sufficient power for operation.

The residence during the snap which has been rather prolonged, has not been at all comfortable the same trouble existing, evidently the pipes being unable to handle the condensate. During the milder weather there seems to be a much better circulation and no trouble to keep heat in the radiators in this wing. The central portion of the building is always comfortable and would not take much fuel to keep so but when the boilers have to be forced to get heat in the residence the middle gets so warm that windows have to be thrown open and a waste follows.

I trust the above will give you an insight into the situation as I have already stated something will have to be done before we enter upon another winter.

Personally I am picking up slowly but not as brisk as I might be.
Copper Mountain, B.C.

Mr. E. Gardiner Smith
Glacier, Alta.

Dear Sir:

We have delayed replying to yours of Dec. 17th for a couple of days in order to make some inquiries here to determine as far as possible just what might be the difficulty with your Heating Plant.

We understand that the original plant at your Institution was installed by Murray Bros, Vancouver, B.C. some two years ago, and since that time some additions have been added, which additions were tacked onto the original Heating System.

We believe that this System was originally designed for a Webster or Dunham Vapor job, that is all returns to the boiler being made by gravity. The choice of this Gravity System may possibly have been made owing to the fact that the initial cost of such System is slightly lower than a Vacuum System, the cost of which would, of course have to include a Vacuum Pump.

We have found that a Heating System running over a comparatively large horizontal area, such as yours possibly covers, is more satisfactory when handled by a Vacuum Pump which makes for the pulling of a speedy and positive circulation through the System. On heating systems in high buildings covering a comparatively small horizontal area the problem of getting free circulation back to the boiler is apt to be much less difficult.

Without seeing your plant it is of course impossible for our Engineers to express anything like an intelligent opinion as to what might be done to remedy the situation, and even if we were to make an inspection of the plant, it is just possible there may be certain limitations beyond which it would be impossible to go toward a remedy owing to your location. For example, if the condition could be corrected by the installation of a Vacuum Pump the question of motive power would have to be considered as it is just possible you have no electric current available there outside of your own local plant, and any electric driven Vacuum Pump would possibly require a 2 or 3 HP Motor, which your electric plant might or might not have capacity to drive. Any attempt to operate a Steam Driven Vacuum Pump from your low pressure boilers would not be practical.
However, as stated above, it is nearly impossible to discuss your difficulty intelligently without seeing your plant, and for the purpose of doing this we would be willing to send our Engineer from Vancouver to go into the matter fully with you on condition that you pay the expense of his trip. We would, of course, make no charge for his time or services outside of his travelling expenses.

If you are satisfied in your own mind that a Vacuum Pump could be installed, that would solve your difficulty, and in the event of our Vacuum Pump being used on the job there would be no charge of any kind for our Engineer to make an inspection, that is this trip would be made at our own expense.

If a Vacuum Pump cannot be installed the only thing that we could suggest would be to have some practical Heating Contractor go into the plant and eliminate as far as possible any lifts in the pipe lines, thereby giving free circulation back to the boilers by gravity.

We shall be very glad to hear from you at any time and to give you any information regarding any point that can be covered by mail.

Yours very truly

Re- St. Georges Indian School, Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Orr:

With further reference to the heating troubles at St. George's School, I enclose herewith copies of further correspondence on the subject from the Reverend Principal, Mr. Lett, which is self-explanatory; and Dunham's, & Mortimer & Crombie's suggestions.

When in Calgary today I had a conference with Mr. Alex Walker, Dunham Co.'s Engineer for Alberta and Eastern B.C., and the situation was reviewed carefully. I had with me the plans of the buildings, and the recent correspondence relating to the heating troubles, and the reports of Mr. Crombie, and Dunham's Vancouver Engineer's recommendations.

Mr. Walker states he is unable to make any very definite recommendation without first checking up the entire job including the capacity of the heating boilers themselves. He says heating boilers are usually over-rated regarding the amount of load they can carry in sub-zero weather. He further states it is probable in very cold weather there is more condensate than can be returned to the boilers with sufficient rapidity over the far-spread sluggish horizontal lines without other help than exists at present. In other words, he thinks the circulation of steam is retarded owing to the system being overloaded with condensate.

To relieve the excess of condensate he makes the tentative suggestion that the wet return from the Chapel be diverted to the Utility Building, towards which there is an excellent fall in grade, and from the Utility Building the condensate could be delivered back to the heating boilers of the School by means of the force pump now installed in the basement of the Utility Building. This change would relieve the wet return of the school of any added load. In this connection the capacity of the automatic force pump in the Utility Building would be first tested.

Regarding the insufficiency of heat in the Residence, Mr. Walker suggests carrying an additional steam main into the Residence from the blind end of a steam main in the school basement almost adjoining the Residence, thus making a loop with the other main which is now furnishing heat to the Residence. The addition of air eliminators which we made last summer relieved the air-bound condition then existing, but apparently additional steam circulation is needed for extremely cold weather. I recall Mr. Crombie said this would give added heat, but he did not then think it necessary, as all the residence radiators heated splendidly at that time.
It is only too apparent that an unfortunate condition exists in connection with the heating service at St. George's School, and to me, personally, it is a matter of deep concern. I shall be only too glad to assist in any way I can to give those good people relief, and to bring their heating service to a proper condition of efficiency.

Mr. Walker has kindly consented to accompany me to Lytton, if so desired by the Department, and to check up every feature of the existing system, and give us the benefit of his knowledge and technical experience in outlining what should be done to correct the troubles which may be found in the heating service as it now stands. I could get away from my work here for a few days without detriment, and would arrange with Mr. Gooderham to visit the job daily in my absence. I should also wire Mr. Crombie, the heating contractor who did the heating work, to meet us at Lytton, and we should then be in a position to make an intelligent recommendation to the Department as to the necessary procedure to follow, by checking up the job itself, under mid-winter conditions as they now exist.

I realize it is possible the Department may have made other arrangements already for dealing with the heating troubles referred to, but I am offering the foregoing suggestion regarding a visit to the St. George's School in case no action is being taken already, and subject, of course, to the Department's wish that I co-operate in solving this difficulty. Mr. Walker would make no charge other than his actual out-of-pocket expenses; and in giving attention to our problem he would be acting in unison with Dunham's Vancouver branch.

Should the Department decide to send Mr. Walker and me to Lytton (or Mr. Walker alone) it would be well to do so at once so that the conditions may be observed as they exist now rather than when warmer weather returns. By wiring a reply we could leave at a day's notice after receiving the wire.

The foregoing suggestions are respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

We were of the opinion that we had cleared up satisfactorily the mechanical trouble as far as the plants were concerned in showing the operator the exact clearance to be kept between the valves, and telling him plainly that he was to leave the valves alone, but however, we received a letter from the School on April 9th, stating that the exhaust valves on both of the engines were again in need of resetting as both were losing compression; this applying to the small plant as well as the large one. We immediately sent our electrician to investigate this and found that their statement was absolutely not correct. The small plant again ran perfectly and there was nothing wrong with the valves, and the large plant had one exhaust valve which was barely closing due to the fact that Mr. Lepine had again ground it in a day or so after our visit, reducing the clearance between the valve stem and the tappet to the extent that the valve would barely close and the engine was losing compression and would have resulted in the burning off of the valve within a few days. He also argued that even though the valves on the small plant were not leaking it would only be a day or so before they would be and to prove to him that his contention was not correct Mr. Waters replaced the exhaust valve in the small plant as well as the one in the large plant with new ones, and brought these valves to Vancouver as evidence that there is absolutely nothing wrong with them. These same valves I have forwarded to Mr. Bitchburn at Victoria for his inspection.

As stated in your letter, we are not having this trouble at the other schools and I quite conscientiously believe that this trouble is caused by the tampering and tinkering around the plants by the operator instead of leaving them alone, and you will have such conditions as long as he is on the job as I cannot see any relief if the plants are not allowed to operate normally. Last fall, he ordered gears, bushings, etc. for this engine, stating that these parts were worn out and causing trouble. Dear Sir:

Further to our letter of March 26th, I informed you that I was leaving that night for Lytton, which I did, taking Mr. Waters, our electrician, with me to enable us to make a thorough check-up on the plants, and remedy as far as possible any troubles that we might find. Mr. Lett, and the operator, Mr. Lepine, were both attendant when we arrived, and a very rigid inspection was made of both plants. We beg to submit the following report:

Small Plant No. 1a

This plant was in very good condition, and ran nicely, and when put on full load, without making any adjustments, carried the full rated output without hesitation. The operator has reported that this plant was giving serious trouble with the valve, but in conversation with him he satisfied me that the trouble is due to the fact that he has not given the proper valve clearance between the tappet and the valve, thereby resulting in the burning off of the valve. This engine is sound and in good shape.

Large Plant No. 2a

This engine was started up, and would not carry over two-thirds of its load, and on examination the trouble proved to be in improper timing of the ignition. When this was altered, it pulled its full load without trouble. This engine is quite noisy due to the natural wear, as it has been doing the most of the work of lighting in addition to operating the lumber machinery. It is not at a dangerous stage, however, and will give plenty of service yet before proving troublesome, outside of the noise which is not detrimental to the operation of the plant.

Both plants were then started up, and they carried their full rated load for a short period, without any difficulty, proving to me that as far as the plants are concerned, there is not much actual trouble with their operation from a mechanical standpoint.

The automatic features, however, cannot function as completely as they should, owing to the fact that the storage battery is completely done, and should be replaced immediately, and successful operation of the plants will not be achieved until such time as this storage battery is replaced.

School Lighting Load.

I asked Mr. Lett to give me the normal lighting load and this load runs approximately 65 Amps. The total load, as might be often called for, is 92 Amps., which is 15% more than...
the full capacity of the plants. This, therefore, means that their ordinary lighting load is practically the full capacity of the plants, and as the lighting load comes on quickly the small plant runs for short time only. The large plant then cuts in to take over the load, and the small plant eventually comes in to assist it. You can, therefore, see that the large plant has had most of the work to do. A lighting plant should not be operated continuously at its full load if long life is to be expected. A margin between its normal working load and its full load should be left, which is not the case with the large unit which is now functioning.

Suggested Improvements.

After carefully considering what is necessary to give the most satisfactory installation for the school under the present working conditions, I would strongly suggest the installation of a larger unit to replace the small one, which is now working automatically with the other large one, and when the necessary time comes replace the engine on the existing large plant.

Our new unit, replacing the small one, would be a 7½ K.W., and by replacing the engine on the present large plant, the capacity would be increased from 6 K.W. to 7½ K.W., which would then give a combined output of 15 K.W., which will put them past the point of power shortage for a long time to come. If I were asked to specify the type of installation suitable for this school, under the present load conditions, I would quote on two 7½ K.W. Lister Prinston Automatic Units, working together.

Reasons for this Change.

If the 7½ K.W. Plant were installed, replacing the small 3 K.W. plant, the operation would be as follows:

When the load comes on and starts this No. 1 plant, it will continue to operate and have sufficient capacity to carry practically full load continuously, and the load could be shifted to the other plant giving both equal running periods, thereby equalizing the wear. As it now stands the large plant takes the majority of the running.

The No. 2 plant would take care of the laundry drive as at present, and a further safeguard could be had by arranging the drive so that the laundry could be operated from either plant. However, this is not of great importance as far as the present question is concerned.

With the above method of operation, much longer life would result from both units, and there would be no chance of overloading either of the plants.

Battery Replacement.

We would be very glad to quote on a new battery to replace the present one, but before doing so would like to clear up one point, namely, the size of battery required.

If the plants are to remain as they are, I would recommend the use of the same size battery, namely, 100 Amp. Hour, but if you contemplated replacing the present small unit with
a larger one at this time or at a later date, I would recommend supplying a larger battery of 120 Amp. Hour capacity.

The price of a 110 volt, Globelite, 108 Amp. Hour Battery would be $535.00 laid down at Lytton, and the price of a 110 volt, 120 Amp. Hour Battery $550.00, freight paid to Lytton.

Delivery on these batteries can be made in a very short time, and we could have either one of them delivered to Lytton in approximately two weeks.

Summarizing this letter, my recommendations are as follows:

1. Immediate replacement of the Storage Battery.
2. Replacement of the 5 K.W. Unit by a 7½ K.W. Unit.
3. Eventually replacing the engines on the present large plant, restoring it to new condition with an increased capacity from 6 to 7½ K.W.

In the event of your replacing the small unit with a larger one, I would advise you that we are prepared to take this small unit in as an allowance on the purchase price of the larger unit, and if you would like me to go into detail on the necessary changes to be made and give you a quotation on it, I would be very glad to do so on receipt of word from you.

Thanking you, and assuring you that we will do all that we can to keep things running satisfactorily, I am,

Yours respectfully,

R.A. LISTER & CO. (CANADA) LTD.

Sir:-

Re Lytton Indian Residential School Lighting Plant.

In accordance with the request contained in your letter of May 22nd., I visited the Lytton Indian Residential School and carried out an examination with reference to the operation of the lighting system, which had been reported to be out of order, and in this connection would report to you as follows:

DESCRIPTION OF LIGHTING PLANT

Power is supplied to the Lytton Indian Residential School for lighting purposes at 110 volts D.C., and is obtained by means of 2 D.C. generators having a capacity of 3 and 6 Kilowatts respectively.

These generators require to be operated at 550 R.P.M., and are entirely automatic in their operation.

In the case of the 3 Kw. generator, it is driven by a 6 H.P. gasoline engine, and the 6 Kw. generator is operated by a 12 H.P. gasoline engine.

The automatic features of the plant are that when the load is below 3 Kilowatts the 3 Kw. unit only operates; but when the load increases above 3 Kilowatts and below 6 Kilowatts the 6 Kw. unit cuts in and the 3 Kw. unit cuts out. If the load is still further

C. E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service,
Vancouver, B. C.
load is still further increased above 6 kilowatts, then the 3 kw. unit again cuts in to assist the 6 kw. unit in carrying the load.

The plant is of the standard type, many of which are in use throughout Canada giving entire satisfaction.

REPORT OF DEFECTS IN PLANT

The principal of the Lytton Indian Residential School at the time of my arrival stated that while the 3 kw. unit gave satisfaction, the 6 kw. unit was entirely unsatisfactory and had never operated properly since the time it was installed.

He stated that while this unit would operate with a certain amount of satisfaction on a light load (not above 30 amps.), when the full load (55 amps.) was placed on it, the speed of the gasoline engine was reduced so much that the load could not be carried and the engine continually stalled.

He also stated that the exhaust valves in this engine continually burnt out and required to be replaced, and that the bearings were loose and that the cam shaft and other parts showed undue wear.

CONDITION OF PLANT AT TIME OF INSPECTION

Upon testing this unit immediately upon arrival, I found the condition of this machine as stated by the principal to be substantially correct, that is to say, while the engine would carry a light load, as soon as a load of 35 or 40 amps. was placed upon it the speed of the engine was reduced from 550 r.p.m. (its rated speed) to as low as 360 r.p.m.
as low as 360 R.P.M., and that if this load was increased the engine stopped altogether.

After repeated tests showed that this unit was not functioning properly, the fly-wheel was removed and the engine was partially dismantled, when the following defects were found:

The clearance between the tappet rods and the tappets on the exhaust valves was far too great.

The spacing of the timing gears in front of the engine, i.e., between the main shaft and the cam shaft, was wrong, due to the fact that either when the engine was assembled or at some other time an inexperienced mechanic had changed the idler gear without making sure that when the new one was put in the relation between the cam shaft gear and the main shaft was correct. The amount these gears were out was 3 teeth.

The engine was then re-assembled and a test run on same. It was now found that while the engine could be brought up to speed (550 R.P.M.) on medium load, it failed to hold this speed at full load, and that no adjustment of the generator brushes or timing gear would remedy this condition.

After a still further examination, it was found that the gas ports on the carburettor situated between the carburettor and the intake manifold were far too small, that is to say that when the machine was running on a light load the gas ports would be partly open and sufficient mixture would pass through into the cylinders to allow the engine to operate, but when full load came on this engine, while the operation...
engine, while the operation of the governor was satisfactory and the governor opened the ports to the full extent, these ports were too small to allow a sufficient amount of mixture to pass into the cylinders to maintain the engine speed.

I therefore instructed the operator to increase the size of these ports by about 40%, which he did by filing and cutting them larger.

Upon re-assembling the carburettor with the ports enlarged, the operation of the plant was entirely satisfactory. The engine speed was easily raised to 600 R.P.M. and the engine carried an over-load of 20% with no signs of faltering. (The rated capacity of this plant is 55 amps., and after adjustments were made the plant carried 65 amps. for a long period with no sign of heating or failure).

A few minor adjustments were then carried out, and the position of the brushes on the generator was corrected, owing to the fact that they had either slipped or had been moved by the operator in his previous endeavours to improve the condition of the plant.

After this had been done the two plants were given tests as one unit, that is to say, the 3 Kw. unit was operated alone; then the 6 Kw. unit was allowed to cut in and the 3 Kw. unit to drop out; then when the load increased above the capacity of this unit the 3 Kw. unit was allowed to come in and assist the 6 Kw. unit. The result was that the plant carried the total load (82.5 amps.) easily with no sign of the engine speed being reduced or any part of
duced or any part of the machinery overheating.

This being the case, it would obviously appear that the whole trouble in the operation of this plant lay in the fact that the gas ports in the carburettor were too small, thereby preventing the engine getting sufficient fuel at high speed for heavy load.

PRESENT GENERAL CONDITION OF PLANT

The general condition of the plant, seeing that it has been in operation for two years, even though this operation has not been entirely satisfactory, is good.

There are certain features in its installation which cannot be described as being first-class and should be altered.

These are as follows:

1) There are too many sharp bends on the exhaust pipe between the engine and the mufflers.

2) These mufflers are situated inside the engine room and are noisy, and are not, in my opinion, the best type for a plant of this size. A concrete exhaust box situated below ground outside, properly equipped with a drain and outlet, would be far superior.

3) The operation of the laundry machinery is carried out by the 12 H.P. engine by means of a heavy belt driving the laundry operating shaft situated overhead and to one side.

The operation of this belt places heavy side-pull on the main bearings of the engine, and as the engine requires to be operated at full speed when driving this machinery, it is only natural to expect the bearings to wear unequally.

(An engine driving a
(An engine driving a lighting plant in which a large institution is entirely dependent for light should not, in my opinion, be used for any other purpose. A separate engine should have been installed to operate the laundry, or it should have been operated by steam).

On days during which the 12 H.P. engine is used to operate the laundry machinery, which usually runs for 8½ hours continuously, the operator reports that the 6 Kw. generator has a tendency to become overheated, which may possibly be caused by an open circuit in one of the coils and which can no doubt be easily adjusted.

It would, however, be advisable to install a different type of coupling between the engine and the generator so that on days during which the engine is being used for operating the laundry machinery only, this coupling can be disconnected and the generator not operated.

Under present conditions, the engine being direct connected to the generator, whenever the engine is in operation the generator is in operation too, and when no lighting load is on, is delivering current to charge the batteries.

Unless this charging of the batteries is closely watched, they can very easily become overcharged and rapidly destroyed.

4) The battery set (52 cells), which is supplied to carry small loads and to start the engines, is entirely destroyed and must be replaced immediately.

When this battery is replaced, cells with larger containers should be installed so as to allow more liquid to
allow more liquid to surround the plates.

The destruction of this battery appears to have been caused chiefly through over-charging, probably due to the lack of experience of the previous operators and the fact that the battery was not cut out of the circuit while the laundry machinery was being operated.

5) The 12 H.P. engine is slightly noisy in operation and shows certain signs of wear, which is only natural after two years use. The following parts should be shortly replaced:

- 2 main bearings,
- wrist pins,
- pistons and piston rings,
- gaskets,
- intake manifold.

The plant should also be given a general overhaul by experienced men under the supervision of this office to ensure that it is properly carried out.

COST

The cost of the above repairs, together with the cost of overhauling the plant and changing the exhaust piping as outlined in this report, would amount to approximately $395.00. (See Appendix A)

This amount does not include the cost of a new battery set.

REMARKS

If the above repairs are carried out, there is, in my opinion, no reason why the plant should not operate with entire satisfaction, with the exception that if the 12 H.P. engine is still to be used for operating the laundry as well as for supplying light
for supplying light, the department must be prepared to expend a certain amount on its maintenance each year.

The present operator appears to be a good man and has undoubtedly done his very best to operate this plant satisfactorily, and it was only due to the fact that the cause of the trouble was most unusual and very difficult to locate that he was unable to do so.

These plants should, in my opinion, be examined regularly by an engineer from this office, and if necessary overhauled and repaired semi-annually, and the cost of this examination and overhaul would undoubtedly be more than saved in the trouble and expense which would be prevented thereby, for the reason that the operator, in addition to looking after the lighting plant, is not an expert and has a great many other duties to perform around the school; and it is not likely that any operator will start in and overhaul a plant or do much work on it until such time as it begins to show that it is not functioning properly, when it is generally too late.

In the present case, it is well to point out that several spare parts had been ordered and purchased by the previous operator, for which I understand the department paid, which were not necessary and in addition have never been used or where used have been
where used have been installed incorrectly.

Your obedient servant,

E. H. Tredcroft,
Senior Assistant Engineer.

REPORT OF J. D. CALDWELL, Indian Agricultural Agent for 1930.

While at Lytton I visited the St. George's Indian Residential School farm. The Rev. Mr. Lett showed me over the school farm and farm buildings. Mr. Lett appears to be a capable and practical farmer and his crops were looking well. Mr. Lett is working hard to get his lighter land in Alfalfa and with the outlook for water very good this year, it looks as though he was going to be successful. The farm buildings were neat and clean inside, but were in need of paint, the paint on the old buildings having peeled off. There are also three new buildings that have not been painted, a machine shed, granary and engine house.

If the present cow herd is to be kept on this farm I should think that isolation quarters should be provided separate from the main building, at the present a portion of the main building being used for this purpose. This herd having contagious abortion, I would hardly think it safe to keep infected animals in the same stable with the other stock.
