Dear Sir:

Your esteemed letter of July 10th to hand re Lytton Indian School, with enclosed report on this plant by Mr. E. H. Tredcroft, of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service.

Dealing first with the portion of your letter, which is an excerpt from a letter received from Mr. Lett, dated May 21st, I note his remarks that he has found a defect in the switchboard which has been responsible for the batteries running down, etc.,......

The last time the writer visited Lytton, I arrived unexpectedly at the school, and, as pointed out in my previous report, found the large plant operating quite satisfactorily, driving the laundry. This plant was supposed to be entirely out of commission. Mr. Lett informed me that he had found the trouble -- namely, a small screw on the relay was holding the relay shut and causing the battery to run down. We went into it in detail and I proved to Mr. Lett's satisfaction that there was nothing in this, and his rejoicing was very short lived. However, he is passing this along to you as the cause of the trouble. I can assure you that there was no trouble such as he outlined on that switchboard, and if the discovery which he made was causing all the trouble, both with the plants and the battery, as he states in his letter, then Mr. Tredcroft's report can be discarded - Mr. Lett contends the trouble was on the switchboard, while Mr. Tredcroft claims it was with the engine. You can, therefore, draw your own conclusions.

Dealing with your remarks that if this defect existed, we should replace these batteries free! I
can assure you that the short life of the battery was caused by improper attention on the part of the attendants. This, I have told you before, and I still adhere to my previous opinion.

Dealing with Mr. Tredcroft's report there are some remarks which I would like to make. On page 2, Mr. Tredcroft states that he found the large plant, on his arrival, not working properly in that it was only carrying a load of 35 to 40 amps, and the speed would drop to 360 r.p.m., and the engine would stop if the load was increased. He also found on removal of the flywheel, that the valve timing of the engine was out due to the idler pinion being improperly meshed. He states that after making the proper adjustments, he found it necessary to enlarge the opening in the carburettor manifold by 40%. This engine then carried a 20% overload with no signs of faltering. Dealing with the above statement, I would point out that he found this plant out of adjustment on his arrival, which was only a few days after my visit. The writer on the occasion of his last visit, and on previous visits to the school, with Mr. Lett and Mr. Lapine in attendance had pulled a 15% overload on this particular engine, and I pointed this out in my report to Mr. R. G. Orr of April 22nd, a copy of which was sent to you. It certainly was not necessary to do any cutting as stated by Mr. Tredcroft in his report. Further, if it were necessary to do this cutting on this one particular engine, it would be necessary to do it on all the engines which our factory turn out, which you know would be absurd, owing to the fact that we have hundreds of these plants and engines in this particular size working satisfactorily.

There is one question which I would like to ask Mr. Tredcroft - considering that this plant is a constant potential system - that is - the voltage remains constant from no load to full load, and the load change is taken care of by a speed variation controlled by the magnetic governor coil, opening and closing the throttle opening, which Mr. Tredcroft altered, if the opening were enlarged to give more gas and more speed on full load what did he do with his excess speed on minimum load due to enlarging the size of the holes in this throttle, which means increased voltage.
The most interesting portion of his report on this page, however, is the fact that he found this engine so badly out of tune within such a short period after our visit to the plant which proves that somebody changed the adjustments after our visit. This verifies my contention in my previous reports—that the adjustments on the plants were not left as we made them, and consequently the plant could not function properly.

Mr. Tredcroft did not accomplish any greater results in getting capacity from this plant than we, ourselves, accomplished every time that we visited the school, as my previous reports to you will show. As far as adjustments are concerned on the brushes of the generator, there is only one place for these brushes, and that is at the neutral point, where you will get absence of sparking and good commutation. This has very little to do with the load of the engine.

On page 3, Mr. Tredcroft states that it would obviously appear that the whole trouble in the operation of this plant lay in the fact that the gas ports of the engine were too small, thereby preventing the engine getting sufficient fuel at high speed for heavy load, and on this point I take exception. He also states that there are too many sharp bends in the exhaust pipe between the engine and the mufflers, and that these mufflers in the engine room are noisy, and in his opinion are not the best type for a plant of this size, stating that a concrete exhaust box below ground level outside, properly equipped with a drain and outlet, would be far superior. I would point out to Mr. Tredcroft that if he had disconnected the exhaust line from the engine, while it was in operation he would have found that his power output would remain just the same, and thereby prove the exhaust equipment on this plant is correct.

The expansion pot is very close to the engines, thereby eliminating any back pressure and the pipe and bends which are on this equipment are of 2" diameter, whereas the minimum pipe diameter which we could use on this installation without detrimental results would be 1½". I am thoroughly satisfied that Mr. Tredcroft does not understand the exhaust end of this installation when he recommends underground exhaust chamber, as this would endanger both life and property. I would advise that when these engines stop they do so by releasing the compression on the cylinder by holding one of the valves open. The
engine still rotates for some time due to the momentum of the flywheels, and there is a certain amount of gas drawn in on each revolution of the engine which is not exploded but expelled from the exhaust line into free air. As the installation is at present it passes through the short exhaust line into the cast-iron exhaust pot, and then in turn into the outside air. At times, this gas becomes ignited with the result that there is a back-firing which is not detrimental in any way as the exhaust pot is small and being made out of heavy cast-iron, is exceptionally strong and no damage results. However, if you were to take an underground exhaust chamber, and expel this unburned gas into the chamber, and it then became ignited you would simply be minus a concrete exhaust chamber, and possibly kill someone in the process. I think that this is a point which Mr. Tredcroft has overlooked, and I warn your Department at this time to refrain from carrying out a plan of this description.

Re the operation of the 12 H.P. Engine on the laundry, I note Mr. Tredcroft states that there is a heavy side pull on the main bearing of the engine, causing undue wear in the bearings, and he recommends that a separate engine should be installed for this purpose. He also states that the operator reports that the generator on this plant becomes overheated when it is run 8½ hrs. continuously. I think it would be better if Mr. Tredcroft had not brought this into his report. If a 10 to 15% load, used for battery charging while running the laundry is going to cause overheating, of this generator, what will 20% overload do to the machine, which he states he developed, in the previous part of his report?

In reference to the side draught on the bearings of the engine, driving the laundry, there is nothing in this as we absolutely guarantee these engines to operate on full capacity, belt load, driving in any direction, and we turn thousands of these engines out for belt drive purposes every year and you can therefore dis-consider this portion of the report. In addition I would point out that on this particular engine the crankshaft is supported by a centre bearing, making three bearings in all.

I note he claims, when operating the engine for driving the laundry, and there being no lighting
load on, the generator is delivering current to charge the battery and the battery can become very easily destroyed by overcharging. If Mr. Tredcroft is well acquainted with storage battery action, he will agree with me that there are certainly no signs of overcharging on this battery, and as a matter of fact one needs only to look at it to see that it has been starved and inadequately charged instead of being overcharged. Therefore when he makes the statement that this battery has been overcharged, apparently due to the lack of experience on the part of previous operators and the fact that the battery was not out of circuit when the laundry was running—it appears to me that he is not very well acquainted with the battery business or he would not make such a statement.

For his information, I would advise that it is possible to operate the laundry machinery without generating any current whatever if it is deemed necessary to do so in this school. It is necessary, as it has been found in all other schools, to take advantage of laundry wash day to give the battery this over-charge, which you must give it to obtain long life, and which is the practice which is carried out in all the other schools, where the laundry is driven by the power plant machine. They all have been operating with exceptional satisfaction.

Mr. Tredcroft states that then the battery is replaced, cells with larger containers should be installed so that there will be more liquid surrounding the plates. On this point, I have nothing to say as I would not recommend the Exide Battery Co. on this point as I am convinced that they know more about this business than I do.

In the last paragraph on page 5, Mr. Tredcroft reports that it is well to point out that several spare parts had been ordered and purchased by the previous operator, for which I understand the Department paid, which were not necessary, and in addition have never been used or where used have been installed incorrectly.

Dealing with this in my previous reports I pointed out that these parts were ordered by Mr. Lepine, which is the case as shown by our Invoice #1846, and the order was signed by Mr. Lepine as well as Mr. Lett in Sept. 1929.
I have his original order for these parts in front of me at the time of writing and it was Mr. Lepine who ordered these parts and not the previous operator as intimated by Mr. Tredcroft. This proves that Mr. Tredcroft's report in this instance is one of protection and is given without having the proper information on hand other than that which he received from the school.

Since Mr. Tredcroft was asked by the Department to give a report on the exact condition of things as he found them, I do not think that verbal statements as given above by the operators of the plants should be taken into consideration.

Summarizing Mr. Tredcroft's whole report, you will observe that the main body of it agrees with my previous reports to your Department, in that he found the plants altered on his visit and not functioning properly, and that the plants will do their work when left properly adjusted, which bears out my contention that the trouble is more in the operation of the plants than in the plants themselves.

If any further information is required, or if you desire to enter into further details, I will be glad to discuss it on receipt of word from you.

Thanking you, and trusting that I may have the pleasure of hearing further from you, I am,

Yours respectfully,

R. A. LISTER & CO. (CANADA) LTD.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Perhaps I am foolish for worrying myself unduly and in taking my duties so seriously, but I'm afraid I'm built that way, and cannot help it. Now after this little preamble I shall disclose the purpose of this letter, and let you know what is on my mind.

The beautiful Chapel which the Department provided for the new school at Lytton has to be abandoned during the winter months because of the inadequacy of the central heating plant to handle the added load. We built on a false premise when we assumed that the existing boilers could heat this building too at times of low temperatures. Theoretically they might do it, but last winter told a different tale. On the authority of the Department, Mr. Walker (Dunham's Alberta Engineer) made a Report on the conditions as he found them, and indicated what should be done to provide sufficient heat for the Chapel, Utility Building and Principal's Residence. You have Mr. Walker's Report and recommendations on file, and are fully conversant with the existing conditions, so I need not dwell on them.

The Rev. Mr. Lett wrote to me recently expressing his anxiety that the heating troubles be remedied before the coming winter. When in Ottawa I mentioned the matter to Dr. Scott, and he was sympathetic towards providing relief, but seemed in some doubt as to whether the money could be found. You were absent from the Capital at the time, and the matter was not discussed at any great length in your absence. I also mentioned the subject to you in Toronto, and if I remember rightly, you said you would see what could be done about it later.

I recognize, of course, that there may be no money available at present for this work, and that of sheer necessity it may have to be postponed. My immediate object in bringing the matter to your attention just now is to say that if there
is any chance of providing the good people at Lytton with the relief they desire, I shall be only too glad to cooperate. Mr. Crombie, of Vancouver, who put in the radiation and hook-up last summer, is the logical man to do the work, and he is conscientious and efficient, and is in full accord with Mr. Walker's recommendations.

I know you are exceptionally busy this summer, and perhaps I should ask your pardon for intruding this problem on your already overburdened mind, but I simply had to write this letter to ease my own conscience!

The work on the Blue Quills School is proceeding with almost mathematical precision, and I am finding the contractors capable and dependable, and they have abundant equipment. The erecting of basement steel, and the bricklaying, should start this week.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely

[Signature]

Inspector of Construction.
Mr. Orr recommends that an improvement be made in the heating system at the St. George's Indian Residential School, so that the chapel can be successfully heated. The cost will be nearly $3,000. At the present time, there is over $1,700 in the New England Company account for this institution and this will be doubled in a few days, when the September quarter grant is received from England. I have examined Mr. Lett's recent reports and I believe that he will not require any special help for current expenses for the time being. The New England Company grant could therefore be used for the heating improvement and I beg to recommend your approval to the proposal.

6th October, 1930.

Dear Mr. Graham,

As it is drawing near to the Winter months and the Department has done nothing regarding the changing of the heating system in the two wings, the Residence and the Chapel, and if we are to get through the Winter without this, some changes are very necessary in order to save fuel consumption and unnecessary freezing of radiators and pipes in the Chapel. Resulting from last year's freeze up we have some breakages to take care of now. This freeze up could not have been avoided as there was no valve in the steam pipe running to the Chapel, hence the necessary repairs that now demand our attention. This valve would close off the line so that there would be no further fear of a freeze up as we could then cut off the Chapel and have no further bother.

Personally, I am trying not to think of the possibility of having, again this Winter, to use the Auditorium for my Services and having no heat in the Residence.

Last year the consumption of fuel was rather great and unnecessary expense could be saved if the heating system were changed.

If the Department could see fit to make this alteration I should be glad, otherwise I must ask for the installation of a valve which is very necessary in order to prevent further damage being done through frost.

Please take this matter to the Department and kindly urge them to make the necessary alteration, if it is possible, or to allow the valve to be put in and make the repairs necessary to the Chapel radiators and pipe lining.

Yours very obediently,

(Signed) A.R.Lett.

Dear Sir:

I have to report upon the Lytton Agency No.5 as follows:

I have inspected St George's Residential School twice this year. At my last visit there were 171 children registered. The dust question seems to be a bad one to solve as every wind that blows brings it in. Considerable oiling of the playgrounds, along with belts of poplar trees round the school, seems to be the only solution. The children were having for their next meal the evening one, gingerbread, apples and stewed pears. I was assured that they were having at least two pints of milk apiece per diem. The dish and food heater in the kitchen was disconnected. Apparently there was something wrong. I instructed Mr. Graham to have the matter investigated and warned a pity to have such a useful and costly piece of kitchen furniture lying idle. Two extinguishers were still lying about as complained of by me last year, and I therefore asked Mr. Graham to urge the principal when he returned to have them placed upon brackets. I went over the classrooms and dormitories and found all in order.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:-

We have a little matter which we wish you would look into and straighten out for us if possible.

In 1929 under the former Government, we built the Indian Residential School at Lytton, B. C., on which there is owing to us a balance of Eight Hundred Nineteen Dollars and Thirty Cents ($819.30). To our constant communications to the Indian Department we have received no reply in this matter. They have never definitely refused to pay the bill but merely ignore our correspondence.

The reason for this, we presume, is because the amount of our charges is for extra wages paid to the carpenters on the demand of your Department, by the late Minister, Peter Heenan.

This demand was made on us by the Minister in order to satisfy the request of the Labour Unions in Vancouver. It was in addition to what our men had agreed to work for, and in addition to any wage scale paid in any of the surrounding country within 150 miles of Lytton, where we were doing the work.

Our contract was for wages to be paid according to the scale of the district, and we had taken special care, before figuring the building or entering into the contract with the Department, to ascertain, both in Kamloops and Chilliwack, what the wages of that district and surrounding country were at the time. As a matter of fact we were already paying our carpenters 50 cents more per day than the rate in the district demanded, but the Minister, to satisfy the Vancouver Unions demanded that we pay another 50 cents per day, and this additional amount, which was required of us, is all
for which we are asking remuneration.

Our whole position is set out in our letters which have been sent to your Department and the Department of Indian Affairs; and also in a statement, in your possession, signed by our men showing that the additional 50 cents per day paid to them was in excess of their agreement with us at the time of being hired.

We think we are justly entitled to being remunerated for this additional expenditure, and we ask that you will favour us by giving it your immediate attention, with the hope that you will see us justly dealt with, and that remittance will be forthcoming to us for same.

We are,

Yours truly,

ADKISON & DILL LIMITED.

Dear Sirs:-

Your letter of the 27th ultimo addressed to the Hon. D. J. Montieth, Minister of Labour, Ottawa, evidently was received by the Provincial Department of Labour, Toronto, and redirected to the undersigned at Ottawa. It is observed from your communication that you are claiming from the Department of Indian Affairs the sum of $819.50, which is stated to represent extra wages paid to carpenters in excess of the prevailing wage on demand of the Honourable Peter Heenan, who was Minister of Labour at the time, for work done on the contract for an Indian school at Lytton, B. C.

In reply may I say that careful consideration has been given to the representations made. Upon going into this question, however, I find that under the labour conditions of your contract the Minister has authority to determine for the purposes of this contract what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages, etc. This authority evidently was exercised in the light of information which had reached the Department respecting conditions prevailing in Lytton and vicinity and with the further knowledge that the carpenters over whom this wage dispute arose had been drawn from Vancouver. In view of the authority of the Minister in such matters as herein referred to, it does not appear to the undersigned that this Department can be of assistance to you in this instance. However, as you have intimated in your letter that this claim has already been submitted to the Department of Indian Affairs, for which Department the work was being performed, I am, therefore, transmitting to that Department, for their information, a copy of your letter and of my reply thereto.

Yours sincerely,

Re: Heating Plant, Lytton, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I met Mr. Sjoquist on Monday last, and accompanied by his steam-fitter, we went over the heating plant at Lytton very carefully. We were able to figure out a scheme whereby the steam main and returns from the Utility Building to the Chapel could be run underground, and Mr. Lett was anxious that the space between these two buildings could be used for a playground, and if we had run the main overhead, the piping supports would have been an attraction for the children, as no doubt, they would have practiced their acrobatic stunts on the steam main.

By using the sub-basement in the Chapel, and a pit in the Utility Building 15 x 8 x 5 feet 6" deep, has given us sufficient depth to run the steam main underground, and also to bring the return back dry. This will prevent any possible chance of freezing in the Chapel through lack of firing.

Regarding the chimney, I asked Mr. Sjoquist to make at least an 8" wall on the side next the building, as a precaution against fire, and there was a matter of 300 extra bricks, but this was covered in the price of $600.00.

The boiler to be used is an Inglis No. 11, and as the water at Lytton is inclined to be of a foamy nature, and steel boilers lack sufficient steam space, I drove down to Vancouver and interviewed the Inglis people, and they agreed to make the boiler 3" higher to give us this extra steam space, and 6" longer to give us an additional heating surface without any additional cost for the boiler.

The new main to the Residence will be installed so that if no heat is required in the School, the fireman will be in a position to shut off the School entirely, and heat the Residence.
The fireman complained to me that he could not keep an equal water line on the boilers. This condition is caused through the use of check valves on the returns between the Hartford connection and the boiler. These check valves are installed according to the British Columbia regulations, and they are of absolutely no value; in fact, they are a cause of trouble, and I suggested to Mr. Sjoquist that he take out the flaps and by doing so, the boilers will retain a steady and equal water line.

I prepared a piping lay-out for the Utility Building, and I also directed the steam-fitter how I wanted this installed.

Before leaving Lytton, bricks and lumber for the chimney and pit were on the job, and the Inglis people were working on the boiler and expected to have it completed in ten days.

As the Department are spending quite a little sum on the above alterations, I believe it would be good business to have a thorough check and tests made on the plant some time towards the middle of January. I would be quite willing to make this report and tests, if you so desire.

The following is a list of my expenses:

Fare & Berth ............. $54.60
Meals & Hotel ............ 30.00

Making a total of ........... $84.60.

I am not putting any charge in for the trip from Lytton to Vancouver and return, as Mr. Sjoquist was kind enough to allow me the use of his car.

Yours very truly,

A. Walker

Dear Sir:

On Friday the 23rd, I completed my inspection of the alterations to the Heating Plant at St. George's Residential School, Lytton.

The Residence which has now a new steam main, is heating very nicely, without any pressure showing on the boiler, and Mr. Lett was inclined to think it was a little too warm, but this can be taken care of by the valves on the radiators.

The Utility Building and the Chapel are also working very nicely, and on making a test on the Chapel, I found it required only a very short time for the steam to travel from the boiler in the Utility Building to the last Radiator in the Chapel. We had perfect circulation through every radiator, with only a small amount of vapour showing at the tri-coc-s, and no pressure indicated whatsoever on the steam gauge. Two to three fires per day will be all that is necessary to keep the Chapel and the Utility Building warm.

The concrete work, the building of the chimney, and the installation of the complete plant have been carried out according to instructions, in a very neat and proper manner and with the exception of two small changes in the piping and the raising of three ceiling Rads in the basement, the work is complete.
There was a rainfall of two inches at Lytton last Thursday, and no water entered the boiler-room, showing that the boxing which covers the mains between the Utility Building and the Chapel was tight.

Attached you will find my expenses covering two trips to Lytton, and the account submitted by the Kamloops Plumbing & Heating Company.

There were 168 children in the school at the time of my visit. The school was clean and tidy. On visiting the kitchens, I found that the supper consisted of corn, bread, and butter and cocoa with rice pudding. The senior boys were getting meat and potatoes additional, and the senior girls apple pie. A small refrigerator of about 10 cubic feet capacity is wanted in the kitchen. Fire drill is being well carried out. I pointed out that the fresh refills should be put into the fire extinguishers, and that they should be tagged. I also requested that these extinguishers should be placed upon brackets, so that they do not get moved about, and always remain in the same place. The plaster walls seem to be giving way and deteriorating badly, apparently being plastered upon too flexible wire. The paint, too, must have been poor as it is pealing and flaking off all the pipes. The root crops were being stored in the barns when I was there. The barns need painting again. There were 22 milk cows being milked at the time of my visit, but there is still some bother and loss with abortion amongst the herd. I also inspected the manual training quarters of nine dual benches. The principal wished he could get a lathe installed.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sanitary Conditions: The main drain pipe from the sinks and which runs under the kitchen floor often blocks. This causes serious trouble. This is not a pipe drain going to the septic tank. The Principal requests permission to open up the floor of the corridor just outside the kitchen. He wishes in the opening thus made to place an inspection trap. It will, of course, be necessary to consult the plans of the pipe lines in the school when starting this work. It can, of course, be carried out at the school without expense to the Department and will make future flooding of the kitchen floor impossible. When this work has been done, I recommend that new linoleum for the 30 ft. by 20 ft. kitchen floor be authorized at a cost of $150.00.

There is plaster off the walls in the Boys' and the Girls' wash rooms on the basement floor. I would suggest that zinc lining be placed in three of the boys' shower baths and in one shower bath on the girls' side.

Farming: I should like to draw the attention of the Department to the fact that a small canning plant at this school would make the surplus product of the farm and garden, in the way of fruits and vegetables, available for winter use. Such a canning plant I am informed would cost in the neighbourhood of $300. I consider that the money spent on this would not be wasted, as much of the perishable products of the garden would thus be saved.

The De Laval Cream Separator is now 10 years old and is not worth any further repair. I beg to recommend that the purchase of a new separator of approved pattern be authorized.

A small electric refrigerator of approved pattern is also recommended for use in the kitchen.

About $600 worth of paint is required. This is the total cost of the paint that the Principal considers necessary if the various farm buildings are to be painted this year. Some of these buildings do not appear to have been painted, and a number require repainting. The boys, under the instruction of one of the staff, could do all the actual work. The provision of materials for the painting of the farm buildings is recommended. The total of $600 mentioned would include the necessary paint for four cottages.
Ottawa, February 6, 1932.

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Schools for the Province of British Columbia, in a report on his inspection in November, last, on the St. George's Indian Residential School, states as follows regarding the sanitary conditions: "The main drain pipe from the sinks and which runs under the kitchen floor often blocks. This causes serious trouble. The Principal requests permission to open up the floor of the corridor just outside the kitchen and place an inspection trap in the opening thus made, and states that the work can be carried out at the school without expense to the Department. This will make future flooding of the kitchen floor impossible."

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of the Principal arranging to open up the drain and install the inspection trap. We understand that he has plans of the drainage, which he should consult before starting the work. The Department would pay the cost of the trap and materials used, but it is expected that the work will be carried out by the school without charge.

The Inspector also draws attention to the condition of the plaster on the walls in the boys' and girls' washrooms on the basement floor. He recommends that a lining be placed in three of the boys' shower baths and in one of the girls' shower baths. You should see that the work is satisfactorily performed, and at the least possible expense, and you may forward a voucher, in duplicate, covering the cost of the material. It is thought that the labour could be performed by the school staff without charge.

The Inspector further recommends that linoleum be supplied for the kitchen floor and also a cream separator. In this connection I have to say that the Department will have no funds to provide the linoleum, and it is considered, with regard to the cream separator, that the school authorities should provide the expenditure required in the purchase of a new separator from per capita earnings or other receipts.

We have noted for our Estimates for the next fiscal year the providing of funds for a small canning plant, the paint required in the painting of the various farm buildings and cottage, and also a small electric refrigerator for use in the kitchen.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Strang:-

Find herewith enclosed bill of expenditure on cleaning and repair of main ditch. This is getting more burdensome as the years go by. It amounts this year, as bill denotes, to the amount of $426.30. This is a rather heavy item on the School as an overhead on irrigation, and in submitting the accounts to you, I wish you would take the matter up with the Department, with the view of having the Department bear this expenditure for us.

In regard to the ditch, on the whole it is evident that new fluming will have to be put in. We are not at all assured of continued irrigation for this year, as the present flume is rotting, and will not in repair hold nails and in many places is completely falling apart. It was necessary this year to replace some fifteen boxes, and it will be necessary, I feel, before another irrigation season that the whole ditch be put in good condition. I am submitting this to you in the early part of this season so that the Department will be able to make provision for this expenditure in the coming Autumn or before irrigation begins next Spring.

If anything is done the ditch should be enlarged as well as a new flume built, so that more water could be handled during the season of Freshet, which would give us assurance of at least one crop of hay on a much greater acreage, and would benefit the Indians to a larger degree as well.

I trust you will take the matter up with the Department at once.

Yours very sincerely,

A. R. Lett.
Principal.

Dear Mr. Strang:

I have been thinking very strongly of trying to put in a small canning plant for the School, and this year the local canning plant is not going to operate. Hence we have some tomatoes on our hands (small acreage), but it would be very nice if we could put a few tons of these up for winter consumption. I have made enquiries regarding the possible cost of this plant, such as we would need, and it would cost somewhere in the neighbourhood of $225.00. This would give us a capacity of about two hundred pounds per cooking, and would be quite an asset to the food supply for the winter.

Besides the tomatoes, we have planted quite a crop of pumpkins, and also have this year, a goodly crop of harvest apples, and in the Autumn prune plums which could all be taken care of by this plant. I have been making enquiries, and understand that Principal Raley of Coqualeetza has, for some years, had a small canning plant which has given him every satisfaction. I also enquired of Mr. P. Moore, superintendent of Colony Provincial Farm, who says that it is one of the best expenditures he has ever made, and cans up to one hundred and fifty tons over the Provincial Asylum.

A supply of cans, which would take care of about ten tons of canning produce, would cost around $100.00. The same cans could be used three years in succession. This would be an extra cost, making total of $325.00 for the Plant and cans. Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn and Inspector Barry have both recommended this installation to the Department, but I have wondered if this expenditure could not be made out of the New England Company's grant to the School.
Mr. A. Strang:

As you know, it would be a very substantial asset to the School as we grow so much perishable food stuffs which could be taken care of by canning. Besides varying our menu, it helps to keep the children in fit condition and happy.

Please do what you can for me, as, if I cannot make this installation this year I shall be at a considerable loss.

Yours very sincerely,

A. R. Lett.
Principal.

Memorandum.

Mr. Buskard,

Referring to your memorandum of the 21st instant with reference to the claim of Adkison and Dill on their contract for the erection of the St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, B.C., I beg to give you the following information.

When plans and specifications are being prepared for a building, the regulations provided by the department shall apply to the Department of Labour for a fair-wage schedule of wages. In the case of the Lytton school the Department of Labour recommended the general clause, which provides that all mechanics shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current in the district where the work is being carried out, and this clause was inserted in the specifications for the St. George's School at Lytton.

On December 24, 1937, the department received a letter from the Department of Labour in which they enclosed a copy of letter which they had addressed to Adkison and Dill, Contractors, advising them that they did not consider that they were paying wages in accordance with the fair-wage clause, and stated that an inquiry had been made by the fair-wage officer which showed that current rate of wages for carpenters should be $7.60 per day, whereas they were paying $7.00 for this class of service. The contractors were instructed to pay the wage as determined by the Department of Labour. The contractors, Adkison and Dill asked the department to reimburse them for the advance in these wages, which, of course, could not be considered, and no allowance was made to them for the wages as required to be paid by the Department of Labour.

Dear Mr. Strang:

I have for some time been contemplating some improvements at Lot 47. I have been thinking of increasing our range herd, to bring it up to the number of around 125, and in order to keep the herd in good shape, it is necessary for me to provide a feed shed to which could be built a silo and some 60 to 70 tons of corn could be siloed.

I would also like to fix up a more decent living place for the man who is caring for this lot. We have considerably improved our output at Lot 47 and would like to develop the range herd, and in order to do so these necessary improvements would have to be made, both of which would cost us in cash approximately $1,000.

I believe the Department could spend this money from the New England Company grant and we would be glad if this could be done that the Department should let us know at the very earliest as we wish to begin these improvements at once while the Fall weather would allow building.

Would you kindly approach the Department to this effect.

Yours very sincerely,

A. R. Lett.
Principal.

Principal.
Sir:

I herewith beg to enclose a letter from the Rev. A. R. Lett, principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School, in reference to having the buildings painted, and also in reference to the assistance asked for the irrigation ditch.

In regard to painting the buildings I beg to say that it is very necessary that this should be done, as they are badly in need of paint, and deteriorate rapidly when let go too long.

In regard to the irrigation ditch the Department promised to have this put in the Estimates for the coming year, and I trust that this is being done, as it is most essential that this ditch and flume should at least be renewed in places, although the whole system should be done over and enlarged. The Department letter in regard to the Estimates was No. 165-0-5 dated May 19, 1932.

Trusting that you will be able to arrange at least to have $600.00 spent on this flume. To rebuild would cost in the neighborhood of $2500.00. This will eventually be a necessity.

Your obedient servant,

(A. Strang)
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Strang:

As the Spring is here, and necessary repairs must be made to irrigation systems, we find that some of our flume has again gone to pieces. Dear Mr. Strang,

At your request and in co-operation with my own correspondence with you, and through you to the Department, I have been over the ditch and find that all of the flume (excepting for that which was put in by the School last Spring—1932—costing approximately $800) is in need of replacing. There is about one mile of flume on the ditch, and it has now rotted to that extent that it cannot be touched at all, and wherever it springs a leak new boxes have got to be put in — hence the yearly expense of up-keep is becoming larger and larger. We have, during the last two Springs spent over $1400 in lumber and costs of repair. I would suggest that the Department buy enough lumber and have same put on the ground so that parts of the flume could be replaced at our own time. The cost of this lumber would be approximately $2000. Enclosed time sheets together with a lumber account which expense was incurred this Spring will leave $300 of the $600 grant just allowed, to buy some lumber, and would suggest that this be spent at once, in order that the lumber may be on the ground in case of an emergency, as we do not know when we may have a break. At any time you wish a list of lumber in detail, I shall be glad to give it to you, but for purposes of quotation we shall need 114,756 feet of lumber to replace the flume.

Thanking you, and trust that you shall take the matter up at once as it is important.

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir:

re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

On July 24th, 1933, I inspected the plant of this school, which consists of:

Two Birchfield boilers 7' x 8' x 4'6", having 64 3" tubes, rated 43 H.P. each, numbered 44028 B.C., built in 1928, making them now 5 years old. Longitudinal joint welded.

One Inglis Supreme boiler, 60" x 30" x 42", having 53 - 3" tubes rated at 34 H.P., No. 44564 B.C., built in 1931, making it now 3 years old. Longitudinal joint welded.

One Vertical tubular boiler 67" x 31" having 43 2 3/4" tubes and rated at 6.3 H.P., built in 1927, making it now 6 years old. Longitudinal joint double rivetted lap. Boiler No. 44008 B.C.

Boiler No. 44028 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found that all stays, plates and joints were in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 40 Lb. and found everything tight.

The internal condition of this boiler is very good, there being no corrosion.

The safety valve works freely and will blow off at 15 Lb. pressure.

The fusible plug has been renewed.

Test cocks, water gauge, main stop valve, blow off cock and pipe are in good condition. The steam gauge is correct.

Boiler No. 44029 B.C.

This boiler is in much the same condition as 44028 B.C. except the blow off cock, which is leaking and needs to be overhauled. The steam gauge is about 1 Lb. light.

The bridge walls of both these boilers have been rebuilt and are in good condition. Some of the nipples of the hot water coils installed in the furnaces are leaking slightly and should receive attention.
Boiler No. 44029 B.C. Continued.

On account of the hardness of the feed water a water softening apparatus has been installed for the laundry. I would suggest that only water from this apparatus be used as make up feed water.

I have issued certificates for these boilers, allowing a steam pressure of 15 Lb. and condition good.

Boiler No. 44008 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful hammer test and found that all joints, plates and rivets were in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic Test of 190 Lb. per square inch and found every part quite tight. I then set the safety valve to blow off at 135 Lb.

The steam gauge is 15 Lb. light and should be renewed.

The test cocks, water gauge, blow off cock, are in good condition.

The fusible plug is to be renewed.

Internally the boiler is in good condition, very little scale showing.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 135 Lb. and condition good.

Boiler No. 44564 B.C.

This boiler is also in first class condition externally and internally. The main stop valve was leaking so badly that I could not complete the Hydrostatic Test. This boiler is fitted with a scum pan or surface blowdown but there is no cock fitted on the outside of the boiler so it can be used. A screwed plug being screwed into the connection this should be fitted with an asbestos packed blow down cock so that it can be used.

The fusible plug is to be renewed.

The bridge is in good condition and will need no attention.

I would like to point out that when this boiler was installed it was installed in a deep pit and no provision was made for draining it. This must be attended to as under present conditions should a leak occur the attendant would very likely be badly burnt before he could get out and the steam and boiling water would prevent him from drawing the fires and the boiler would be practically ruined. To put in a drain would cost about One Hundred Dollars ($100.00).

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 Lb. and condition good.

Laundry.

The machines are kept in good condition. There should be a pipe guard placed around the washing and drying machines which I pointed out to the engineer. Some of the materials required are at the school and the rest will cost about Ten Dollars ($10.00).

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Amall,
Engineer, D.E.W.

Sir:

Mr. Arnall, Engineer of the Department of Public Works, who inspected the boilers and machinery at the St. George's Indian Residential School in July, last, has forwarded a report of his inspection to this Department. He has drawn attention to the condition of the boilers at this school and the repairs required, as follows:

Boiler No. 44029. The blow-off cock, which is leaking, needs to be overhauled. The steam gauge is about 1 lb. light. Some of the nipples of the hot water coils are leaking slightly and should receive attention.

Boiler No. 44008. The steam gauge is 15 lb. light and should be renewed. The fusible plug is to be renewed.

Boiler No. 44564. This boiler is in first class condition externally and internally. The main stop valve was leaking so badly that I could not complete the hydrostatic test. This boiler is fitted with a scum pan or surface blowdown, but there is no cock fitted on the outside of the boiler so it can be used. A screwed plug is screwed into the connection and this should be fitted with an asbestos packed blow-down cock so that it can be used. The fusible plug is to be removed. This boiler was installed in a deep pit and no provision was made for draining. This must be attended to, as under present conditions, should a leak occur, the attendant would very likely be badly burnt before he could get out and the steam and boiling water would prevent him from drawing the fires and the boiler would be practically ruined. To put in a drain would cost about $100.

You should draw the above to the attention of the Principal and he should arrange to see that the repairs, as mentioned by the Public Works Engineer, are attended to at an early date. The cost should be met by the school authorities from per capita grant or other receipts.

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection of Boilers & Machinery,
Indian School, Lytton, B.C.

BOILER No. 44564.

I beg to report that on July 11th I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found all stays and plates in good condition. I then gave it a Hydrostatic test of 40 lbs. and found it perfectly tight.

I set the safety valves to blow at 15 lbs. water pressure.

Care must be taken to keep the internal wet legs clean and free from sediment, also the furnace crowns as there was a lot of sediment in them.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

BOILER No. 42028.

On the same day I gave this boiler a similar inspection and found it in first class condition. I set the safety valves to blow off at 15 lbs. The steam gauge is 2 lbs. heavy.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.

BOILER No. 42029.

I also gave this boiler a similar inspection and found it in first class condition. There were some corrosion blisters on the tubes and furnace crowns which must be kept clean. The previous water treatment for the three boilers numbered above must be continued. I set the safety valves to blow off at 15 lbs. water pressure. During the Hydrostatic test the blowdown cock was leaking badly and needs regrinding. The steam gauge is correct.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 15 lbs. and condition good.
BOILER No. 44006.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found that there was quite a lot of internal corrosion, some corrosion blisters on the furnace crown and tubes. These must be all cleaned off and when raising steam must be done with a slow fire and the water kept in the gauge glass nearly to the top. After steam is formed blow some water down to the proper working level.

I then gave it a Hydrostatic test of 200 lbs. and found it quite tight. The fusible plug must be renewed. I set the safety valves to blow off at 135 lbs. water pressure. The steam gauge is 2 lbs. light.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 135 lbs. and condition good.

When this boiler is not in use it should be emptied and dried out to prevent corrosion.

AUXILIARY MACHINERY.

The auxiliary machinery is in a very good condition. They have been kept in very good condition and will need no repairs. All the necessary guards have been installed.

My attention was drawn to the large amount of fuel used during the season. The only solution is to install automatic coal stokers of the underfeed type which will make a considerable saving in the cost of fuel as well as greatly add to the efficiency of the plant.

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall

Dear Sir,

Within the past year the School was obliged to replace the third hot water jacket and now the fourth one has cracked. It would seem that something is radically wrong with this installation because the original heater installed when the school was built should still be functioning but together with it three others have likewise cracked and up to the present time these replacements has cost the school approximately $400.00 and now we are confronted with another expenditure of $150.00. Twice I have reported the fact of these jackets going in this manner and have asked the Department to bear the cost of replacement which was refused and the school was obliged to carry this extra out of Per Capita Earnings. Now I am not worrying over past expenditures but as this is the fourth, in six years of this nature, I think something should be done to remedy the cause.

I would suggest that the Department have a heating engineer look into the matter with the view of ascertaining why this so happens. I believe myself that the Jacket installed is not of large enough capacity to handle the hot water needs of the school and constant heavy firing results in the cracking of the Jacket. It is very evident that something is responsible for such repetitions and I feel the Department now should take steps to remedy the condition.

The hot water proposition in the school has always been a worry and since a constant supply of hot water is so very essential for the cleanliness and health of the children we should have an efficient heating plant in order that the Staff and Children should be sufficiently supplied.

Sincerely thanking you for immediate attention.

Yours very obediently,

Mr. A.F. McKenzie,
Dept of Indian Affairs

Sir:

I herewith beg to enclose a letter from the Rev. A. R. Lett, principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, in regard to the way in which the Utility Building has settled.

In this connection I beg to state that I have inspected the above mentioned building and found, as Mr. Lett states, that the east side of the building has settled, causing a distinct list in the chimney.

This is evidently caused by the seepage of water through a hole in the floor of the boiler pit on that side of the building. To prevent further settling of the building, I would suggest that the water be piped from the pit to the west side of the building where it is lower. This would mean tunnelling under the floor in order to reach the pit on the east side.

I think that the sum of $50.00 would cover the expense of this, at the very outside, and I would like to recommend that this amount be granted for this purpose.

Dear Mr. McInnes:

Your letter No. 165-0-3, dated October 16th, re application for Ford Station Wagon, which as stated would, to a large degree, make us independent in our transportation necessitated in our inter-town and school games. We have made as many as six trips to Lillooet, 45 miles distant, also four trips to Spence's Bridge and Ashcroft, 24 and 52 miles distant, and Lytton every other week.

During the late agent's term of office among us, he (Mr. Graham) was very good in putting himself and his car at our disposal on competition trips of this necessary activity of school life, but we are not now so favored for the present agent has no interest in us whatever in this regard, hence I have been obliged to beg, borrow or hire extra transportation, and I thought, by having a light truck in which I could comfortably seat up to twelve or fourteen children, it would leave us in a position of independence at times of this sort.

The big truck is cumbersome and not conducive to much comfort and is also expensive to send on long trips with only half loads, also these B.C. Interior roads do not materially help in keeping down repair bills.

I also had in mind, as pointed out, the fact that I had for all these years been taking care of the morning town trip and feel it is time some member of the staff or one of the boys should now be given this work. During times when, such as this year, I have been obliged to do so much running in transporting children at vacation time, a light truck would be a very great help for us; wherein, I was obliged to make two trips with the car when one would have been sufficient, wherein I sent the big truck to bring a much smaller load than it could carry.

Most of our freighting also could be taken care of by a light truck, saving the expense of running the heavy one to and from Lytton. Very often, in this regard, with a light truck, freight could be lifted during the morning trip in collection of the mail, bread and other school supplies, thus saving again in being obliged, first in using my car as a light express freight wagon, secondly in having the large truck.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

By the time this arrives, you will have received the Inspector's Report regarding the progress of the school and its need as to class-room reorganization.

We propose a new class-room to be housed in the Chapel basement, and to be used as a preparation and feeder room for the remaining class-rooms in the school.

The Basement of the Chapel lends itself very nicely to the establishment of a Primary room. It could also be used as a playroom for these younger children; with very little expense, other than extra desks and blackboard, this could be made an ideal place.

I have been hoping for such a room for some time, but felt that unless I could have a guarantee of a special grant from the Department or have extra available children who would become per capita earners, brought in, I could not possibly carry this extra incurred expense of a teacher's salary.

There are now in the school one hundred sixty-two and four in the hospital who will, I expect, shortly be returned, making a per capita earning capacity of one hundred sixty-four, which does not warrant the expenditure of another fifty dollars a month, cash, with twenty-five dollars for room and board. I believe this number could be materially increased if pressure by the Agent was brought to bear on some of the parents now holding their children out of school, and a number maintained closer to our maximum of one hundred eighty. With an average of one hundred seventy-five children I feel I could undertake such an expense.

It would seem that I should rather talk, not from a money point of view, but for the cause of education take steps immediately to establish a new classroom. I would appreciate your advice in this matter.

I would also call attention to the straggly manner in which children enter the school. If more attention were paid to time of entry it would make the classroom work much easier. In September we had sixteen entries due mostly
to my own activities and also to those of the missioner. Beginning October 22nd we had three local children brought in and two belated ones from Ashcroft—making five in all. This fact is very upsetting and a principal cannot expect efficiency from a teacher if her numbers are constantly being added to. With a little interested diplomatic activity, on the part of the Agent, the Indians could easily be led to observe September and February as times of entrance and it would make a very great difference in getting efficiency and maintaining it, especially in the lower class-rooms—children coming in at any time is upsetting to both children and teachers.

The Inspector will report adversely on the Primary Room and this fact is not all due to the teacher, she has been terribly handicapped by straggly entrance. Personally, I cannot do more than ask, and feel that more sympathetic and interested co-operation should be forthcoming. The school is now in good shape and has regained its standard. We have not had any truants and the children and staff are happy.

It is unfortunate, that during an epidemic of nasty sore throats, we had one death, cause of death pneumonia. This girl's father has always objected to his children going to school and held them out until the latter part of October when she was brought in at the Agent's demand. I made a special trip for the girl and her sister at the beginning of the term, and, together with the Department's Constable, saw these people in the hop-fields, a promise was given by the father that his girls would be sent up the following Wednesday, September 11th, with no results; no further notice was taken until October 22nd. I feel, that had the father been made to carry out his promise and the girl had had a month and a half's good food regularly, I would not have lost her. She came in in a run-down condition and covered with impetigo, consequently she did not rally in the crisis. In every case of pneumonia, twelve in all, we were able, with reasonable nursing, to pull the children through and I am sure this would also have applied to pupil No. 0170, Lily Smoker.

I shall be glad of an early reply, for then I can make the necessary preparations.

If available children are brought in I am sure they would increase our number up to one hundred seventy-five, or one hundred eighty.

Yours very obediently,

A. R. Lett,
Principal.

The Matron asked me to recommend that two new Singer TAILOR machines be given to the school as they are so badly needed for this vocational training. I wish to draw the attention of the Department to the fact that at night although the ordinary doors of the dormitories are locked the doors leading to the fire escapes are not locked or protected with seals or in any way. It is claimed that on one occasion about a year and a half ago boys got into the girls' dormitory. Mr. Phelan made suggestion to the Principal that electric bells be connected to the Supervisor's rooms, but the Principal does not like the idea. Rev. Mr. Lett, Principal of the school, is obtaining a couple of drums of oil to see if the immediate vicinity of the school can be oiled so as to abate this dust nuisance. He also took me down to see the new hot water boiler in the boiler room. This school has had to install a number of these boilers since it was built. Apparently, the trouble is caused by the presence of calcium carbonate and calcium sulphate which, when heated, causes scale in the pipes. As I have seen advertised in English papers some remedy for this, I am going to let the Principal have some information at a later date. I am afraid the installation of this boiler is going to cost more money than was originally expected. It seems that Rev. Mr. Lett obtained an estimate from Mr. Dawson of the Public Works Department, which he submitted to the Department, for $220.00. Unfortunately, Mr. Dawson had not estimated in this certain brick and other work that had to be done, and apparently, the final cost will be around $360.00. I don't think this could be avoided.

I am afraid that the school is going to be very hard up for water for irrigation purposes this year, as apparently, some of the white users opened the gates to Botanie Lake where there is storage. There seems to be some mix-up, too, regarding the closing of these gates early in the fall for storage purposes, and the Dominion Water Rights Engineers, I understand, thought that it was not safe to keep the storage fairly full throughout the winter, owing to a possible early and excessive run-off, in the spring. However, this year, there was very little snow on the watershed, and the consequence is that the storage naturally did not have a chance to fill up, as it might have done if the gates had been kept closed earlier and the lake gone into the winter with some storage from last year. I am not absolutely clear in this matter, but the next time I see Mr. Webb, I will make enquiries.

SPECIFICATION

CANADIAN IRON STOKER

HOPPER:
To be made of Copper Steel, Heavy Gauge, Rust Treated, with a capacity of 600 pounds. The body to be close riveted and to have extended flanges on the bottom for bolting to Base. An Agitator within the Hopper prevents the coal arching, thus ensuring a steady flow of coal to the fire.

HOPPER BASE:
The Hopper Base shall be of Cast Iron heavy section ribbed to make a rigid Base for the machine. It shall be flanged outward, and properly supplied with an asbestos gasket and have bolted thereto the Hopper in a manner which shall ensure a leak proof joint.

CONVEYOR:
The Conveyor Screw shall be a one piece casting of Manganese Steel and shall be a length to suit the installation. It shall be enclosed in a steel housing which shall form the feed connection between the Hopper Base and the Retort.

RETORT:
The Retort shall be made of Cast Iron 14" wide by 27" long, and of heavy section designed to withstand heat of combustion. Top section is made up of heavy sectional Tuyere Blocks, openings through which permit of a distribution of the air for complete permeation of the coal below as well as through the fire zone.

These Tuyere Blocks are readily renewable. Trough shaped interlocking Deadplates, supported on the Retort Base, are furnished of the proper size to fit the furnace. A Cleanout Door will be placed conveniently for the periodic cleaning under the Retort.

GEAR REDUCTION:
The Gear Reduction shall comprise a quiet triple reduction and provide three speeds, 70 pounds, 140 pounds, and 210 pounds of coal per hour, and neutral, to the feed screw, and shall be so designed as to permit changes of speeds noiselessly and by the most approved design of shifting mechanism, while the machine is operating. The Worm Gear is hobbed from Phosphor Bronze and the other Gears shall be made from an alloy steel and be heat treated to proper hardness, and shall have machine cut teeth. All Shafts shall be made of Alloy Steel and Bearings of Bronze. S.K.F. Ball Thrust Bearings will be supplied on the Worm Shaft. The Gear Case will be of Cast Iron and be oil tight. A suitable oil gauge is provided at a convenient position on the Case. A safety shear pin, easily replaced, is provided in the drive to protect the machine in case of heavy overloads.

Connection to the Motor is made by means of a "V" Belt.

ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT:
The Motor shall be one of approved make, 3/4 Horsepower capacity, and guaranteed to take care of the maximum load and be equipped with Service Switch and approved type of Circuit Breaker.
FAN:
The Fan is of the balanced centrifugal type with ample delivery and is enclosed in an Aluminum Housing with a well designed Shutter for efficient control of the air supply. The Duct leading from the Fan to the Retort is made of Copper Bearing Steel as a preventive against rust. An auxiliary air duct prevents smoking back.

CONTROLS:
A Thermostat for the automatic control of the room temperature shall form a part of this specification, also a Pressure Control for the safe regulation of the boiler from excess pressure. The Thermostat, which is located conveniently in one of the rooms to be heated, is of a nationally known make and is designed to function within two degrees variation in temperature. This unit controls the operation of the Stoker; that is, when there is a call for heat the Thermostat connects the Stoker Motor electrically and operates the Stoker, then when the temperature is sufficiently high the Thermostat shuts off the Stoker.

GUARDS:
Proper Guards are provided on the Stoker for protection of all moving parts.

GUARANTEE:
The equipment is guaranteed against all mechanical defects or faulty workmanship for one year.

INSTALLATION:
The installation shall be made in a concrete pit with 4" concrete walls and floors, and which shall be of a sufficient depth to provide the maximum area for efficient combustion.

WEIGHT: 2500 lbs.

BREATHING Mabury-Combustioneer's underfeed method of firing secures the highest combustion efficiency. The volatile matter which causes smoke when firing by hand, is progressively distilled from the coal as it passes through the incandescent fuel bed. The carbon in the coal is then burned and practically every heat unit is converted into useful energy. The patented Mabury-Combustioneer gear box causes the fuel to be agitated during the process of combustion. The feed screw starts slowly, increases in speed until it reaches maximum velocity and then slowly stops. Due to the spongy nature of coal, this alternate compressing and releasing of the fuel causes the small particles of coal to pack momentarily and then spring apart. As this occurs from 60 to 90 times a minute, the air reaches and surrounds each particle of coal and supplies the right amount of oxygen to burn the coal completely. This is in contrast to the continuous feed type of gear box where the coal is under constant compression and the air cannot reach the center of the fuel in the retort.

GEAR BOX. The patented Mabury-Combustioneer Gear Box is of the heavy duty intermittent type designed to produce the "breathing" action of the fuel bed which is so necessary to burn bituminous coal efficiently. There are only three rotating parts in the gear box. Positive splash and contact lubrication of all moving parts is provided. All parts subject to wear are hardened and ground. The bronze worm wheel, special alloy steel worm, heat treated steel drop forgings, large bronze bushings, ball bearings and the bronze and steel drop forged eccentric, insure long service life. All parts are machined in jigs and fixtures and are interchangeable. The coal feed can be changed without stopping the motor. Every part is accessible from the front of the gear box.

SAFETY CLUTCH. The exclusive Safety Clutch automatically disconnects the coal feed worm from the driving gear in case of an overload caused by an obstruction to the feed worm. It is adjustable to suit any kind of coal used. The clutch is re-engaged by simply pulling a lever. It is as positive, simple and dependable as the clutch in your automobile. Antiquated shearing pins have been eliminated. Electrical connections to clutch lever can be arranged to stop motor and sound alarm bell in case the clutch is operated, thereby preventing the fuel bed from burning down in the retort.

ACCESS PLATE. The Patented Access Plate permits the removal of obstructions from the feed worm without emptying any coal out of the hopper. A crusher pocket in the base automatically reduces the lumps of coal to proper size so as to pass through the worm tube, thus insuring a uniform flow of fuel to the retort at all times.

RETORT. The Retort is built up of sections to take care of expansion and contraction. They are constructed of special heat resisting iron, heavily ribbed to amply support the weight of the fuel bed and a portion of the dead plates. The sides and ends of the retort are so shaped as to allow free upward movement of coal to the tuyere blocks.

TUYERES. The Tuyeres are of heavy construction and made of special heat resisting iron. Sectional type with ventura shaped air passages arranged to secure correct air distribution in fuel bed. The design of the tuyeres minimizes the possibility of clinkers forming and adhering to their sides. The correct amount of air passes out of the back of the tuyeres to complete combustion.

FAN. The fan is carefully balanced and especially designed for quiet operation. The shape, position and arrangement of the blades is determined after years of experimentation and represent the latest development in fan design.

AIR CONTROL. Patented, micrometer adjustment, stream lined Air Control permits the exact amount of air to be supplied to the fuel bed at the proper static pressure by changing the effective width of the fan. The entrance to the fan and the air duct are unobstructed by dampers, thereby eliminating surging of the air supply and uneven static pressures. The patented Mabury-Combustioneer Air Control minimizes the electric power consumption.

GAS BACK ELIMINATOR. Air at fan pressure is introduced into the retort end of the coal feed tube from the air chamber, thereby preventing gas from being forced back through the hopper. The design eliminates long pipes which might stop up with coal.

SHEET STEEL PARTS. Hopper, air duct and other sheet steel parts are made of heavy, rust-resisting, copper-bearing steel. The side of the hopper toward the boiler is ventilated. Two sheets of heavy gauge steel are used with a dead air space between. This construction prevents over heating of the rear sheet in contact with the coal and increases the life. Hopper is hinged to the heavy cast iron base and can conveniently be tipped to either side to facilitate cleaning of fires. Coal capacity approximately 600 lbs.

COAL FEED WORM. Mabury-Combustioneer "Truflite" coal feed worms are made of special formula chrome-manganese steel. Metal patterns are screwed out of the mould guaranteeing perfectly true flights throughout entire length of worm.

LONG LIFE. The model 15 Heavy Duty Mabury-Combustioneer is of extra heavy construction throughout. It has been designed for the owner who considers low yearly operating cost more important than low purchase price.

Dear Mr. McKenzie:

On the strength of reports received from Mr. T. J. Arnall, Boiler Inspector of the Public Works Dept., and after consultation with him, acting upon his advice, I have asked for quotations from the companies who have been visiting the school in connection with Automatic Stokers for the boilers, which quotations are herewith enclosed. I am also enclosing copy of specifications given me by Inspector Arnall, a copy of which was enclosed in my letter to each company and their quotations were governed thereby.

The Sumner Iron Works are, I notice, slightly higher than Kolelectric, and Mabury Engineering Works is very much lower which denotes inferior quality or workmanship and I am inclined, therefore, to eliminate their quotation asking for the consideration of the Sumner Iron Works, reasons being that the Vancouver Island Coals Ltd., who have been responsible for considerably lowering our cost of heating, recommends these people as very reliable and will install into it the best of workmanship and material, they also have a service-man on the road.

It is a well-known fact that no matter how careful the resident engineer may be it is humanly impossible for him to keep an even temperature throughout the building and we find that the northwest end is very hard to heat entirely, and I find in doing so that the remainder of the building is heated to excess. Thermostats in this part of the building would govern the distributed heat and would therefore give us more uniformity. It is also a well-known fact that by doing this we would be able to use a less costly coal thereby saving considerably in the cost of heating operations; in fact the Automatic Stoker people maintain that over a period of three years their installation would be paid for in savings on the coal bill.

The District Medical Inspector has just paid us a visit and asks that temperatures be taken in the classrooms and in other parts of the building where uniformity cannot be held and which we have here-to-fore done. I find a considerable variance and find it im-
possible to hold an even temperature.

It would appear that the installation of Automatic Stokers would benefit the school in more ways than one and would eliminate the necessity for a man to stay on duty for necessarily long hours during the extreme cold. Occasionally I have had to put on a second man which also adds to the cost and which would be eliminated by Automatic Stokers.

You have, I presume, a copy of Mr. Arnall's report and can see for yourself that he strongly recommends this change and, personally, I feel that the school would be very grateful for this benefit and would do all I could to facilitate such installations in taking care of men and hauling of material.

I trust you will not feel that I have stepped too fast in asking for and forwarding these quotations. I feel, that if the Department should see fit to make this expenditure or allow the school to take care of the same out of coal purchase savings, it would be a very worth while consideration.

Yours very sincerely,

I do not like the way in which the girls' dormitories are open to invasion from the fire escapes. This matter has been mentioned in a previous report. A suggestion was made by Mr. Phelan that Bells should be fixed up, but the Principal did not agree.

I have suggested to the Principal that the Manual Training Class fix LIGHT hasps on the doors of the dormitories opening to fire escapes, and that these hasps be locked with VERY SMALL padlocks about the size of a 25¢ piece. Further that the spare keys for these locks be kept in glass fronted boxes at the sides of the doors, and proper fire axes be also kept in glass fronted boxes near the doors.

The Principal thoroughly agrees with me that this would solve the difficulty. It will be remembered that the proper protection of the girls was one of the points brought up by Indians when they refused to send their children here. They claim that there is no proper protection of the girls in their dormitories. The above suggestion will solve the difficulty without increasing the danger in case of a fire. I would ask the Department to write the Principal with regard to this matter.
Ottawa, November 18, 1936.

Rev. Sir:

The Department understands from Mr. Inspector Barry's report that no steps have yet been taken to prevent anyone entering the girls' dormitories from the fire escapes. Mr. Barry also states that at the time of his visit it was suggested that light hasps be placed on the doors and these hasps locked with small padlocks. The Department is not prepared to approve this suggestion.

Please arrange to have each door leading from the girls' dormitories to a fire escape attached by wire to an electric bell. It should be arranged that this bell will ring in the supervisor's room in the event of anyone opening the door to the fire escape. This is considered the best method of preventing anyone from entering the dormitories, and, at the same time, leaves the doors unlocked so that they may be immediately opened in the event of fire.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Mr. Agent Strang.

Yours truly,
