Dear Sir:

Re Heating St. George's Residential School,
Lytton, B. C.

Major Mackay, the Indian Commissioner, asked me to make a special report on the heating conditions of the above school during my last inspection. I now beg to submit the following report.

From what I can find out, there has been trouble with the heating ever since the school was built. Several changes have been made from time to time so that it is very hard to arrive at a decision without making a proper investigation when the plant is operating under the full load condition. At present I can only give you hearsay evidence, and form an opinion on that.

First, there is no doubt that the two boilers are not large enough to properly heat the school during very cold weather. I was informed that after the school was built, a new Chapel building was constructed, and was supposed to have been heated from a boiler in the school. Then this was found impossible to do, an engineer from an eastern firm was called in and he stated that the two boilers were not large enough to heat the school, much less the Chapel. He recommended that a new boiler be purchased and installed in another building, now used for a manual training school, and the new mains leading from the old plant cut. This was done, and now neither plant is giving satisfaction, and being so far apart makes the operation quite a difficult matter for one engineer to operate.

Another change made was in the heating of the Residency. This part was always cold, and I was told that a new steam main was taken from the boiler to lead direct to it. This was a good solution, but upon following it up I found that the new branch was taken from the steam main in the wing of the school nearest the Residency. There was also an air eliminator installed close to where the branch was taken off. Naturally seeing that this branch would be the one offering the least resistance, most of the steam would travel towards it, and the other wing, not having an air eliminator, would not get much steam until the pressure in the boilers was great enough to overcome the air pressure in the mains and force it out at the traps. This required steam pressure to be very high to obtain during cold weather, and the boilers would fired as they are at present. This condition can be considerably relieved if Automatic air valves are installed on the radiators on the end of the runs. I would say from 8 to 10 radiators would require valves.

The above is the situation as near as I can give it.
Reedy: The question has been suggested to install Automatic Underfeed Stokers in the main plant. From my experience I would say that they would increase the efficiency of the boilers to such an extent that it would relieve the underheating of the buildings as well as reduce the fuel bill considerably.

I would also like consideration to be given to the following suggestions, which, if carried out, would in my opinion remove these difficulties. That is, to take out the new boiler now used to heat the chapel and manual training and bring it up to the main boiler room and install it on the same lines as the other boilers. This will give more steam capacity. Install a wood-burning hot air furnace in the basement of the chapel and also one in the basement of the manual training school, as both of these buildings will require intermittent heat.

Then, with the two boilers equipped with stokers, and the new boiler hand-fired, this would give an additional boiler in case anything went wrong with the power line during severe weather.

Install automatic air valves on the above-mentioned radiators. This suggestion would also bring the whole heating plant of the school under one control point. The radiators now used in the chapel could then be used in various parts of the school where required.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall

T. J. Arnall,
Engineer, P.E.
Dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to refer to your 165-0-5 of the 25th of April and June 29th regarding the heating plant of St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton.

An examination of the heating system at this school was recently made by Mr. T.J. Arnall, Engineer of the Federal Department of Public Works and his report with recommendations are forwarded herewith. Mr. Arnall made his examination of the heating plant during the month of August when the system was inactive but he has inspected similar plants when in operation so that with his knowledge of such units, together with the information supplied by Principal Lett, the engineer in charge and the Agent, it is considered Mr. Arnall would be in a position to make the recommendations embodied in his report.

Briefly, Mr. Arnall recommends as follows:

(1) The installation of Underfeed Automatic Stokers to fuel the two boilers of the main plant.

(2) The removal of the boiler heating the manual training department and Chapel to the main building and its addition to the main heating system as an auxiliary and emergency unit.

(3) The heating of the manual training department and Chapel by separate wood burning hot air furnaces.

(4) The installation of automatic air valves on 8 or 10 radiators.

These recommendations merit consideration and, I am inclined from my own personal investigation of the situation at the school, to agree that the suggested changes would go a long way to increase the efficiency of the heating unit to what is necessary for St. George's school.

Automatic Underfeed Stokers have been installed at Coqualeetza Indian Residential School and have greatly improved the heating situation for that school. Stokers have also been installed in a number of the Federal public buildings in this province and, I understand, have been found highly satisfactory.

An estimate of the cost of the stokers, hot air furnaces, automatic air valves, removal of boiler and installations, is placed at three thousand (3000) dollars. Mr. Arnall assures me that this work can be undertaken within the next four or five weeks without interfering to any important extent with the conduct of the school or endangering the welfare of the pupils and staff.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

In accordance with instructions contained in your 165-0-5 of June 23rd, I examined the dormitories in the St. George's Indian Residential School to ascertain if certain changes could be made to permit of wash and bathroom accommodation being provided in the present dormitory space.

I found that this could be done and, although such alterations would probably necessitate some readjustment of the present sleeping arrangements, the Reverend Principal assured me that this could be done without much difficulty and would not mean that the bed cots would be crowded as other space, not being at present used for sleeping quarters, could be utilized for this purpose if necessary.

Four dormitories would be involved in the proposed alterations; two on the first floor and two on the second floor. The estimated cost of the proposed alterations is approximately $3,000. Dear Sir: Re: Installation of Stokers, Hot Air Furnaces, and alterations to Heating Plant at St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B. C.

On January 13th, 1938, I made an inspection of the above plant and now beg to report as follows:

Automatic Stokers:
Two Model D "Iron Fireman" Automatic Underfeed Coal Stokers have been installed in a first class manner. They are operating very efficiently and giving a good CO₂% and a very low slack heat loss.

Hot Air Furnaces:
There have been two steel welded hot air furnaces installed, one in the Chapel and one in the Utility Building. The one in the Utility Building is giving every satisfaction. The one in the Chapel, although heating the building very comfortably in zero weather, could be improved by either installing a small fan in the long run which discharges near the Chancel, or by reducing the air flow from the outlet in the west end of the Nave. These improvements can be done by the school staff with very little expense.

Main Heating Plant:
This plant is a low steam pressure having a gravity wet return, which has a slow circulation and is generally troubled with air pockets which prevent the steam circulating freely in the radiators.

The proper solution would be to install a Condensate Pump in the boiler room, this pump to be connected in such a manner that it can be used in conjunction with the present returns, that is, during peak loads in the daytime and very severe weather, the pump can be used, but during light loads, nights and during mild weather, the present return system can be used. The cost of pump installed would be approximately $550.00.

Another method can be adopted to remove most of the air from the radiators, that is, to install a small air relief valve on the air locked radiators. This I suggested in my previous report, and has been done in some parts of the building where much better circulation has been obtained, but there will be 15 or 16 more required to complete it.
I also found that the system was out of balance, that is, some of the radiators were getting too much steam and others not enough. This can be remedied by inserting orifice discs in the steam valves at the radiator. I explained to the Principal of the school and to the Engineer the method of making and installing these discs. I was informed whilst at the school, that conditions this season were at least 40% better than they were before, if my suggestions for the air valves and discs were carried out, more improvements will be noted.

The steam boiler formerly used in the utility building, and which is proposed to be installed in the main boiler room, has not yet been removed, but this is going to be done as soon as time permits. When this is done the school will have a compact steam plant.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

T.J. Arnall
Engineer, D.F.W.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Fraser Valley, B.C.

When this school was erected in the summer of 1927, washroom and bathroom accommodation was not provided adjacent to the dormitories. We have received innumerable complaints from the Inspector, the Medical Officer and the Principal, with reference to this defect, and it has been pointed out on several occasions that the present arrangement of the building is detrimental to the children's health as well as being very inconvenient.

Commissioner MacKay was instructed some time ago to visit St. George's Residential School and report what alterations he considered should be made.

He visited the school and found that in order to install washroom and bathroom accommodation adjacent to the dormitories, alterations would be required to the four dormitories; two on the first floor and two on the second.

Commissioner MacKay consulted Mr. H. J. Davies, Contractor, 619 St. Paul Street, Kamloops, B.C., with reference to the alterations, and I enclose copy of a tender which was submitted to Commissioner MacKay by

Mr. Davies -
Mr. Davies. In his recent letter Commissioner MacKay states that the proposed changes in the dormitories were discussed with Mr. R. A. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, during the latter's recent visit to Vancouver, and he approved carrying out the work on which Mr. Davies quotes.

You will note that Mr. Davies' quotation is $4,350.00. Funds for this purpose are available in Trust Account No. 460. As you are aware, the New England Company have been associated for many years with the Department in the operation of this school, and they contribute an amount of $5,000.00 a year towards the cost of alterations and repairs. This money is kept in a special Trust Account and used as necessary. At the present time there is a credit balance in this account of $10,755.44.

As the St. George's School is now closed for summer holidays, it is a convenient time to make any improvements, and I should therefore appreciate receiving the approval of the Honourable the Minister to proceed with the work contained in the tender of Mr. Davies and recommended by Indian Commissioner MacKay.

Director.

Sir-

Other authorities on the subject say that an extension would not help matters.

Re: Carpenters Wages - Indian School,
Lytton, B.C.

Gentlemen:

We wrote you on January 5th, in reference to a communication we had received from the Minister of Labor with the request that you take up the matter of carpenters wages with him. This, you advise us has been done but we have received another letter from the Department urging that the difference in the wages be made up to $7.50 per day for each carpenter. We are, therefore, writing you to know what your attitude is in the matter. From our former letter it must be perfectly obvious to you that it is impossible for us to pay the increased wage out of our own funds.

We certainly followed the letter of your specification in figuring the job and went beyond the spirit of your specification in paying the men $7.00 per day instead of $6.50, being the amount on which we based our estimates.

If, however, the government desires that a higher wage shall be paid than that which we could reasonably estimate, then we think the government, through the department involved, will surely have to make up that difference. It makes no difference at all to us how much we have to pay the men so long as we have been able to figure that amount into our estimates, and if you feel like allowing the difference to the men, we certainly will be pleased to distribute the amount when ratified by you or give you all the names and the amount of time worked so that it could be handled direct from your department, if you so wish.
In reference to the second clause in the Minister of Labor's letter, copy of which we enclose, he states that all the men who are employed have been brought from Vancouver. Would say it is possible that most of the men came from Vancouver, but, we did not bring them. They were hired on the job at Lytton, paying their own way there. It is only the fact that our head office is in Vancouver that Vancouver carpenters have easy access to us. Had we been contractors for Kamloops, for instance, this question never could have risen and we must maintain that we are in the same position.

The Minister of Labor refers to the Provincial Government building at Tranquill, on which they are paying $7.50 to carpenters. This, we understand, is quite true, but, you must note that the Tranquill contract was let quite a time after ours and in addition to that the Provincial Government took the precaution to state the amount of wages that were to be paid to carpenters, thus eliminating any necessity for the contractors to discover for themselves what rate was being paid in the district.

Trusting that you will either ratify the increased payment or take this matter up with the department of labor further and have it eliminated, which, we think, as a matter of fact would be the better plan as we must assure you that all men being hired on the job knew well the wages that were being paid and agreed to same without question.

We are

Yours truly,

ADKISON & DILL, LTD.,

per (Sgd.) J. C. Dill

Gentlemen:

Re: Carpenters' Wage Rate
Indian School, Lytton, B.C.

My attention has been directed to a communication which has been addressed by your firm to the Department of Indian Affairs in relation to the subject matter of my letter to you of the 27th ultimo. I have read the contents of your letter carefully and am sorry if your tender for the work was based on a lower rate of wages than you have found it necessary to pay. I note that you were not furnished until recently with a schedule of current wages rates which had been prepared by Mr. Harrison, our Fair Wages Officer at Vancouver.

The contract with your firm does not contain any fair wages schedule, but does contain a fair wages clause providing that all persons employed in the construction of the work shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed for the character or class of work in which they are respectively engaged, and if there be no current wages in such district, then fair and reasonable rates. The Fair Wages Officer who investigated the complaint in regard to the carpenters' wage rate on the Lytton school, found that the men of this trade who are employed have been brought from Vancouver and that Vancouver rates are applicable for carpenters as far east as Lytton and indeed are being paid a hundred miles further from Vancouver on work which is being done for the Provincial Government at Tranquille.

After giving consideration to the statements contained in your letter, I do not find any reason to change the direction which was given in my earlier communication, and would ask that this ruling be put into effect without further delay in accordance with the requirements of the Fair Wage Clause of your contract.

Gentlemen:

Re: Erection of Indian Residential School - Lytton, B.C.

My attention has been drawn to correspondence with reference to the rate of wages payable to carpenters employed by your firm under a contract with the Department of Indian Affairs for the erection of the above mentioned Indian residential school. The contract in question calls for the payment to mechanics, labourers, etc., of such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed. It is further declared that the minister of Labour may at any time and from time to time determine for the purpose of the contract what are the current or fair and reasonable rates of wages. In the present case enquiry has been made by the Fair Wages Officer of the Department of Labour which shows that the current rate of wages for carpenters is the same as that in Vancouver, namely, $7.50 per day, whereas it is represented to us that your firm is paying a rate of wages of $7.00 per day for this class of service.

Under the authority of the labour conditions of the contract, I am writing you to say that a rate of wages of $7.50 per day must be observed for carpenters on this building and that settlement must be made to individual carpenters who have received less than this rate for the amounts which may be severally due them, covering the full period of their employment.

I should be glad to have word that this ruling is being put into effect.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Peter Heenan

ADKISON & DILL, LIMITED

Vancouver, B.C., January 5, 1928.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Re: Erection of Indian Residential School - Lytton, B.C.

Gentlemen:

We enclose herewith copy of letter from the Minister of Labour to us in connection with the rate paid to carpenters on the above school and also copy of our letter in answer to this.

We wish here to advise that when figuring this building we enquired of the rates being paid to carpenters and other mechanics in that district and all up the line. We found that in Chilliwack they were paying from $5.50 to $6.50 per day. Kamloops being the largest centre actually in the Lytton district, we found that the wages paid carpenters were from $6.00 to $6.50 per day. We, therefore, figured our job at $6.50 for carpenters, believing that to be the proper rate to be paid. We found, however, about the time of starting this work that the men in Kamloops would soon be asking for a raise in wages to $7.00. We, therefore, started our work off at that price wishing to have no controversy in the matter. We are, therefore, as you will see, out fifty cents 50¢ per day on every carpenter we have employed on the job.

If the letter from the Department of Labour is to be followed and the men paid $7.50 per day, we think it will be only right that the department should pay this difference and not ourselves as we have already gone half way at a loss to ourselves.

We do not see, however, that the department can possibly be correct in their assumption that $7.50 should be paid in this district. It is true we found out only a few weeks ago that Mr. Harrison, the fair wage officer of Vancouver had struck a rate of wages for this work being practically that which is paid in Vancouver. We, however, at the time of figuring and not until a few weeks ago were not cognizant of that fact and there is no rate of wages stated in the
specifications or any of the papers coming from your department at the time of figuring this work, merely a reference to wages usually accepted in the district which we have followed and gone one better by paying the men 50¢ per day more than seemed right at that time and fully the amount which actually exists today in that district.

We ask that you will take this matter up with the Minister of Labour and if found necessary to pay the other 50¢ per day, we trust that you will make it up to us.

We assure you, however, this objection has not come from any of our men but is merely the work of an agitator in the City of Vancouver.

Trusting you will give this matter your immediate attention and greatly oblige

Yours truly,

ADRIAN & DILL, LTD.,
per (Sgd.) J. C. Dill.
Ottawa,
January 30, 1939.

The Honourable Mr. Lapoint,
Minister of Justice,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir;

Reviewing the correspondence in connection with our claim, I am moved to ask; is it really impossible for born and bred Canadian citizens to obtain justice from the Government without having to resort to court proceedings? We wonder that nations cannot settle their differences by arbitration but surely in our own country it can be done. It seems that every difference of opinion must be made a cause for contention instead of being looked into in a reasonable way and decided on its merits. I made my appeal to you direct because I thought surely in the Dept. of Justice we will at least get a hearing and I asked that a disinterested official or judge - apart from ourselves or the departments affected - be asked to go thoroughly in to all the evidence and give a decision. I left the matter entirely in your hands and stated that we would abide by such decision without further question. We do not wish to put the Government or ourselves to further expense in the matter, but the conditions of our affairs are such that a settlement is very urgent. I therefore beg that you will have our claim fairly dealt with as above requested and the adjudication will be accepted by us as final.

In closing I think there will be no betrayal of confidence when I tell you that Dr. Duncan Scott the former Supt. of Indian Affairs told the writer personally, when he was in Vancouver, that he did not feel that we had been justly dealt with at the time, also the fact remains that none of my statements that were written at the time, together with a signed declaration of all the men who worked on the job and received the extra pay, have ever been disproved or refuted.

Thanking you for your forbearance and soliciting some interest in our case

I am yours truly

J. C. Dill

Principal Lett has just reported that the return condensate pipe of the heating plant at St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C., is leaking and requires replacement. As the present installation runs under the cement floor and partitions for the full length of the school, repair and replacement of existing installation would involve the removal and replacement of cement flooring. In view of this it is suggested that further use of the present pipe be discontinued and that a new exposed pipe line with condensate pump in boiler room be installed at an estimated cost of three hundred (300) dollars. Dear Sir:

Answering yours, No:165-0-5, dated February 20/40, the cost in excess of the grant originally asked for was due to a forced change in the original plan of over-head return pipe to taking up the concrete floor and installation of box and pipe below floor level and again to the necessity of changing and re-insulating traps in different parts of the heating system. When I spoke of the excess cost of these changes, The Murray Plumbing & Heating Co., assured me that it would not be a great amount. I informed them that I had $300.00 with which to do the job.

I again, when I realized that the grant was being over expended, approached Murray's man and asked him to be careful not to over-run too much as I would have to care for the extra out of school funds. I had to, eventually, take the man off before he had finished his suggested work, expecting to have Mr. Arnall, Public Works Inspector, judge whether any more work was necessary. Mr. Arnall reported no need of any extra which we could not do ourselves. In the meantime I had Mr. Murray's bill and I was very surprised at the amount and informed Mr. Murray that he would have to wait for his money and so the matter stood.

Dear Sir:

I wish to place the following facts before you, with regard to my transactions with Mr. A. R. Lett, principal of St. George's Ind. Res. School, Lytton, B.C.

I have each year for the last nine years supplied Mr. Lett with 150 twelve-weeks old Barred Rock pullets. I have always endeavored to send him good stock, and he has apparently always been well satisfied; our relationship, accordingly, has ever been pleasant and cordial.

At the latter part of June, this year, I forwarded the usual consignment to Mr. Lett, the price being exactly $100.00.

On July 8th, Mr. Lett wrote acknowledging receipt of the shipment in good condition, adding: "Cheque will go forward for same during the month or first part of August."

Up to present date, the cheque mentioned has never been received. Since first September I have written...
Hazelbank Poultry Farm
Production-Bred Barred Rocks
Specializing in Pedigreed Eggs and Stock

R.R. 1 Aldergrove, B.C.

three times to Mr. Lett regarding the matter, but can get no reply from him. (Am enclosing copy of my third letter to Mr. Lett.)

Confidentially, I am of the opinion that Mr. Lett issued the cheque as he advised would be done, and that none of my letters have ever reached him.

I expect that whoever may be intercepting my letters will also know what became of the cheque that was intended to pay for the consignment of pullets.

My hearing is not sufficiently acute to carry on a conversation over the telephone, otherwise I would have tried to get Mr. Lett over "long distance".

So, I could think of no other alternative to enlisting your aid in straightening out this matter.

Dear Mr. Lott,

I wrote to you first week of Sept., with regard to the fact that I had not received cheque for the pullets I shipped to you latter part of June, and reminding you that your letter of July 8th stated that cheque will go forward during this month or first part of August.

As no reply was received to my letter of early September, I wrote to you again in similar strain, on Sept 17th, and surmising that probably my letter & your reply had gone astray in the mail, I forwarded my second letter under registered cover.

Two weeks have passed, and still there is no acknowledgment, and it seems futile for me to attempt further to obtain an accounting of our transaction by the usual methods of corresponding. Dear Sir:

Mr. N. Stewart, Acting Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, informs me that the problem of clothing for the boys and girls is a very pressing one as no clothes were ordered for them for this term, and their present clothing is practically in rags.

On the occasion of Inspector Barry's visit, Miss Jobling, the matron, and the Acting Principal discussed the matter with him and he thought it advisable that quotations be obtained on the actual cost of refitting each child with the necessary clothing for the present term.

These figures are now available. The complete outfit for the girls will amount to approximately $407.68 and for the boys, $328.00.

Mr. Stewart states that the question of dining room utensils is an urgent one. All utensils are apparently in poor condition and to replace them would require approximately $178.45.

I should be glad to receive authority to proceed with the purchase of the clothing required at the school. With reference to the dining room utensils, I may say that I consider the purchase of such articles might well be left until the new Principal has taken charge of the school.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

Re St. George's Indian Residential School.

I have received a letter from the Reverend Mr. Hives, newly appointed Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, requesting the purchase of muresco and kalsomine brushes to carry out certain redecorating of the Principal's residence at the school. I purchased the materials, with the exception of the kalsomine brushes, and had same shipped to the school in care of Mr. Stewart, requesting that the instructions issued by Mr. Hives with respect to the decorating be carried out. I hesitated about the purchase of three kalsomine brushes in view of the excessive cost of a good quality brush for this purpose and in case some brushes might be available at the school to do the necessary work. If there were none available at the school suitable for the work I suggested to Mr. Stewart that he endeavor to purchase a brush locally.

I should appreciate being advised if it is the Department's wish that applications of this kind be first submitted to the Department for approval. I may say that I anticipate that Mr. Hives will wish to purchase new furnishings, etc., for the residence and possibly other items for the school immediately on his arrival here and I should like to know what provision has been made to meet expenditures of this kind. An early reply would be appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant the Department will forward to the Principal of the St. George's Residential School, from New England Company funds, an amount of $176.60 to cover the cost of the new tables in the students' dining room.

Dear Mr Hoey:

It is my unpleasant duty to report to you a fire, which occurred yesterday, and which destroyed our pig house, along with twenty-two pigs, most of which were ready for the butcher. It is a big loss to us, and one which must be replaced as soon as possible.

With the help of the entire staff and the boys, we were able to save the barns, but we had great difficulty in doing so, and we had to work very hard and constantly all afternoon until evening. There was a high wind blowing, as there generally is here, and the building was only about sixty feet from the barns. Had the wind turned a little, we could never have saved them. We seldom ever get any rain in this part of the country, and so the wooden structures are ready to explode into flame as soon as they come into contact with fire.

The fire was no doubt caused by a spark from the feed cooker, located in the building. This source of fire hazard should never have existed, but like a lot of other foolish ideas, which have been allowed to exist here, it was not adjusted in time.

It is a very serious loss to us. Especially the loss of the pigs, which were ready to help out in food and revenue. In many respects, the removal of the building is a good thing. For although it was an expensive one, it was much too near the main school building, and was therefore a nuisance in respect to sanitation. It bred swarms of flies, and produced terrible odours. Also it was not conveniently built.

It will cost one thousand dollars to replace it, and I would like to build a properly constructed pig house, conveniently and in safe proximity to the main
building. We can do all the work ourselves if we have the material. The biggest part of which would be the cost of cement.

I would urgently recommend that the sum of up to one thousand dollars be spent for this purpose if that sum is available.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Hives:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 25th instant, in which you intimate that the piggery at the St. George's School was completely destroyed by fire on August 24.

It is indeed disturbing in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves to learn of the destruction of this building. We have been reminded recently by the Purchasing Division that certain supplies, including building materials, are becoming increasingly difficult to secure. It is my hope, therefore, that you will experience no difficulty in securing the supplies necessary for the construction of the new building.

I am sending forward a cheque for $1,000.00 from the funds contributed by the New England Company and you are authorized to proceed with the construction of the building. It is scarcely necessary to emphasize that the cost of the building itself should be kept down to the lowest possible figure. When I think of the sacrifices the people of England are making at this time it almost breaks my heart to accept these funds for the upkeep and maintenance of our school buildings.

May 6, 1943

Dear Sir:

While Dr. Moore, of Ottawa, was here recently, the matter of our milk production and consumption was discussed. Quite frequently, when pupils are ill, and the doctor finds it difficult to diagnose, the milk is blamed; although our cows are well and carefully looked after, and our milk is carefully taken care of. Also the cows are tested for T.B. regularly. At one time a Veterinary Surgeon made a monthly visit from Vancouver to attend and inspect the cows, but really we cannot afford such an expense, and his services were discontinued.

To do away with any uncertainty regarding the safety of using our milk supply, I would recommend that a pasteurization system be installed. The cost of this installed would be not more than one thousand dollars, and would have a capacity of fifty gallons, which amount would be sufficient for this institution. If the cost of this had to be taken from the New England Company funds, I do not know of any better way of using it at the present time. Dr. Moore assured me he would endorse such a project, and would be willing for help to come from his Service if necessary.

I would also refer to letter No. I-I-3 from the Director, and relative to Special Grant of $10.00 per capita pupils for the year 1942. Our attendance for that year, according to the Audit Report was 156. I would be very much obliged if this Special Grant could be available for us to use now. I have sent for, and am expecting two car loads of coal immediately; and two more next month; so that our next Winter's supply will be on hand. This will entail a cost of over $1400.00 by the time it is in the coal bins.

Will you kindly see what you can do with these two
important matters.

Yours faithfully,

Chas. F. [signature]

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to a request of the Principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School for an amount of $1000.00 to install a milk pasteurization system. While I agree that such installations may be very desirable, at the same time it is difficult to understand why the Principal should decide to install one this year when both material and labour for such installations are needed for more necessary purposes. It might be presumed that the Principal is just looking for another method of spending the grant made by the New England Company and I should appreciate your again reminding him that there is no assurance that this payment is going to continue indefinitely. The Principal should review this matter very carefully and, if he still feels that it is absolutely necessary to make this installation, another letter can be sent for our consideration.

With reference to the second paragraph of your letter, a special grant at the rate of $10.00 per capita was paid from the appropriation for Indian education to all Indian residential schools for the year 1942. You were advised regarding this payment in circular letter dated March 26, 1943. However, no such payment was made either to the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ont., or the St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, B.C. Both of these schools are specially favoured by receiving payments from New England Company funds and consequently the special grant was not paid to either of them. With regard to the St. George's School, an amount of $4,575.00 was paid from New England Company
funds during the year 1942. I understand, of course, that some of this amount was in connection with the old debts but, with the amount provided for these deducted, the Principal received very substantial financial assistance and, as a matter of fact, a great deal more than any other Indian residential school in Canada.

Dear Sir:

Sometime ago I received a letter from the Director saying that the Residential Schools would be receiving a Special per capita Grant of ten dollars for the year 1942. On applying for this grant, I was informed that St. George's School, along with another were excepted, because they receive financial help from the New England Company.

My reason for applying for this Special per capita Grant at this time was to buy our supply of fuel for next Winter. We are being urged to do this, and warned of the difficulties we may encounter if we are not prepared with our fuel situation. I am very anxious to secure our supply.

Fuel prices have advanced $5% during the past year along with pretty well everything else, including salaries and wages. But fuel is something we cannot do without.

A car load of coal cost approximately $375.00 by the time it is in our bins. We require four car loads, and I would like to secure it as soon as possible. One car load arrived a few days ago, and I expect another one shortly.

Will you kindly state our case to Ottawa, and recommend that a cheque for the amount of $1500.00 be sent to us for the purpose of buying fuel for next Winter. And that this amount be taken from the New England Company funds. If required, I will forward receipted accounts showing that the amount is actually used for the purpose of buying our fuel supply.

Believe me, sir, I would not apply for this if I did not think it absolutely necessary. But in view of
the warnings we have received, and the serious situation of last Winter, makes it imperative that we secure our supply as soon as possible. And also, in view of the advanced cost of living, I find it extremely difficult to meet our financial obligations on the per capita grant.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

A few years ago, a small frame building was constructed, for the purpose of accommodating the cannery equipment. The building was very poorly constructed, and had there been a fairly heavy fall of snow during any winter since its construction, would, no doubt have caved in. It was built near to the electric light and power transformer. In fact, in order to save the trouble of moving the transformer, the roof of the building was made very flat, and the transformer lodges against and on the roof.

This creates a hazard, which has been pointed out to me by electricians as a very serious one. The building is convenient to the boys' playground, and boys have a propensity for climbing on building, even though they are punished for doing so a dozen times in a day. This they do, and I am afraid they will one day play around with the transformer, and either be electrocuted or cause serious damage.

This hazard could be eliminated by pulling down the poorly built cannery, and erecting another in close proximity, but a safe distance from the transformer. Mr Coleman, Inspector from the Vancouver office was here yesterday and took a snap shot of the situation.

To pull down and reconstruct this building would cost approximately two hundred dollars. We could do the work ourselves as part of the Manual training programme, but we should require extra material.

Will you kindly recommend that this matter be looked after.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Re: St. George's School Irrigation.

With respect to your inquiry of November 20 in connection with the above, I wish to inform you that Mr. Warren made an inspection of the irrigation works and interviewed the principal regarding the maintenance of the system.

Mr. Warren found the works in fair condition. There is a considerable length of small wooden flumes and a number of wood pipes across fields, roadways, etc. All require some repairs. It is not believed that the bill of material contained in Mr. Hives request of November 15 is excessive and that it all could be usefully employed except possibly the creosote which is not necessary. Mr. Warren suggested that Mr. Hives order 200 lbs of Barrett's plastic elastigum and 50 lbs. of ships oakum for repairing leaky flume joints; also that additional supports be provided for the flume boxes, that is, a 12' or 14' flume box should have a support on the middle as well as both ends. It is thought that the lumber can be secured from the local sawmill.

A full report on the irrigation system will be forwarded at an early date. The information contained herein is substantially the same as will appear in the report to be submitted and is offered now in order not to delay unduly the securing of the necessary materials.

The work of repairs could readily be undertaken by the school authorities as has been done in the past and at much less cost for labour than would be the case if supervision of this service should be required.

G.E. Webb
District Chief Engineer
Per: W. C. Warren.

Dear Sir:

Will you kindly give consideration to the following recommendations, and forward the same on to the Department. They represent some of our most urgent needs; and if there are sufficient funds in the New England Grant to pay for these, I do not know of any better way of spending the money.

Swimming Pool: You can bear me out when I say that during the Summer this is a very hot place. Yet there is no natural safe swimming place nearer than fifty miles away. Years ago a small valley was dammed up with cement, in which the boys spent many delightful hours; but the cement has given way, and the swimming hole has disappeared. I would like to put this place into proper repair again. In fact, with a little more work than was put into it before, this place could be made into a very good swimming pond for the pupils. We should require 300 sacks of cement. This would cost, including freight, $350.00.

Dairy: At the present time, we have a building used as a dairy, situated near to the cow barn. The Herdman with the boys attend to the care of the milk, making butter, and washing dairy equipment. In spite of all the care we may exercise, Indian boys are not to be trusted in the safe and sanitary handling of dairy equipment, and the disposal of milk. Since coming to Lytton, I have noticed that although nearly all these Indians have cows, very few ever milk cows, or use cows' milk. If they use milk at all, it is the canned article from the store. I think it is a great pity, for the pupils must miss it greatly during vacation time, or after they are discharged from school; for they have it three times a day while they are here in school. I would like to change our system, and provide for a position of Dairy Maid Supervisor, who should teach the girls the Dairy business; so that after the boys have done the milking, the milk is delivered to the dairy, and the Dairy Maid Supervisor then take charge of it; teaching the girls how to make butter and cheese. If this were done, I feel sure the girls would then carry on after they leave school in their own homes. We
should require a properly constructed Dairy located near to the main building, so that it would be convenient for the girls, and also could be connected with the steam pipe from the high pressure steam boiler. I estimate that this would cost $1,200. It should be constructed of cement, and if funds would allow, have the inside walls lined with white tile. The Manual Instructor would look after the construction of the building with his class of boys.

Irrigation pipe: We have to depend entirely on irrigation for the watering of our crops and pastures. A considerable amount of wood pipe was laid underground for the purpose of conveying the water. This pipe has become decayed, with the result that some of the fields are becoming useless. Wood pipe, such as is used, is bought for 72¢s per foot. I would like to put in 600 ft. this fall. This would mean an expenditure of $450.00.

Playground equipment. This part of the school life is very important; for the pupils must make this their home, and we want them to be happy. We could help in this matter if we could spend $400.00 on new equipment.

Repairs to cars and trucks: During the war years, very little has been done to vehicles. I am not asking for any new ones, but I would like to have our truck, station wagon and car put into good repair. We should require $1,000.00 for this purpose.

Will you please place this matter before the Department as soon as possible, so that we may get to work on looking after these things in the near future. I have looked over the estimates made above very carefully; and I assure you that we would do our best to use all money to the best advantage.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I wish to place before you three very urgent needs, the first of which is causing us grave concern and much inconvenience.

It is in connection with our hot water heating for domestic hot water. Over a month ago the hot water jacket ceased to function on account of the alkaline deposit filling up the channels in the jacket heater. It seems impossible to avoid this trouble under the circumstances; and when it happens, the jacket heater bursts and becomes useless. After this happened, in order to supply the building with hot water, we had to connect the high pressure steam boiler with a coil in the tank. This did effectual work until two days ago, when the flues in the boiler leaked so badly, we had to discontinue. We are now heating the water by means of one of the low pressure boilers used for heating the building. This method is unsatisfactory, slow and harmful to the system.

We have a low pressure steam boiler, not in use, and standing, dismantled, under the Manual Shop. This boiler was at one time used for heating the Chapel and the building it is now in; but owing to the fact of it being expensive to maintain, hot air furnaces were installed in the Chapel and the Manual Shop. I have been told by the Provincial Engineer that this boiler could be used for the purpose of supplying hot water through the main building, by installing it in the boiler room of the main building, and connecting it with the steam coil in the water tank. This would necessitate buying a pump to force the condensate water back into the boiler. It is important that this should be done in order to avoid the alkaline deposit forming in the boiler. There would also be required certain fittings and aquastat control. I have made careful inquiries regarding these extras, and in all the cost would not exceed $400.00. We would do all the work of installing the system.

Last December, I engaged a young man as Manual
Instructor. This young man had just recently been discharged from the army, where he had been Carpenter Instructor for three years. He had recently been married, and his wife is now holding a teachership on my staff, where she is doing excellent work. I am very anxious indeed to hold these young people, as they are both desirable acquisition to the life of this institution. But, in order to that, they must have a home to live in. We have several cottages for the married people. The one they will have to occupy is unfit to live in. The inside of the building has no lining on the studding. To finish it off will require 4000 ft. of shiplap, and 2000 ft. of finishing material. Also a sink, some plumbing, and electric wiring. The total cost for this material would be $340.00. We can do the work, but we have not funds to buy the material.

Our water main is a wood pipe, and is one thousand feet in length and six inches in diameter. We have had to replace three sections of this pipe during the last two years. It is leaking in numerous places, and appears as if the pipe line is in a state of collapse, and should be renewed as soon as possible. I asked for and received prices of six inch wood pipe from the manufacturers yesterday. The price is 64.50 per 100 ft. If pressure creosoted, as they recommend it would be 10.50 extra. I understand that this process doubles the life of the pipe.

Will you kindly place these important matters before the Department at your earliest convenience.

Yours faithfully,

Principal.

Dear Sir:

I wish to place before you certain matters, which have become very difficult problems in the work connected with our institution; and which are continually being forced on my mind, causing grave concern about the future maintaining and financing of our work.

During the years of war, we had to, more or less, mark time, with the result that very little progress has been made in the matter of development or extension. In fact, it has at times, seemed extremely difficult to maintain and keep in order what equipment we now possess. But, I feel the time has now come, when we must progress by improving and modernizing our equipment and our methods, or else be subject to adverse criticism from the general public, as well as from the people whose lives we are trying to improve. Moreover, I feel we are at present actually leaving ourselves open to adverse criticism and even ridicule unless ways and means are provided by the Department to improve and modernize our methods and equipment capable of coping with present day problems and ideas. I know we are all looking to the time when our problem regarding training and welfare of Indians will be solved; but at the rate we are going, it will take a long time. Comparing methods and equipment with those of any Provincial system of education and training, we lag far behind. And yet, ours is the only project of education for which the Dominion Government is responsible. We have not even an Inspector to visit our schools and classrooms, and to give us advice, encouragement or profitable criticism. We do leave ourselves open to ridicule, and such a condition makes it very difficult obtaining proficient and enterprising teachers.

The Indians are becoming more and more persistent in their demands to be, not only released from all restraining influence; but also to be given financial aids of tremendous proportions. I am of the opinion that they are not ready to be released from the restraining influences exercised by the Department; and they certainly are not yet ready to entrusted with responsibility that accompanies the spending of large sums of money. Yet their voice is ever increasing in volume;
and public opinion is becoming more and more aroused, and spurred on by those who are looking for self aggrandizement. We know we have the welfare of the Indians at heart. We have the feeling that we know what is best for these people, because we have studied them and understand them. But we do require new life and zeal and interest. We do require more backing from the Dominion Government. The constant struggle to make ends meet; and at the same time to feed and clothe our children properly on the meagre grant allowed us, is a strain that could and should be eliminated. Instead of which, the strain and the worry remains, giving one the impression that our main object in life is to curtail expenses. I am afraid this idea and this impression is all too evident to all who pass by.

There is talk of a change in the policy of caring for and educating Indian children. I have been in the residential school work for over thirty years; and although I am fully aware it is not the ideal system, yet I am of the opinion that it will remain for sometime, for there will be, for sometime, many problem children to be taken care of.

The property on which the school stands, comprises 396 acres. About two thirds of this is of such rough terrain as to be looked upon as waste land. A great deal of money has been spent on developing the land to its present state; but the work that has been done is of such a temporary and makeshift nature, much of it has fallen into decay, so that the whole system of fencing and irrigation requires renewing and making safe and permanent.

Our farm should be the centre of instruction and attraction to all the Indians of this district. And I have no hesitation in saying that it could be made so if the property were developed, improved and set in order. This can only be done by the aid of proper modern machinery and equipment; for it is only with the aid of modern machinery that the waste land can be brought to the state where it can be irrigated.

Our farm is extremely vital to our living. We depend entirely on its produce for fruit, vegetables, cereals and cow feed; and we certainly could not operate without it. Moreover, there is not a better fruit country in B.C.; and if we had our land planned properly, we could quite easily plant two thousand apple, peach, apricot, plum and cherry trees on its terraced slopes that would greatly supplement our present income, and make us become more self-supporting; as well as to make us the centre of attraction and instruction.

Our fences need to be pulled down and new ones built in some systematic order. Our whole system of irrigation
requires a complete re-survey and re-adjustment. We would require two thousand fruit trees to plant. Our buildings which have not seen paint for over ten years, and are in a very shabby condition, require a two coat job. The roof of our main building is leaking in places, and requires a thorough going over. Our water main leaks in many places. This is a wooden pipe, and has had to be replaced in several sections during the last two years. Our plumbing requires a lot of replacements. Our floors, which are all fir wood, require renewing. To do all this work, and buy the necessary machinery and equipment, such as a bull dozer and other machinery, I estimate would represent an outlay of twenty thousand dollars. But I assure you, sir, we would have something worth while to show for it. Something the general public would not ridicule. Something that would be constructive, instructive and attractive. And something which the Department would be proud of.

It seems to me, that in order to progress these days, money has to be spent. There was a time when we could pick and shovel our way along with these people, and lead them on. That way has become extinct, and we should recognize that fact. I would like to see our work take on a new lease of life.

After reading the above over, I would be very much obliged, sir, if you could see fit to endorse what I have written.

Yours faithfully,

Principal.

(g) (Cont'd) school at food locker room. Here it branches into 2 - 2" iron pipes; one for fire line under full pressure of 74 pounds per square inch, the other through reduction valve to 54 pounds per square inch for domestic use.

In regard to Item 1 - condition of 6" pipe line. Three lengths of pipe have been replaced in the past two years, and the wood in these was apparently quite poor. However, a careful examination of the growth along the pipe line would indicate no further leaks. A check was made of the pipe in one place and the wood fibre and wire binding were still in good condition. According to the manufacturers (Canadian Wood Pipe and Tank Company) a pipe line like this could be expected to last 25 to 30 years, or a further five to ten years. However, they pointed out that the odd stave may rot and leak, and hence require replacement of such a length from time to time.

Recommendation

In regard to Item 1, pipe line from reservoir to school, it is recommended that the pipe line be left as it is, a yearly check be made for signs of leaks and 25 feet of 6" double wrapped wood stave pipe be kept on hand at the school, together with instructions on how to replace pipe. This pipe would be in the following lengths: one each of 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 feet, which combination will replace any length from 3 to 18 feet.

Cost of pipe, plus couplings, plus four split couplings would be $40. delivered to school. Labour
for such emergency replacement would have to be obtained by the school authorities.

In regard to Items 2 and 3 - sanitary and silting conditions. There are three springs shown on sketch 2 as E1, E2, and E3. These springs are shown as 2 on exhibit A Water Rights sketch with Final Licence No. 3140, order No. 2506. The water from these springs flows through a steep ravine heavily wooded with poplar, alder, willow, briers, and underbrush. The soil is a light clay and silt.

The flow from each spring is as follows:

E1 - 1" over 90° V-notch weir full contraction = 1.96 gpm = .0052 cfs.

E2 - 2 9/16" over 6" rectangular weir full contraction = .16 cfs.

E3 - about 1/8 times E1 by estimate = .008 cfs.

Sanitary conditions at E2 are not good, especially when the water supply is for some 200 people. One hundred square feet of ground has been cleared close to the spring, and is used by an Indian family resident on the property, for laundry and bathing area. Water is heated over a small grate beside the stream. The used water is then turned out beside and into the stream.

On July 15, Mr. Hives, Principal of the School, told the son of this Indian (a man about 21 years) the importance of keeping the water supply clean. The man replied that he did not know that such was harmful as he was under the impression that the school had a purifier. However, he said he would keep the water supply clean. There was no change
in the next few days, and Mr. Indian Agent Strang saw the conditions of this spring on July 18. He will endeavour to arrange that this area be kept clean.

Spring E1 is 46 feet north of E2, and was untouched by man.

Spring E3 is about 200 feet south of E2, and part of the flow has been diverted to a drinking trough for animals.

Sometimes the tail water from irrigation flows into the ravine above the present intake; such was the case on early morning of July 17, causing the water to be very muddy.

The dam at 'c' is fenced, keeping animals away, but it is accessible to man, and is often used as a source of supply for passing motorists and sometimes campers. I am told that in winter when other sources of water fail, local families get their water supply here.

The dam 'c' silt up quickly and must be cleaned at least once a week. Even though this is done, much silt collects in the reservoir and pipelines, scoring valves and discoloring water. The reservoir is cleaned once a year. The water is drained through the pipe line to the school, leaving four or five inches of water in the reservoir. The silt is removed by buckets lifted through the manhole. Since water remains in the reservoir it is difficult to do a good job of cleaning.

On July 18 at 5 p.m. a standard sample of
water was taken from a faucet in the school and another one taken at the spring E2. These were delivered to the Provincial Board of Health, Vancouver, on afternoon of July 19. The results of the tests were as follows:

| Specimen                  | Coli-Aerogenes Test |
|---------------------------|--------------------|
|                           | 0.1 cc.            | 1 cc. | 10 cc. |
| No. 1 Faucet              | 0/2                | 3/5   | 5/5    |
| No. 2 Spring (source of water) | 0/2                | 0/5   | 1/5    |

These tests would indicate that the water at the spring is clean, but is contaminated by the time it reaches the school. From the foregoing observations of conditions along the line of flow, the contamination could be from man.

**Recommendation**

To improve existing conditions I would suggest that the total flow from spring E2 be collected by works shown on Sketch 3 and piped directly to the overflow chamber 'e' of the reservoir. The spring and adjoining land should be fenced, and to cover the riparian rights and good-will of the Indian occupant, conditions at E3 should be improved so as to collect more of the flow of this spring for his use. Water licence No. 3140 will have to be modified to cover new point of diversion and arrangements made to permit the fencing of the area around the spring. The reservoir area should be fenced and the overflow chamber be improved and provided with a new cover as a protection from contamination by animals or man.
The direct pipe line from spring to reservoir should not only insure clean water, but should eliminate the necessity of cleaning the reservoir annually.

The estimated cost to install a suitable water collecting box; 3" wood stave pipe line to connect with the present pipe line at dam 'c'; to improve the overflow chamber 'e'; to drain the reservoir and spring SE areas and improve connections at spring SS is $1,930.00.

Local Indian labour can be obtained, but in addition it would be desirable to have at least one white man from the school. The work can be done anytime the ground is free of frost - March 15 to October 1. Suitable gravel for concrete work can be obtained within 5 miles, and material can be delivered to site by truck or wagon.

It should be noted that the proposed 3" pipe line connects with the present 5" pipe line 'd' near dam 'c'. This 5" pipe line 'd' has been in use for 20 years and has a probable further life of 5 years. When replacement is necessary the 3" main should be continued to the overflow chamber and then to the reservoir.

The gate valve now installed at the intake dam site should be moved to the pipe line between the overflow chamber and the reservoir.

A. Unsworth

Mr. Hoey,

Re: St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, British Columbia.

In reply to your memorandum of May 30th, 1946, requesting a report on certain works at the above mentioned school, a report in connection with the domestic water supply has been submitted by the Engineering and Construction Service, a copy of which is attached. The recommendations contained therein are concurred in. It will be noted that the cost of the proposed work is $1930.

At the time Mr. Unsworth visited the school to investigate the water supply he also made a very extensive report on the domestic water supply system within the school, apparently at the request of the Indian Commissioner.

From a report of Mr. Unsworth dated September 12th and from subsequent data, analysis shows that the failure of the domestic water supply system is due mainly to two causes; firstly, the evident lack of a full appreciation of the hot water requirements in a building of this kind; and secondly, trouble caused by untreated water, which has resulted in a rapid deterioration of equipment by scaling.

It is pointed out that several methods of heating water have been tried and all have failed for varying reasons. After a full consideration of the requirements and taking into account existing equipment which could be used to better advantage, it is recommended that the following operations be carried out:

(a) Provide water softening equipment, of an approved design, which will neutralize the effect of hard water.

(b) Provide new indirect steam fed heater of tube and shell design and connect to present heating boilers, in a method to be outlined later.

(c) Clean existing storage tank; remove existing
submerged coil, and examine present temperature regulating valve. If same is found to be unsatisfactory, and unequal to the work required, remove and replace with new valve of proper capacity.

(d) Disconnect high pressure boiler from domestic hot water service.

(e) Make necessary piping revisions, as may be required, to carry out the above work.

The estimated cost of the above operations at this time can only be approximated as conditions discovered when work is actually undertaken may reveal the necessity for additional operations. However, an amount of not less than $4,500.00 should be available at the outset.

It should be mentioned that Mr. Unsworth has strongly recommended water softening equipment and has gone into considerable detail regarding capacities and performances. We concur fully with him regarding the urgent need of this equipment.

If you wish to proceed with the installation as outlined above, plans and specifications can be prepared by our Engineering and Construction Service. Your further advice in this regard is awaited.

We have been unable as yet to have a report prepared on the irrigation system, but as soon as one is available you will be advised.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am writing you in reference to the matter relative to our domestic water equipment. During the Summer and Fall, there have been several surveys made of the situation, and reports sent in regarding the need of repairs and extra equipment. One of the recommendations is that of an electrically driven pump that would send the condensate back into the high pressure steam boiler against 110 lbs pressure. This is a very important matter.

As you are aware, the alkaline deposit on the inside of our boilers has ruined several jacket heaters and steam boilers during the past five years. While our domestic water was heated by jacket heater, the amount of water that had to be heated and therefore which had to go through the jacket heater system, was very great, and consequently left a great deal of deposit on the inside of the heater, resulting in the channels of the heater being filled up, and making the heater useless.

At the present time we are heating the water by means of a steam coil in the hot water tank, connected to the high pressure boiler. This has done very good and effective work. But the drawback of such a system is that the high pressure steam boiler requires so much additional water to make up for that used up in the steam coil, and each replenishment of water in the boiler means more alkaline deposit in the boiler tubes, which means, in the near future again, either a new boiler or new tubes. Both of which, or either of which are expensive replacements.

If we could have installed, a pump to handle the condensate water from the steam coils in the
hot water tank, so that the condensate water, which is now devoid of any alkaline, could be returned to the boiler, I see no reason why much of our problem would not be solved, and the life of the boiler increased.

This matter is part of the responsibility of the Department. It has always been a problem, and a very difficult one. I believe a recommendation regarding this matter has been made, and I would like to know if there is any hope of that recommendation being carried out in the near future.

Yours faithfully,

Principal.

January 23, 1947

Dear Sir:

I am again placing before you the matter of the urgent need of a high pressure pump for the purpose of forcing the condensate water back into the high pressure steam boiler.

Yesterday, we made an examination of the hot water tank after using the live steam coil in the tank for heating the water for a period of six months. After draining the tank, and taking off the man hole, we found an alkaline deposit on the outside of the steam coil, which immediately peeled off as it dried, leaving the copper pipe coil exposed and clean. This examination proved to us that the steam coil system of heating is a success, and better than any other system so far used during the last five years.

The only drawback to the system is the loss of the condensate water. A great deal of condensate water is made in the heating of water for a building with 200 residents. Every bit or drop of fresh water that goes into making that steam leaves an alkaline deposit on the tubes and crown of the boiler. This deposit will ruin the boiler as it has done in the past.

If we had the high pressure pump, electrically driven, to force the condensate water back into the boiler, I feel assured that the present boiler would stand in good repair for years. The cost of the pump was approximately $400.00.

Yours faithfully,

"Chas F. Hives"

MEMORANDUM:

Re: St. Georges (Anglican) Indian Residential School.
Lytton, British Columbia.

Further to our memorandum of November 20th, 1946, January 23rd, 1947 and February 12th last, in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

An officer from this Service, on an inspection trip covering a number of Indian Residential Schools, called at Lytton and obtained the necessary additional data to enable plans and specifications to be prepared in line with our recommendations under date of November 20th, 1946.

A complete inspection of the boiler plant and a further analysis of the requirements made at the job, showed that our original comment covered the essentials. The boiler room equipment was found to be in good condition and with few exceptions, the piping arrangement was of good design.

The high pressure boiler, originally designed to serve laundry and canteen requirements, has been pressed into service to heat domestic hot water. Since it is not possible to return more than half the condensate from these three sources, raw make up water must be used. This has caused failures through corrosion in the boiler tubes as the water is exceptionally hard. It has been responsible also for the rapid burning out of every type of jacket heater used.

Emphasis is placed on the need for water softening equipment to protect the heating apparatus, in a hook-up with the present heating boilers along with a new indirect steam fed heater, to provide the necessary amount of domestic hot water. The heating boilers, stove fired, are ample in capacity to heat the building and the domestic hot water, and full advantage should be taken of this. Generatively few piping changes will be involved and the work could be carried out with little, if any disturbance to the normal school routine. The high pressure boiler when used for laundry and canteen purposes only, as was originally intended, can be fed with the treated water and should last for years.

As stated in our memorandum of November 20th, 1946, it is thought that for the operations recommended an amount of approximately $4500.00 should be provided by Indian Affairs.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am taking the liberty of writing you a personal letter relative to a matter which is causing me some deep concern. It is in connection with the matter of the installation of a water softening plant in our school, which has, I believe been recommended by the Water and Power Commission.

Two years ago, because of the trouble we were having with our hot water heating equipment, by the alkaline deposit in the boiler ruining the tubes of the high pressure steam boiler, I recommended that an electric pump should be installed for the purpose of returning the condensate water, made in the steam coils in the hot water tank, back to the high pressure steam boiler. This pump was to cost $400.00, and it would, by pumping back the condensate water, eliminate, I reckon, 80 per cent of the trouble, and prolong the life of the boiler.

After much correspondence the matter was referred to the Water and Power Commission who sent a man to make a survey of the situation. He came and stayed with us for about two weeks, and made quite an elaborate report, which, I believe, was quite a thorough one. Later, another man came, who stayed a few days, and made another survey and report. And still later, a man came from Ottawa, and made another survey and recommended a water softening plant, estimated to cost $4500.00.

Some years ago, before my time here, a water softening plant was installed, and used a few years. After which it was taken out and lies in a decayed state in one of the out buildings. I believe it was similar to the one recommended now to be installed. It was taken out and scrapped because it was considered a nuisance and an unnecessary expense.
I have no doubt a water softening plant should be of value where the water has such a large alkaline content; but there are so many other equally important requirements, which we shall certainly be unable to secure if that large amount of money is taken from the New England Company funds. I feel quite sure that my request for an electric pump would have answered the purpose of protecting and prolonging the life of the high pressure steam boiler. I did not ask for the water softening plant.

We require a swimming pool in the worst way for our pupils. Such an acquisition would protect the lives of our pupils. We also, very urgently need a new poultry house. These things, I feel, could honestly be paid for from New England Company funds. I doubt if we are honestly spending those funds by installing an elaborate water softening plant, which we have not asked for, and which, will no doubt be quite an expense to maintain when and if it is installed.

I am quite willing to go by your judgement in this matter; but as it stands, it does give me some concern. I also feel that we should show to the Indian people that we are possessed of human sympathies. I doubt if they would ever recognize a water softening plant as of as much importance for their children, as they would a safe swimming pool, or a good poultry house for the production of eggs to feed their children.

If you can deal with this matter without others having the feeling that I have been presumptuous in going over their heads, I shall be much relieved. I know you and your staff are always greatly concerned both about our welfare and the proper expending of money. Yet, because we are remotely situated from you, I feel sure that direct and first hand information is also welcomed, in dealing with problems.

With kindest regards and every good wish.

I am, Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

the boiler at present dismantled at St. George's School,
Lytton, B. C., I now submit the following report.

The last inspection allowed 15 pounds as safe
working pressure, with condition - good and sound.

This boiler is rapidly turning to junk in its
present location and I would suggest it be moved to the
present Boiler Room and connected as a spare boiler, or,
moved to the Dairy, and covered with asbestos and used
occasionally in order that the vertical boiler could
be cleaned better and more often. The covering would
offset the boiler being too large for the dairy, making
it more efficient.

it should be sold while it has a market value.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 16th ultimo referring to the appointment of an Inspector of Construction in connection with the new Indian residential school to be built at Lytton, B.C., I beg to inform you that there were thirteen applications for the position received at this office by the 2nd instant. Two of the applications were not completed as the forms were not declared to by someone having the power to take an affidavit. These, therefore, have not been received by headquarters. Of the remaining eleven it is found that two of them are not residents of the competition district and, therefore, would not be considered eligible providing a competent person is found within the remaining nine. Very few of the applicants have had any experience as Inspectors of Construction, though most of them have filled positions as Superintendent of Construction which is an entirely different thing.

I am attaching hereto the applications of the eleven applicants above referred to with rating sheets appended thereto. The applicant receiving the highest rating is Mr. Charles Macdonald, Vancouver, B.C., who apparently has had the most experience. He was Inspector of Construction at the Edmonton School and was offered the same position at the Cardston School, so I take it that his services were eminently satisfactory to our Department. On this account it might be proper for you to attach to his application a letter of recommendation for the position, for I think it is only right that the Department should have something to say in connection with the appointment of a person who will have the oversight of such a large expenditure of the public funds.

Attached also is the printed poster advertising the vacancy, which was displayed in the window of my office from the 24th of June to the 4th instant inclusive.

W.B./K.D.

July 13th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Foran,

I am enclosing herewith applications for the position of inspector of construction at Lytton, B.C., with rating sheets furnished by the Indian Commissioner, Mr. Ditchburn. There are 13 applications in all. Of these two, Nos. 12 and 13 have not been dealt with by Mr. Ditchburn because they were not accompanied by the necessary affidavits. Of the remaining 11, two are from points outside the district advertised in.

I regret that these applications do not on the whole appear very satisfactory. This is an important position; the appointee must not only have the requisite technical knowledge, but he must be a person of undoubted integrity owing to the necessity of most careful supervision of the work and the oversight of a large expenditure of public funds, in this case approximately $150,000.00. There is no doubt that Mr. Charles May of Vancouver is the best qualified man and he is rated highest by Mr. Ditchburn. Some three years ago Mr. May, who was then a resident of Edmonton, was inspector of construction on the large industrial school which

William Foran, Esq.,

we erected in the vicinity of that city. So satisfactory was his work that we endeavoured to obtain his services to supervise the construction of a new school a year later on the Blood reserve. Sir,

As advised by telegram you have been appointed Inspector of Construction for the new Indian Residential School at Lytton, B.C., and you will be paid for your services at the rate of six dollars ($6.00) per day, and allowance will be made for your board at Lytton. You will be expected to devote all of your time to this work, and to see that the building is erected in accordance with the plans and specifications. The contract for the building has been awarded to Adkison and Hill Ltd., of Vancouver, at their tendered price of $159,000.00; and they are being notified that all correspondence relative to this work is to be forwarded to the Department through you.

It will be your duty to issue progress certificates for payment to the contractor. These should be forwarded to the Department in duplicate. You will notice by the specifications that the Department pays up to 90% of the value of the labour and material in the building. I am sending you, under separate cover, blue print copies of the plans and specifications, also certificate forms and diary sheets. These diary sheets should be kept and forwarded to the Department with your voucher for payment of your salary, which should be signed by the Indian Agent or the Reverend Mr. Lett.
