To J D McLean
and Deputy Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

It would assist me very much in my efforts to obtain new employment to have possession of a letter from my last employer certifying as far as you know of as to my personal character—honesty, integrity, trustworthiness during the period of my appointment as Inspector of Construction. I am somewhat of a stranger here & find it difficult to get employment or to have such a letter—if only brief would assist.

I might further observe that one makes but few friends as Inspector of Construction for the more severe, or vigilant, one is the more he is disliked & on the other hand if he is too lenient, he loses his job.

No one could be more vigilant an Inspector at Lytton but there were
may adverse factors against me
which I could not control such
as winter building, some interference
from local officials, etc., etc.

I was at all times conscientious in
my work or put in my whole time
on this job with the exception of
when I was assisting Mr. Lott in
building the new Horse Barn, Garage,
Granary, or Root House. I supervised
the erection of these buildings also
put in upwards of 250 hours of
manual labor, carpentry, cutting
patens, pouring concrete, bending
finishing, laying hollow tile, applying
stucco, directing unskilled Indians
in the use of tools, the mixing of
cements or Plasters, believing it to be
in a good cause. I also applied
my personal labor in installing
$2,000 worth of new school fixtures.
I consider the value of my labor
alone to be worth $300.

I might mention that I built all
the walls of a Hollow Tile Root House
22 ft x 60 ft.
single handed with the help of an
Indian helper, laying 1200-12x12 hollow
tile staked out & leveled foundations
of all 4 buildings. In consideration
of all my energy in this direction
I received a cheque of $25.00 from
Mr. Lott, gratuity.

I nevertheless kept close track of the
construction work of the school, and of
course when a large force of men
were there I could not leave them.
I made all the designs of the £2,000
fixtures, tables, bookcases etc etc.
4 sets of all the drawings, as I am
a competent draftsman.
I always did my best for the Depart-
ment no one can say otherwise, and I am
sorry to say it did not get me anywhere
for Lytton. As an extremely isolated place
160 miles from Vancouver, so I had to virtually
forego all my business connections in
Vancouver to go there.

Trusting you will send me letter of
commendation asked for.
I remain Sir
Yours Truly
Frank W. Baker

MEMORANDUM

Re: St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, British Columbia.

Further to our memorandum of August 7th relative to the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of a letter from Mr. Webb in which were enclosed two tenders covering the work outlined on our plan and specification for the above.

Below is a summary of the two tenders received:

Acme Plumbing and Heating Service, 114 Water St., Vancouver—$7,895.00
Barr and Anderson Ltd., 1060 Homer Street, Vancouver——— $5,185.00

Mr. Webb had some difficulty in interesting any firms to offer tenders, and their reluctance to bid is directly reflected in the tender prices which are fantastically higher than our considered estimate of $4,500.

If the boiler room, laundry, domestic hot water equipment, and domestic water piping systems are to be protected against costly and rapid deterioration brought about by excessively hard water, the work outlined by this Service should be proceeded with; but we do not feel justified in recommending the acceptance of either of the above tenders as it is felt that they are unreasonably high.

However, the vertical high pressure boiler which serves the laundry equipment should have some individual protection. This unit is being supplied with raw make-up water, as it is not possible or feasible to return more than 50% of the condensate.

It is suggested therefore, that the high pressure boiler be provided with an individual water treatment system along the lines of that offered by Goddard and Company of Sidney, Vancouver Island as outlined in their letter of September 25, 1947.

If this protective treatment were supplied for this boiler, it could be made to work in conjunction with the equipment outlined in our original recommendation and would therefore not be lost should the entire renovations be carried out at some later date.

It is not to be considered however, that the above is an alternative to our original recommendation; as this equipment would only provide protection for the high pressure boiler.

When Indian Affairs decide what steps they are prepared to take after considering this report, we will, upon receiving instructions, institute the necessary action to carry out their wishes.

Dear Mr. Kelan:

I am writing you because I know you will understand our circumstances better than anyone else there, then I tell you of them. Your comprehensive knowledge of residential school work, and the many problems you have had to tackle makes it almost necessary that I should write to you in respect to matters that concern our needs.

We have a full school. The largest number in the history of the school. Of course, I knew this would happen. As you are aware, I have had great difficulty in filling the school since I came. The people, parents of children in St. George's district, have shown very little real interest in school and education until some thirty new pupils came from the north. Now, like all true Indians, they think they are missing something that someone else is getting, and they are flocking into school. I have had to turn many away. We now have a full school of nearly 200 pupils, and we are not adequately equipped to handle that number.

Quite a few boys and girls are lying on the floor instead of a bed at night. I am still waiting for the small dormitory beds and mattresses and blankets which you thought you could get for us while I was with you in your office. I do hope they will come soon. Many of the beds, which we are using have been on the go for so long, they should be either repaired properly or scrapped.

The kitchen stove. It is altogether too small and too antiquated for our crowd. I believe it was taken out of the old school twenty years ago. Having such equipment in such an important department not only makes the work difficult, but causes much discouragement to the staff who have to work in that department, so that we have too many changes, which is bad for the school generally. Surely there must be good kitchen ranges with war Assets that would suit our needs.

Laundry. I don't know how long the
equipment there has been on the go, but it is not in good shape. And being so far away from any means of getting a proper repair job done on the washer, which is too small anyway, it has become leaky and castings etc., worn and slack. Our electricity is so expensive, we have to use the old flat iron, heated on a little stove. I cannot allow electric irons, for our light bill now is around two hundred dollars a month, which is more than we can afford. We need a steam flat iron machine in order to take care of the work in the laundry. With the staff, we have over two hundred persons whose clothing have to be taken care of.

I was over at the War Asset warehouses in Vancouver recently. They have a lot of material there that we need in the worst way. Chairs and tables and kitchen and diningroom equipment. Our chairs in the Assembly Hall have been knocked around for twenty years, and are the cheap collapsible kind. They have hundreds of these at the war assets at two dollars each. We need fifty very urgently.

It takes every bit of the grant allowance to feed and clothe, pay salaries, which are higher than ever before, and all the rest of the general expenses. We simply cannot buy the things which I have mentioned and which we need so urgently.

Can you do anything for us to relieve the situation. The work is going along fine. I have good workers, and I want to keep them. You want our work to be a success. Please, if you can possibly do something for us, we would be very grateful.

Yours faithfully,

Re: St. George's (Anglican) Indian Residential School, Lytton, British Columbia.

An Officer from this Division visited the above last March during the course of an extended inspection trip covering the number of schools.

The Principal, Rev. C.F. Hives, had been advocating the installation of a high pressure boiler feed pump to return condensate to the vertical high pressure laundry boiler, in an effort to overcome the destructive effect of raw make-up water.

The result of our Officers' inspection confirmed our previously stated opinion that the installation of this pump, is not the proper solution, as only slightly more than 50% of the condensate could be returned, necessitating the introduction of raw make-up water.

Following an analysis of the complete data obtained as a result of this inspection, recommendations were made to the Indian Affairs Branch, outlining the installation of suitable water softening apparatus along with certain revisions to the existing boiler room piping and equipment. These recommendations are fully outlined in our memoranda under date of November 20, 1946, and April 11, 1947.

Subsequently Mr. Webb, District Engineer, of Vancouver, was asked to obtain tenders based on plans and specifications prepared by this Division. After a considerable delay occasioned by the reluctance of West Coast contractors to take on additional work at this time, two tenders were received. These tenders were nearly 100% higher than our considered estimate of $4,500.00, and we did not feel justified in recommending that either one be accepted.

It was felt, however, that some means of protection against hard water should be provided for the high pressure boiler, which is one of the more expensive items of equipment. With this in view, we outlined in a memorandum dated October 22, 1947, a system of feed water treatment consisting of prescribed compound, testing apparatus etc. While this treatment is not to be considered as an alternative to our original recommendation, it would provide a satisfactory measure of protection for the high pressure boiler only, and could be incorporated into the original proposal, at such time as it may be possible to obtain a more favourable price for the entire work.

As a result, the Indian Affairs Branch authorized this Division to request Mr. Indian Agent Strang to place an order with Goddard & Company of Sidney, Vancouver Island, to supply the necessary boiler compound and testing kit to the school. In this connection we wrote to the Goddard & Company, outlining the requirements. We also wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Strang and Principal C.F. Hives, and we are advising Mr. Webb of the action that is being taken.

Director,

Mr. W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,

St. George's Indian Residential School

Inspector Davey's reports upon the classrooms at this school have been noted. It would seem that this residential school is one for which we will have to consider the provision of a classroom block at some future date. We will be in a better position to decide this matter by the time our next year's estimates are being prepared.

Inspector Davey's comments concerning the manual training have been drawn to the attention of Mr. Doucet and it is likely that you will hear further from him in this regard. It is suggested that a requisition be forwarded for the type of mangle which is recommended for use in the laundry. The purchase of this will depend largely on the amount of money that is required to re-surface the floors in the boys' senior dormitory. Therefore we will be able to definitely decide about the provision of the mangle when an estimate is obtained as to the cost of re-surfacing the floors. However, we would like to know the approximate cost of the mangle, as recommended.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
May 4, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

Reverend Canon Hives, principal of the St. George's Residential School visited the Department this week.

He pointed out that the roof of the main building requires repairs and he also recommended that the exterior of the building be painted.

We have approximately $3,500.00 provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the St. George's School and I would appreciate it if you could give the matter your early attention and let us have a recommendation regarding what repairs you consider should be made.

If possible, you should obtain a quotation for the work required in order that we may submit same for the Minister's approval.

PP/MGD

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Repairs - St. George's Residential School

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of May 4th (file 165-0-5 E.I.), I have discussed with Canon Hives the question of repairs and maintenance of the above mentioned school buildings and recently had an opportunity of discussing the matter further with a representative of the Tremco Company. While we have yet to secure all the details it is anticipated that the school management will provide labour for painting the buildings, the Department will be asked to provide the necessary paint and the Tremco Company will tender on material and labour necessary for repairing the roof of the main building.

Paint, and particularly white paint, is in extremely short supply which will necessitate securing small quantities as and when available and it might be necessary for me to ask for authority to purchase small amounts from time to time within a specified total cost. The matter will be the subject of a further communication at an early date.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Forwarded the Department herewith is a letter addressed to me by the Reverend Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School in which he requests funds from the New England Company grant in the amount of $2000.00 for the following purposes:

(1) purchase of mattresses and blankets $450.00
(2) reconditioning farm truck 650.00
(3) purchase of 2 milk cows 500.00
(4) purchase of wire fencing 400.00 $2000.00

A. Strang,

Rev. Canon C. F. Hives  
Principal

Sept. 7, 1948  
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Will you kindly endorse my request to the Department for the amount of two thousand dollars from New England Company grant for the following purposes:

We urgently need mattresses and blankets for the dormitory beds. I was able to purchase beds from War Assets Corp. for a very reasonable price, but no mattresses or blankets were available. Our farm truck, which is a very necessary vehicle, and which we use for hauling fuel and goods, has to be either replaced with a new truck, or reconditioned. I would recommend that, under the circumstances, the truck be reconditioned, and the cost will be $650.00. This year, the pupils have come, flocking in, on time; so that we are having to turn some of them away for lack of accommodation. Our present milk supply is hardly adequate enough for the number of children we have; so that we should purchase two more cows. These will cost, at least, $250.00 each. I would also like to renew our old fences, which are in very poor shape. And for this purpose we require wire fencing to the amount of four hundred dollars.

I would be very much obliged if you would present this matter to the Department as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr A. Strang,  
Superintendent,

CANADA
November 16, 1948.

Colonel Neary:
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.

With Mr. Supt. Strang I visited this school on Friday, Nov. 12th. This school which, like the Mohawk Institute owes its origin to the New England Company and is administered similarly, affords many points of comparison with the Eastern Canada institution.

Laundry: The apparatus comprises a washer, extractor and drier. These are driven by overhead belts which could be better guarded. Another hazard that has luckily so far not caused trouble is observable in the fact that to shut off the machinery one has to attract the attention of the man on duty in the next room and he is quite deaf. There is, indeed, a small pane of glass in the intervening wall, but I couldn't see through it. To get to the switch through the connecting doors and passage would take a good many precious seconds.

The machinery is getting old, and the principal hopes for replacements soon but as this is a belt-driven assembly, it might absorb the Chapleau machinery if those units can be restored to acceptable efficiency. The room is about 45' x 15' and could hold more units.

All the ironing is done by hand, taking too much time.

Steam is supplied by a 16 H.P. boiler, and the suggestion is made that this unit should be supplied with a high-pressure pump so that the used water may be returned to the boiler. The fresh water is so highly alkaline that a considerable saving of tubes and machinery and materials would, it is claimed, result.

Dishwashing apparatus and procedures: Well below the ideal.

Dining-room: The children are sitting close together. Except for the floor which is concrete and needs a better surface eating conditions are acceptable. The food is good and there is plenty of it in pleasing variety.

Playroom space is inadequate for the smaller girls particularly. It might be possible to exploit the assembly hall and the gymnasium to a greater extent.

Dormitories have their full quotas, and in some cases are, perhaps, exceeding it slightly. There is a commendable tendency to allow the pupils greater access to their own property than exists elsewhere.

Vocational training: The set-up rather favours the boys. A few electrically-powered sewing machines and a mending machine would allow the chore-sewing to be handled faster so that progressive work could receive more time.

Classroom equipment: Supplies have been slow arriving. Even for the junior high school grades the science equipment is inadequate. The senior pupils attend the local high school.
During a survey limited to one day I saw many aspects of handling the school and farm that were very encouraging.

The principal said that two hundred blankets are an almost immediate requirement.

C.A.F. Clark

Feb. 21, 1949 Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

I am writing you in reference to the electrical wiring system of St. George's School. From one's observations of the workmanship which was put into the construction of this school, I am of the opinion that not too much care was exercised by those responsible, and particularly in connection with the electrical wiring.

In the whole of the building there was not one wall or floor electrical connection in the way of a receptical installed. Consequently, during the years since the completion of the building, a great deal of amateurish work has been done; and all the staff rooms have extensions connected in some way from the ceiling drop light to their bed or table. This condition is not safe, and I feel sure would not pass the inspection of any fire department or fire insurance underwriter. We have had a very hard winter, and lights have had to be used a great deal, although there are no electrical appliances in the way of heaters etc. in the staff room.

We have two hundred children in school, and, as you must realize, Indian children are not always responsible for what they do.

I would urgently recommend that an inspection of our whole system be made by an authorized expert, and his findings reported to the Department without delay.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) Chas. F. Hives.
Principal.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have just received a letter from Commissioner Arneil, saying that a food chopper and slicer, which we are very much in need of in our kitchen, be purchased from the New England Company funds. I am sorry you have made this decision, as I was hoping that the England Company funds would accumulate sufficiently to enable us to buy a very much needed farm truck. The one we have has been on the go for twelve years, and is now just a bit of expense trying to keep it in repair. We cannot do without it, for all our fuel has to be hauled from the station three miles away, or from the bush twelve miles away.

We also need the kitchen equipment, which, according to the list sent out by the Department, is equipment which the Department should buy. So far, I have tried in every way to use the New England Company funds for extraordinary expenses. We receive financial help from no other source other than the per capita grant allowance; which, comparing it with that of other schools is no larger than those. We simply cannot run this school much longer on this grant, and keep up repairs and a decent appearance.

I do hope you will reconsider this matter of Kitchen equipment, and allow the New England Company fund to remain intact for the Farm truck.

Will you kindly tell me how much there is in the New England Company fund now.

Secretary,
Power Commission,
Victoria.

Dear Sir:

I am writing you to express our deep concern over the light and power situation here at St. George's School. The light is very poor indeed, especially when it is most needed. This is the first time that I have made any complaint about it, but I really think something should be done to improve the situation.

It seems to me that the plant which supplies the light and power is entirely inadequate and overloaded. We are at the beginning of the dark season of the year. We have to depend so much on it. We have two hundred children in school, and several times we have been thrown in darkness, at very inconvenient times, when we have to take to coal oil lamps and candles. Some years ago the power was off for forty-eight hours, when the temperature at that time happened to be 23 degrees below zero. We have power stokers on the heating plant; you can therefore well imagine our position at that time.

Unless the Power Commission takes the matter in hand, I see no reason why we shall not be subject to the same condition of inconvenience, fire hazard and all that again this winter.

I would respectfully and urgently ask that this matter be treated as paramount importance by your Commission.

Yours faithfully,

Principal.
Dear Major MacKay:

We have had a very enjoyable visit from the Primate, the Most Rev. Archbishop Kingston and his wife. It was really a very delightful visit, and I feel sure that he enjoyed seeing our school and our work amongst the Indian children. We also had a visit a few days ago from General Turner of the Residential School Administration. He also was very much surprised and pleased with what he saw.

I felt very embarrassed when, during the service, the lights were so poor, we could hardly see to read, and we had to sing without the organ, which being electric, went quite flat.

But that is not my worst fears. Winter is coming on, and we have some dark, cold nights; and as our heating depends on the electric power to drive the stokers, it would be terrible to have to go through what we experienced the first Winter I was here, when the Spencer's plant failed, and we were without light or power for forty-eight hours, and the temperature was 23 below zero. The plant is over-loaded now, and when these new storages are completed, the load will be increased.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I am sending to the Power Commission. I believe a letter from you might add a great deal of weight, so that they would take action.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Rev. Canon C. F. Hives
Principal

Dear Sir;

With reference to your letter of Oct. 18, your file 7-11-3 regarding an increase in enrolment at St. George's School.

I have now inspected the existing dormitories and the rooms which could be used to increase the enrolment. There are at present two large dormitories for the boys, one of these having a partition through the center. The measurements of these two dormitories are 61 X 28 X 10 feet each and there are 49 boys in each.

The girl's dormitories are the same size as the boys', one with a partition and one without. They are the same size and have a 100 girls in them, 48 in one and 52 in the other. The 28 foot walls on each end of the dormitories have windows built close together for the full width of the room.

With the proposed alterations, the two new rooms which are now sewing rooms would be 17½ x 27 x 10 feet. A short wall would have to be built to change these rooms so they could be used as dormitories and the rest of the material would be used for building shelves and cupboards so smaller rooms could be used for sewing rooms.

I enclose quotations on materials required, having been advised by Canon Hives that the work could be done by employees and pupils of the school. Canon Hives also advises that he will also require 20 beds, 5 foot size with mattresses.
Although the air space is not 500 feet per pupil, it is no doubt far more than we find in the average Indian home, and with so much window space in each dormitory I do not think the pupils will suffer from the shortage of space.

Yours truly,

D.M. Hett,
A/Superintendent,
Lytton Indian Agency.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Domestic Water Supply System
St. Georges Indian Residential School
Lytton, B.C.

During my visit of November 2 to the above mentioned school in connection with an electrical survey, I also made a brief inspection of the domestic water supply system. This system appears to be in an unsanitary sanitary condition, and in need of repairs, since the six inch wood stave supply line running from the reservoir to the school is over twenty years old, is leaking badly in several places, and has had to be repaired frequently during the past two years.

Mr. Unsworth's Report of September 11, 1946 regarding the subject

In general, the whole question of the present water supply system is dealt with in Mr. Unsworth's report on this subject.

Sanitary Conditions

An Indian family holds several acres of land which drain into the creek conveying the water from the present supply spring to the reservoir intake. This makes for unsanitary conditions for the following reasons:

(1) Cattle and horses graze over this land causing possible contamination during the rainy season and irrigation periods.

(2) The ground which is cleared close to the spring from which the water supply is taken, appears to be still used by the Indian family resident on the property above for a laundering and bathing area. As stated in Mr. Unsworth's report, water is heated over a small grate beside the stream. The used water is turned out, to run into the stream feeding the school water supply system.

(3) During the irrigation periods when the ground above is flooded, considerable sediment is washed into the stream, causing the domestic water to become discoloured.

A collecting box connected to a pipe line to feed the present reservoir should improve the unsanitary conditions mentioned above. If, however, it was found that there were still signs of contamination due to percolation through the soil during the rainy seasons or irrigation periods, a chlorinator could then be procured for use during these intervals.

Recommendations

To put the above mentioned system in order, I would suggest that the following work be done without delay:

(1) A water collecting box at the supply spring be installed as outlined in Mr. Unsworth's report.

------To cost about $500.00

(2) A 4" No. 12 gauge spiral welded steel pipe asphalt dipped, asbestos felt wrapped, be laid from the collecting
box to the present reservoir.

------- To cost about $2,500.00

(3) A 6" No. 12 gauge spiral welded steel pipe, asphalt dipped, asbestos felt wrapped, be laid from the reservoir to the school.

------- To cost about $3,250.00

(4) A 6" No. 12 gauge spiral welded steel pipe, asphalt dipped, asbestos felt wrapped, be laid to connect the fire hydrants to the main supply.

------- To cost about $1,250.00

Total cost is about $8,200.00

The protected steel pipe which has an expected life of 40 years, against 20 to 25 years for wood stave pipe, has been recommended since the school is a permanent structure and, as stated by the Indian Commissioner for this Province, is expected to be used for a long period. An approximate breakdown of the costs for items 2, 3 and 4 is attached.

Thomas A.G. Beeching

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Domestic Water Supply System
St. Georges Indian Residential School
Lytton, B.C.

During my visit of November 2 to the above mentioned school in connection with an electrical survey, I also made a brief inspection of the domestic water supply system. This system appears to be in an unhealthy sanitary condition and in need of repairs, since the six inch wood stave supply line running from the reservoir to the school is over twenty years old, is leaking badly in several places, and has had to be repaired frequently during the past two years.

Mr. Unsworth's Report of September 11, 1946 Regarding the Subject

In general, the whole question of the present water supply system is dealt with in Mr. Unsworth's report on this subject.

Sanitary Conditions

An Indian family holds several acres of land which drain into the creek conveying the water from the present supply spring to the reservoir intake. This makes for unsanitary conditions for the following reasons:

(1) Cattle and horses graze over this land causing possible contamination during the rainy season and irrigation periods.

(2) The ground which is cleared close to the spring from which the water supply is taken, appears to be still used by the Indian family resident on the property above for a laundering and bathing area. As stated in Mr. Unsworth's report, water is heated over a small grate beside the stream. The used water is turned out, to run into the stream feeding the school water supply system.

(3) During the irrigation periods when the ground above is flooded, considerable sediment is washed into the stream, causing the domestic water to become discoloured.

A collecting box connected to a pipe line to feed the present reservoir should improve the unsanitary conditions mentioned above. If, however, it was found that there were still signs of contamination due to percolation through the soil during the rainy seasons or irrigation periods, a chlorinator could then be procured for use during these intervals.
Recommendations

To put the above mentioned system in order, I would suggest that the following work be done without delay:

(1) A water collecting box at the supply spring be installed as outlined in Mr. Unsworth's report.

-------To cost about $600.00

(2) A 4" No. 12 gauge spiral welded steel pipe asphalt dipped, asbestos felt wrapped, be laid from the collecting box to the present reservoir.

-------To cost about $2,500.00

(3) A 6" No. 12 gauge spiral welded steel pipe, asphalt dipped, asbestos felt wrapped, be laid from the reservoir to the school.

-------To cost about $3,850.00

(4) A 6" No. 12 gauge spiral welded steel pipe, asphalt dipped, asbestos felt wrapped, be laid to connect the fire hydrants to the main supply.

-------To cost about $1,250.00

Total cost is about $8,200.00

The protected steel pipe which has an expected life of 40 years, against 20 to 25 years for wood stave pipe, has been recommended since the school is a permanent structure and, as stated by the Indian Commissioner for this Province, is expected to be used for a long period. An approximate breakdown of the costs for Items 2, 3, and 4 is attached.

Referring to the memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs dated January 12th, we note the suggestion to prepare specifications and plans necessary for the calling of tenders on the above project.

As noted by you, similar type of pipe is proposed for the above installation as used in the Sheshatshai Reserve project, and that in the former, day labour is recommended, as opposed to contract work in the latter. It is still recommended that the work at Lytton be done as suggested in our letter of January 20th.

Ottawa, March 31, 1950.

Memorandum:

The Deputy Minister,

I attach a memo and requisition dated the 28th instant from Mr. P. Phelan, Indian Education Division, Ottawa, requesting the purchase of Transite Pipe to the value of $4,994.60, from the Johns-Manville Co. Ltd., Vancouver, B.C.

The pipe is for the construction of a Domestic water Supply System at St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

You will note that even if an order was placed, it would be impossible to secure delivery in order to make payment from funds of appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50. I discussed this aspect with Mr. MacKay and he would like very much to have the order placed and invoice rendered even if delivery was made at a little later date, so that payment might be made from this year's funds.

Under the circumstances, and as Transite Pipe is specified by Engineering Service which is only obtainable through the Canadian Johns-Manville Co. Ltd., I would recommend that the order be placed immediately and that the Indian Affairs Branch will look after payment as and when delivery is made.

Recommended

Deputy Minister

CONNECT SWITCHES AND MULTIBREAKER PANELS

These shall be installed in an approved manner and located as shown on the drawings, or as noted.

CONDUIT SYSTEM

All service drop wires and ground wires shall be run in galvanized rigid steel conduits. All wires in the main school building, manual training building, Church and other buildings as shown on the drawings are to be run in rigid steel conduits, except for surface wiring in the class rooms, and staff quarters which is to be run in surface metal raceway.

Conduit runs which are exposed shall be run to right angle bends and parallel with adjacent walls.

INSTALLATION OF CONDUIT

All conduit must be securely fastened in place by means of approved supports and fastenings.

The conduits shall be installed in the floors and ceilings or in the walls and partitions in such a manner as not to weaken or interfere with the structure of the building.

All conduit shall be cut with a hacksaw, the ends being reamed before installing and after threading.

CONDUIT ENDS

In installing the conduit, particular care should be taken in cutting it to length so that the ends will project into the outlet and distribution boxes a uniform distance and shall be firmly attached by the use of bushings and lock nuts.

SURFACE METAL RACEWAY

The metal raceway must be of an approved type. It must be continuous from outlet to outlet, junction box, or approved fittings designed especially for use with the metal raceway. All outlets must be provided with approved terminal fittings which will protect the insulation, unless such protection is afforded by the construction of the boxes or fittings. All metal raceways and terminal fittings must be securely fastened in place by means of approved supports and fastenings. Metal raceways must not be used in damp places.

GROUNDING

All conduit systems and distribution panels shall be thoroughly and efficiently grounded in an approved manner.

CUTTING AND PATCHING

The contractor shall be responsible for all cutting of holes through walls, floors and ceilings incident to his work and shall be required to patch to match existing wall, floor, and ceiling finishes in the area affected. Skilled workmen shall be employed for this work and it shall be carried out to the satisfaction of the representative of the Engineer.

WIRES

Non-metallic sheathed cable shall be used in wiring the adjacent buildings and residences as called for on the plans and shall be supported and terminated at the boxes and distribution panels in an approved manner.

Thermoplastic wires shall be used in the conduit runs and surface metal raceways.

PULLING WIRES

No wires shall be pulled in until the conduit system is completed and all plastering finished. No oil, grease or compound other than soapstone shall be used to facilitate the pulling of the wires.

JOINTS IN WIRES

All wire shall be continuous between outlets or from the panel to the first outlet.

All joints shall be properly soldered using non-corrosive flux and shall be carefully taped with rubber tape and covered with friction tape, both of approved brands.

FIXTURE LOOPS

At each fixture outlet, the contractor shall leave a loop or end of wire not less than 8" for connection of fixtures.

DISCONNECT SWITCHES AND FEEDERS

Disconnect switches and feeders shall be installed as outlined on the relative drawings.

DISTRIBUTION PANELS

Furnish and install where shown on plans. Panel boards shall be of the multibreaker type with 15 ampere circuits unless otherwise specified, the number of circuits required being shown on the plans.

Each circuit shall be numbered at its switch and a typewritten circuit directory cemented to the panel box.

BRANCH LIGHTING CIRCUITS

All branch lighting circuits, as shown on plans, that are to be installed or modified by the contractor unless otherwise shown shall be of No. 14 B & S. gauge thermoplastic wire. Utility outlets in all cases shall be of No. 12 B. & S. Thermoplastic wire.

Location of Outlets

The right is reserved to change the exact location of any switch, bracket, ceiling or other outlet in any room before same is installed, said changes to be at the option of the Engineer.

If an outlet is installed by the contractor in such a location as to be out of proper relation to beams, walls or other details of the building construction, its location shall be corrected by and at the expense of the contractor under the direction of the Engineer.

Unless otherwise indicated, outlet boxes, etc., shall be located with their center lines at the following elevations:

Switch outlets in all rooms: 4' 0" above floor.
Convenience Receptacle Outlets: 6' 3" above baseboard.
Utility outlets in kitchen and laundry to be located to suit.

Provide and install at all outlets for electric lights and switches, pressed steel outlet boxes. MODIFICATION AND RENEWAL TO THE ELECTRICAL SYSTEM AT ST. GEORGE'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, LYTTON, B.C.

General Conditions:

The entire electrical installation shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations pursuant to the Electrical Energy Inspection Act for the Province of British Columbia. The requirements of this specification and plans are the minimum that will be accepted.

In General:

The contractor shall furnish all materials, labour and equipment for the electrical work on the above-mentioned system, all located on the grounds of the St. George's Residential School at Lytton as shown on the accompanying plans 106 Plates 1 - 9 inclusive and hereinafter specified.

Scope of Contract:

The specifications and accompanying plans are intended to provide for the complete installation of:

(1) A 2300V three phase supply line, a 2300V single phase primary distribution system and a 115/230V secondary network, all as shown on plan 106 Plate 1.

(2) The power and light service installations for the school and surrounding buildings are to be modified as shown on the relative drawings and as described in this specification.

(3) The electric light and power wiring systems from the thermal trip breaker panels in the buildings are to be modified in order to adequately supply the new fixtures and equipment.

(4) Replace all damaged existing fixtures and make repairs and modifications to conduits and splices in wires and drop cords as necessary to make the existing systems which are to be utilized to conform with the B.C. Electrical Code requirements.

(5) Install fire escape lights, exit lights, and a fire alarm system as hereinafter specified and shown on attached drawings.

(6) Each new system and modification to the existing system is to be installed complete in every respect, including all the necessary fixtures and is to be left in perfect operating condition ready for the owner's use, serving all portions of the buildings as intended.

Permits and Fees:

The contractor shall obtain at his own expense all permits for his work and shall pay any lawful charges for inspection or tests.

Drawings and co-operation:

The plans forming part of this contract cover, together with the specifications, the work that is to be done. In case of discrepancy in drawings, the contractor shall submit same to the E. & C. Service of the Indian Commissioner's Office in Vancouver for adjustment. No deviation from drawings will be permitted without written permission from the Indian Commissioner's office in Vancouver.

Materials and Workmanship:

All materials shall be new and of the quality specified. Where

The contractor shall employ men skilled in the work they are to do. All workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be installed in accordance with the best practices of the trade involved. All apparatus and materials used in this work which are subject to approval by the Canadian Standards Association shall bear the C.S.A. number of approval.

Testing and Inspection:

The contractor shall notify the E. & C. Service of the Indian Commissioner's Office, in writing, that the work is ready for inspection at such time as will permit of inspection being made before any work or portion thereof is liable to be concealed.

When the contractor reports, in writing, that the installation is completed and ready for acceptance, an operation test shall be made by the contractor in the presence of a representative from the E. & C. Service to ascertain whether it complies with the specifications and contract. Should it fail to do so, the contractor shall at once remedy all defects. The contractor shall have a representative present during all tests. Final acceptance by the E. & C. Service will be given within ten days after completion and final tests if the installation is found to comply in all respects with the specification and plan.

A Guarantee:

The contractor shall furnish a guarantee covering all labour and material for a period of one year from the date of final acceptance of his work and shall agree to repair and make good, at his expense, any and all defects which may develop in his work during that time, if, in the judgment of the E. & C. Service such defects arise from defective workmanship or materials.

Electrical Current:

2300V 60 cycle three phase current will be obtained from the local power company at a point about 600' distant from the main school building, where a pole top disconnect switch is to be installed.

Metering:

The contractor is to install the following meters in conjunction with the B.C. Electric Power Company:

Main School Building, Church, Manual Training Building and Cannery.

The metering of the single phase three wire lighting power and the three phase motor power for the above-mentioned buildings shall be accomplished by two meters, located in the main school building.

Farm Buildings

The metering of the single phase three wire lighting power supplying these buildings shall be accomplished by a meter connected to the secondary side of a pole mounted transformer supplying these buildings.

Staff Residences

The five residences shall be fitted with individual outside mounted meters.

Outside Distributing System:

General:
General:

The contractor is to erect and install an outside primary distribution system with a secondary network, and service wires as shown on Plate I of Plan 106. The British Columbia Electric Power Company will supply the transformers and make the necessary installation and connections for the transformers at the poles upon which they are mounted. This entire system is to be installed in a manner to conform with the rules for the construction of overhead electric lines in British Columbia, passed by Order in Council under the "Electrical Energy Inspection Act" 1922.

Poles:

The poles are to be winter cut and conform to Class "B" specifications of the B.C. Electric Power Company's Code. Each pole must be given a good brush coat of creosote on the butt, for a distance of seven feet from that end.

Poles supporting both primary and secondary feeders are to have a minimum length of 40 feet and those supporting the secondary feeders alone are to be not shorter than 35 feet.

Setting of Poles:

In normal firm ground the poles must be set to a depth of 6 feet and 5 feet respectively according to their length.

In digging and excavating pole holes, as little material as possible in excess of that necessary to admit and erect the pole is to be removed or disturbed. The diameter of holes dug in earth must be the same from top to bottom and sufficiently large to permit the use of a tamping bar on all sides of the pole.

Poles are to be set to stand perpendicular when the line is completed so that no pole is more than 2° out of line with the others. Poles at line terminals, angles and other points of abnormal stress are to be given a slight rake against the direction of the stress. Poles with a bend are to be placed with the bend in the direction of the line.

In straight runs alternate poles are to be set facing in opposite directions. Poles next to corner poles are to face the corner. Poles next to end poles are to face the end of the line.

After a pole is in position, only one shovel is to be used in filling the hole, while three tampers continuously tamp until the hole is completely filled. When available, small size rocks should be used in the filling.

Guying:

Guys are to be installed wherever the wires tend to pull a pole or cross-arm out of place and when installed are to take up all of the strain so that the pole acts merely as a strut. The only exception to this rule is to be for angles up to ten degrees, when poles which carry not more than 4 No. 6 wires or 2 No. 4 wires are to be raked and the ordinary straight line construction used.

Line Grading:

The length of the poles, if possible, is to be so proportioned to the contour of the ground that the difference between the level of the wires on adjacent poles shall not change by more than 10 feet.

Ground Clearance of Secondary Distribution Lines:

These lines shall have a minimum clearance of 20 feet to ground at the poles and no less than 18 feet to ground at any point over their span lengths.

Racks:
Racks:

All secondary distribution and service connection wires are to be supported on the poles by racks to give 3" spacing between conductors. The racks should be attached to the poles by means of a 5/8" through bolt at the top and a 1/2" lag screw at the bottom as long as no service feeders are attached, in which case 5/8" through bolts must be used at both points of attachment.

Primary Distribution Lines:

The existing supply wire is to be utilized for the primary distribution lines which will be carried on crossarms.

Secondary Distribution Lines:

These lines are to be #4 Medium Hard Drawn Double Braided Weather Proof Wire.

Transformers:

The transformers are to be of capacities as shown on Plate 1. Each transformer is to be protected by two expulsion cutouts fused appropriately adequately grounded, and mounted on the poles located on the above-mentioned drawing.

Clearance to Buildings:

The distribution lines are to be not less than five feet in a horizontal direction or eight feet in a vertical direction from any window, balcony or other part of any building.

Service Conductors:

The minimum size for the service conductors to the homes or other buildings is to be #6 Double Braided Weather Proof wire supported at the structure at a distance of not less than 15 feet from the ground level or sidewalk by end connectors.

Service Drops:

The service drops in all the outlying buildings, other than the Manual Training Building are to be No. 8 Thermoplastic-covered single braided wire carried in a 1/2" galvanized conduit. Those in the Manual Training Building and Church are to be installed as shown on the plans. The service entrance cables are to be equipped with an approved rain type service head. Drip loops are to be formed on each conductor and a minimum of 30" left for splicing.
Memorandum to Mr. Arneil:

Re: Modification and Renewal to the Electrical System - St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

Introduction

In accordance with your instructions, I visited St. George's Indian Residential School on November 2nd, 1949, to inspect the electrical system at the school and obtain sufficient information to draw up plans to improve the lighting in the class rooms and also bring the entire system up to date to meet the requirements of the B.C. Electrical Code.

General Existing Conditions

(1) The illumination in the class rooms, sewing room, manual training shop, kitchen, etc., was entirely inadequate.
(2) The electrical distribution system to the main school and adjacent buildings is in poor condition, since the poles are badly decayed, and should be replaced.
(3) The service entrance panels in all buildings are ungrounded.
(4) The wire and conduit runs in the farm buildings in most cases are partially pulled down and many of the existing fixtures broken.
(5) The wiring runs in the staff homes are in poor condition, the fixtures inadequate and not installed in accordance with B.C. Code requirements.
(6) The staff rooms in the main school building have no utility outlets. At present, drop cords in most cases have been connected to the ceiling fixtures in a precarious manner.

In general, the entire system is in poor condition and requires many modifications. With this in mind, the attached specification and plans have been drawn up to bring the installation up to first class shape.

Proposed Alterations

Main Supply Distribution System

To be rebuilt and modified as shown on the attached plans.

Main School Block

(1) New light and power service boxes and installations to be installed to feed the main school building, manual training building, and Church.

(2) New multi-breaker panels to be installed to feed all circuits.

(3) Fluorescent lights to be installed in class rooms, sewing room, staff dining room, scullery and kitchen.

(4) Utility receptacles to be installed in the staff quarters.

(5) Domestic purpose receptacles to be installed in laundry and sewing room.

(6) Any existing fixtures in disrepair to be repaired or replaced.

(7) Wiring is to be run in ½" conduit using #14 gauge Theroplastic wire except as shown on plans.
(8) Fire escape and exit lighting, and fire alarm system shall be installed as hereinafter specified.

(9) The entire system to be modified to conform with the B.C. Electrical Code requirements.

**Manual Training Building**

(1) New light and power service box assemblies to be installed.

(2) New multi-breaker panels to be installed to feed all circuits.

(3) Fluorescent lights to be installed in the class room and manual training room.

(4) Utility outlets and motor outlets to be installed as shown on plan. All permanent motors to be solidly connected.

(5) Any existing fixtures in disrepair to be repaired or replaced.

(6) Single phase circuits to be run with #14 ga. wire except as shown on plans.

(7) The entire system to be modified to conform to the B.C. Electrical Code requirements.

**Church Building**

(1) Multi-breaker panel to be installed to feed all circuits.

(2) Lamp holders to be replaced in basement outlets.

(3) Any existing fixtures in disrepair to be repaired or replaced.

**Farm Buildings and Teachers' Residences**

(1) Each of the above-mentioned group of buildings is to be provided with a new service entrance installation with multibreaker panel.

The following is a list of the buildings with a general resume of the work required to bring their electrical installations to satisfactory standards.

For full details see appropriate plans attached to this report.

**Cannery**

To be completely rewired in conduit with water-tight fixtures. Juicer to be wired with R.W. or T.W. wire.

**Blacksmith Shop**

To be almost completely rewired in conduit.

**Root House**

To be completely rewired in conduit using R.W. or T.W. wire.

**Dairy Building**

(1) Service entrance and multi-breaker panel to be installed.

(2) Water-tight switches and one water-tight receptacle to be installed. R.W. or T.W. wire to be used.

(3) Water-tight lamp holders to be repaired or replaced.

**Dairy Office**
Dairy Office
To be completely re-wired in non-metallic sheathed cable.

Pig Barn
To be completely wired in conduit with water-tight fittings, and R.W. or T.W. wire.

Granary
To be completely re-wired.

Horse Barn
(1) Service entrance and multibreaker panel to be installed.
(2) Water-tight switches and light fixtures to be installed. R.W. or T.W. wire to be used.

Dairy Barn

(2) Water-tight fixtures installed throughout, and R.W. or T.W. wire to be used.

No. 1 Chicken House

(3) Most of the homes will have to be considered as being entirely re-wired since the fixtures, switches and connections are in such poor condition that it will take as much time to modify the electrical system in these homes as it would to completely re-wire them.

METERING

Main School Building, Church, Manual Training Building, and Cannery
The metering of the single phase three-wire lighting power and the three phase motor power for the above-mentioned buildings will be accomplished by two meters, one for each supply.

The meterings of the single phase three-wire lighting power supplying these buildings will be accomplished by a meter connected to the secondary side of a pole mounted transformer supplying these buildings.

Staff Residences

Recommendations

It is recommended that the work suggested above be carried out this summer as outlined in the accompanying plans and specifications to eliminate the fire hazard which presently exists and provide the classrooms and staff accommodation, etc., with modern light and power facilities when the school re-opens in the fall term.
